791<article>

793 <div class="resize-content">

794

795 <h1>

796Wilms Tumor and Other Childhood Kidney Tumors Treatment (PDQ)Health Professional Version</h1>

797

798 <div id="cgvBody">

799

800 <div class="summary-sections">

801

802 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

803

804 <h6>

805On This Page</h6>

806

807 <ul>

808

809 <li>

810<a href="#_755">

811General Information About Childhood Kidney Tumors</a>

812</li>

813

814 <li>

815<a href="#_1">

816Wilms Tumor</a>

817</li>

818

819 <li>

820<a href="#_432">

821Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC)</a>

822</li>

823

824 <li>

825<a href="#_17">

826Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</a>

827</li>

828

829 <li>

830<a href="#_10">

831Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney</a>

832</li>

833

834 <li>

835<a href="#_429">

836Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma</a>

837</li>

838

839 <li>

840<a href="#_20">

841Ewing Sarcoma of the Kidney</a>

842</li>

843

844 <li>

845<a href="#_1241">

846Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinoma</a>

847</li>

848

849 <li>

850<a href="#_150">

851Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma</a>

852</li>

853

854 <li>

855<a href="#_383">

856Multilocular Cystic Nephroma</a>

857</li>

858

859 <li>

860<a href="#_440">

861Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney</a>

862</li>

863

864 <li>

865<a href="#_438">

866Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma</a>

867</li>

868

869 <li>

870<a href="#_436">

871Nephroblastomatosis</a>

872</li>

873

874 <li>

875<a href="#_1820">

876Special Considerations for the Treatment of Children With Cancer</a>

877</li>

878

879 <li>

880<a href="#_134">

881Changes to This Summary (09/11/2023)</a>

882</li>

883

884 <li>

886About This PDQ Summary</a>

887</li>

888

889 </ul>

890

891</nav>

894 <div class="accordion">

895

896

897

898 <section id="_755">

899

900 <h2>

901General Information About Childhood Kidney Tumors</h2>

902

903 <div id="_section_755" class="pdq-sections">

904<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

905<a href="/types/kidney/patient/wilms-treatment-pdq">

906Go to Patient Version</a>

907</div>

908<p id="_758" tabindex="-1">

909Dramatic improvements in survival have been achieved for children and adolescents with cancer. Between 1975 and 2020, childhood cancer mortality decreased by more than 50%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9101</a>

911-<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9123</a>

913] For children younger than 20 years with Wilms tumor (also known as nephroblastoma), the 5-year relative survival rate is 93%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9142</a>

915] Childhood and adolescent cancer survivors require close monitoring because cancer therapy side effects may persist or develop months or years after treatment. For information about the incidence, type, and monitoring of late effects in childhood and adolescent cancer survivors, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq">

916 Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

917.</p>

918<p id="_759" tabindex="-1">

919Childhood kidney cancers account for about 7% of all childhood cancers. Most childhood kidney cancers are Wilms tumor, but in the 15- to 19-year age group, most tumors are renal cell carcinoma. The 5-year relative survival rate for patients with renal cell carcinoma in this age group is 76%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9202</a>

921] Wilms tumor can affect one kidney (unilateral) or both kidneys (bilateral). Less common types of childhood kidney tumors include <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_17">

922rhabdoid tumors</a>

923, <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_10">

924clear cell sarcoma</a>

925, <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_429">

926congenital mesoblastic nephroma</a>

927, <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_20">

928Ewing sarcoma of the kidney</a>

929, <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1241">

930primary renal myoepithelial carcinoma</a>

931, <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_150">

932cystic partially differentiated nephroblastoma</a>

933, <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_383">

934multilocular cystic nephroma</a>

935,<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_438">

936 primary renal synovial sarcoma</a>

937, and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_440">

938anaplastic sarcoma</a>

939. <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_436">

940Nephroblastomatosis</a>

941 of the kidney is a type of nonmalignant neoplasia.[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

9424</a>

943,<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

9445</a>

945]</p>

946<h6 do-not-show="toc">

947References</h6>

948<ol>

949<li id="section_1.1">

950Smith MA, Altekruse SF, Adamson PC, et al.: Declining childhood and adolescent cancer mortality. Cancer 120 (16): 2497-506, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract">

951[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

952</li>

953<li id="section_1.2">

954National Cancer Institute: NCCR*Explorer: An interactive website for NCCR cancer statistics. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. <a href="https://NCCRExplorer.ccdi.cancer.gov/" title="https://NCCRExplorer.ccdi.cancer.gov/">

955Available online</a>

956. Last accessed May 19, 2023.</li>

957<li id="section_1.3">

958Surveillance Research Program, National Cancer Institute: SEER*Explorer: An interactive website for SEER cancer statistics. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. <a href="https://seer.cancer.gov/statistics-network/explorer/" title="https://seer.cancer.gov/statistics-network/explorer/">

959Available online</a>

960. Last accessed August 18, 2023.</li>

961<li id="section_1.4">

962Ahmed HU, Arya M, Levitt G, et al.: Part I: Primary malignant non-Wilms' renal tumours in children. Lancet Oncol 8 (8): 730-7, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17679083&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17679083&amp;dopt=Abstract">

963[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

964</li>

965<li id="section_1.5">

966Ahmed HU, Arya M, Levitt G, et al.: Part II: Treatment of primary malignant non-Wilms' renal tumours in children. Lancet Oncol 8 (9): 842-8, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17765193&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17765193&amp;dopt=Abstract">

967[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

968</li>

969</ol>

970</div>

971

972 </section>

973

974

975

976 <section id="_1">

977

978 <h2>

979Wilms Tumor</h2>

980

981 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

982<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

983<h6>

984In This Section</h6>

985<ul>

986<li>

987<a href="#_723_toc">

988Incidence of Wilms Tumor</a>

989</li>

990<li>

991<a href="#_1084_toc">

992Syndromes and Other Conditions Associated With Wilms Tumor<ul>

993<li>

994<a href="#_1086_toc">

995Syndromic causes of Wilms tumor</a>

996</li>

997<li>

998<a href="#_1092_toc">

999Nonsyndromic causes of Wilms tumor</a>

1000</li>

1001</ul>

1002</a>

1003</li>

1004<li>

1005<a href="#_1203_toc">

1006Genomics of Wilms Tumor</a>

1007</li>

1008<li>

1009<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777841_13_toc">

1010Molecular Features of Wilms Tumor<ul>

1011<li>

1012<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777841_16_toc">

1013<em class="gene-name">

1014WT1</em>

1015 gene</a>

1016</li>

1017<li>

1018<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777841_33_toc">

1019<em class="gene-name">

1020CTNNB1</em>

1021 gene</a>

1022</li>

1023<li>

1024<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777841_35_toc">

1025<em class="gene-name">

1026AMER1</em>

1027 (<em class="gene-name">

1028WTX</em>

1029) gene on the X chromosome</a>

1030</li>

1031<li>

1032<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777841_37_toc">

1033Imprinting cluster regions (ICRs) on chromosome 11p15 (<em class="gene-name">

1034WT2</em>

1035) and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome</a>

1036</li>

1037<li>

1038<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777841_44_toc">

1039Other genes and chromosomal alterations</a>

1040</li>

1041<li>

1042<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777841_1267_toc">

1043Genomic alterations in Wilms tumor at relapse</a>

1044</li>

1045<li>

1046<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777841_1270_toc">

1047Genomic alterations in adults with Wilms tumor</a>

1048</li>

1049</ul>

1050</a>

1051</li>

1052<li>

1053<a href="#_583_toc">

1054Bilateral Wilms Tumor</a>

1055</li>

1056<li>

1057<a href="#_558_toc">

1058Screening Children Predisposed to Wilms Tumor<ul>

1059<li>

1060<a href="#_1099_toc">

1061Genetic counseling</a>

1062</li>

1063</ul>

1064</a>

1065</li>

1066<li>

1067<a href="#_898_toc">

1068Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

1069</li>

1070<li>

1071<a href="#_900_toc">

1072Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

1073</li>

1074<li>

1075<a href="#_551_toc">

1076Prognosis and Prognostic Factors for Wilms Tumor</a>

1077</li>

1078<li>

1079<a href="#_968_toc">

1080Older Adolescents and Adults With Wilms Tumor<ul>

1081<li>

1082<a href="#_1961_toc">

1083Treatment of adults with Wilms tumor</a>

1084</li>

1085</ul>

1086</a>

1087</li>

1088<li>

1089<a href="#_11_toc">

1090Histological Findings in Wilms Tumor<ul>

1091<li>

1092<a href="#_587_toc">

1093Favorable histology (FH)</a>

1094</li>

1095<li>

1096<a href="#_589_toc">

1097Anaplastic histology</a>

1098</li>

1099<li>

1100<a href="#_2426_toc">

1101Germline <em class="gene-name">

1102TRIM28</em>

1103 testing</a>

1104</li>

1105<li>

1106<a href="#_591_toc">

1107Nephrogenic rests</a>

1108</li>

1109</ul>

1110</a>

1111</li>

1112<li>

1113<a href="#_23_toc">

1114Stage Information for Wilms Tumor<ul>

1115<li>

1118</li>

1119<li>

1120<a href="#_28_toc">

1121Stage II </a>

1122</li>

1123<li>

1124<a href="#_33_toc">

1125Stage III </a>

1126</li>

1129Stage IV </a>

1130</li>

1134</li>

1135</ul>

1136</a>

1137</li>

1138<li>

1139<a href="#_386_toc">

1140Treatment of Wilms Tumor<ul>

1141<li>

1144</li>

1148</li>

1152</li>

1154<a href="#_982_toc">

1156</li>

1157<li>

1158<a href="#_986_toc">

1159Treatment of stage IV Wilms tumor</a>

1160</li>

1161<li>

1164</li>

1165<li>

1167Treatment and outcomes of recurrent Wilms tumor</a>

1168</li>

1169<li>

1170<a href="#_1072_toc">

1171Follow-up after treatment</a>

1172</li>

1173<li>

1174<a href="#_760_toc">

1176</li>

1177</ul>

1178</a>

1179</li>

1180</ul>

1181</nav>

1182<section id="_723">

1183<h3 id="_723_toc">

1184Incidence of Wilms Tumor</h3>

1185<p id="_724" tabindex="-1">

1186Wilms tumor is the most frequent tumor of the kidney in infants and children. The incidence of Wilms tumor is 10.4 cases for every 1 million children younger than 15 years, and 0.2 cases per 10,000 infants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

11871</a>

1188,<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

11892</a>

1190] Approximately 650 cases of Wilms tumor are diagnosed in the United States each year. The incidence is substantially lower in Asian people.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

11911</a>

1192,<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

11933</a>

1194] </p>

1195<p id="_1254" tabindex="-1">

1196The male to female ratio in unilateral cases of Wilms tumor is 0.92 to 1.00, but in bilateral cases, there is a female excess (0.60). The mean age at diagnosis is 44 months in unilateral cases and 31 months in bilateral cases of Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

11974</a>

1198,<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

11995</a>

1200] About 10% of children with Wilms tumor have an associated congenital malformation syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

12016</a>

1202]</p>

1203</section>

1204<section id="_1084">

1205<h3 id="_1084_toc">

1206Syndromes and Other Conditions Associated With Wilms Tumor</h3>

1207<p id="_1087" tabindex="-1">

1208Wilms tumor typically develops in otherwise healthy children without any predisposition to developing cancer. However, approximately 10% of children with Wilms tumor have been reported to have a congenital anomaly.[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

12096</a>

1210,<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

12117</a>

1212] In patients with congenital anomalies and Wilms tumor, nephrogenic rests have been reported in 60% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

12138</a>

1214] Of 295 consecutive patients with Wilms tumor seen at the Institut Curie in Paris, 52 (17.6%) had anomalies or syndromes, 43 of which were considered major, and 14 of which were genetically proven tumor predisposition syndromes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

12159</a>

1216] </p>

1217<p id="_1255" tabindex="-1">

1218Children with Wilms tumor may have associated hemihypertrophy and urinary tract anomalies, including cryptorchidism and hypospadias. Children may have recognizable phenotypic syndromes such as overgrowth, aniridia, genetic malformations, and others. These syndromes have provided clues to the genetic basis of the disease. The phenotypic syndromes and other conditions have been grouped into overgrowth and non-overgrowth categories (see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1947">

1219Table 1</a>

1220). Overgrowth syndromes and conditions are the result of excessive prenatal and postnatal somatic

1221growth.[<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

122210</a>

1223,<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

122411</a>

1225] </p>

1226<p id="_1298" tabindex="-1">

1227It is important to recognize that the absolute risk of developing Wilms tumor varies with the underlying condition or anomaly. For example, most patients with hemihypertrophy will not develop Wilms tumor. </p>

1228<table id="_1947" class="table-default expandable-container">

1229<caption>

1230Table 1. Syndromes and Conditions Associated With Wilms Tumor<span class="sup">

1231a</span>

1232</caption>

1233<colgroup>

1234<col align="Center" width="26.35%">

1235<col width="30.96%">

1236<col width="21.75%">

1237<col width="20.92%">

1238</colgroup>

1239<THead>

1240<tr>

1241<th>

1242Syndrome/Condition</th>

1243<th>

1244Gene</th>

1245<th>

1246Overgrowth Phenotype</th>

1247<th>

1248Non-Overgrowth Phenotype </th>

1249</tr>

1250<tr>

1251<th colspan="4" align="Center" scope="col" valign="Middle">

1252High Risk of Wilms Tumor (&gt;20%)</th>

1555</table>

1556<p id="_1097" tabindex="-1">

1557For information about the genes associated with Wilms tumor, including <em class="gene-name">

1558WT1</em>

1559 and <em class="gene-name">

1560WT2</em>

1561, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1203">

1562Genomics of Wilms Tumor</a>

1563 section.</p>

1564<section id="_1086">

1565<h4 id="_1086_toc">

1566Syndromic causes of Wilms tumor</h4>

1567<section id="_2013">

1568<h5 id="_2013_toc">

1569<em class="gene-name">

1570WT1</em>

1571-related syndromes</h5>

1572<p id="_1256" tabindex="-1">

1573<em class="gene-name">

1574WT1</em>

1575-related syndromes include the following:</p>

1576<div class="pdq-content-list">

1577<ul id="_1257">

1578<li>

1579<strong>

1580WAGR syndrome (WAGR spectrum).</strong>

1581[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

158213</a>

1583] WAGR syndrome is characterized by the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

1584<ul id="_1258" class="list-dash">

1585<li>

1586<strong>

1587W</strong>

1588ilms tumor.</li>

1589<li>

1590<strong>

1591A</strong>

1592niridia.</li>

1593<li>

1594<strong>

1595G</strong>

1596enitourinary abnormalities.</li>

1597<li>

1598<strong>

1599R</strong>

1600ange of developmental delays. </li>

1601</ul>

1602</div>

1603<p id="_1259" tabindex="-1">

1604The constellation of WAGR syndrome occurs in association with an interstitial deletion on chromosome 11 (del(11p13)). The prevalence of this deletion is about 0.4% of children with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

160514</a>

1606,<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

160715</a>

1608] The risk of Wilms tumor development in children with WAGR syndrome is approximately 50%. These children will present earlier (median age, 22 months) and have a higher incidence of bilateral Wilms tumors (37%) than children with nonsyndromic Wilms tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

160916</a>

1610,<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

161117</a>

1612] In 43 patients with WAGR syndrome who developed Wilms tumor or nephroblastomatosis, none of the patients developed metastases or exhibited anaplastic histology. Three patients developed contralateral tumors, one of which occurred 7 years after initial diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

161317</a>

1614] For more information, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1203">

1615Genomics of Wilms Tumor</a>

1616 section.</p>

1617</li>

1618<li>

1619<strong>

1620Denys-Drash syndrome and Frasier syndrome.</strong>

1621 Genitourinary anomalies such as hypospadias, undescended testis, and others are associated with <em class="gene-name">

1622WT1</em>

1623 mutations (prevalence is about 8%&#8211;10% of children with Wilms tumor). Children with XY genome with pseudo-hermaphroditism and/or renal disease (glomerulonephritis or nephrotic syndrome) who develop Wilms tumor may have Denys-Drash or Frasier syndrome (characterized by male hermaphroditism, primary amenorrhea, chronic renal failure, and other abnormalities),[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

162418</a>

1625] both of which are associated with mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

1626WT1</em>

1627 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

162819</a>

1629] Specifically, germline missense mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

1630WT1</em>

1631 gene are responsible for most cases of Wilms tumor that occur as part of Denys-Drash syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

163220</a>

1633,<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

163421</a>

1635] The risk of Wilms tumor is about 90% for children with Denys-Drash syndrome, and bilateral disease develops in 20% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

163621</a>

1637,<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

163822</a>

1639] In Frasier syndrome, splice-site <em class="gene-name">

1640WT1</em>

1641 mutations result in an imbalance of <em class="gene-name">

1642WT1</em>

1643 isoforms and a much lower incidence of Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

164423</a>

1645]</li>

1646</ul>

1647</div>

1648</section>

1649<section id="_2014">

1650<h5 id="_2014_toc">

1651<em class="gene-name">

1652WT2</em>

1653-related syndromes</h5>

1654<p id="_1260" tabindex="-1">

1655<em class="gene-name">

1656WT2</em>

1657-related syndromes include the following:</p>

1658<div class="pdq-content-list">

1659<ul id="_1261">

1660<li>

1661<strong>

1662Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.</strong>

1663 Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by asymmetric growth of one or more parts of the body, large tongue, omphalocele or umbilical hernia at birth, creases or pits in the skin near the ears, kidney abnormalities, and hypoglycemia (in neonates). It is also characterized by the development of Wilms tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, and hepatoblastoma in the first decade of life. Approximately 15% of children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome will have bilateral tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

166424</a>

1665]<p id="_1227" tabindex="-1">

1666Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by altered expression of two gene clusters involved in growth control and cell-cycle progression regulated by two independent imprinting control regions (ICR1 [telomeric ICR] and ICR2 [centromeric ICR]) at chromosome 11p15.5. The two ICRs are characterized by differential methylation of maternal and paternal alleles. A variety of molecular mechanisms are implicated in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome pathogenesis, leading to unbalanced expression of imprinted genes within these two domains. Tumor predisposition results primarily from dysregulation at the telomeric domain of 11p15 (ICR1 gain of methylation [ICR1-GoM] and paternal uniparental disomy [UPD]) rather than at the centromeric domain of 11p15 (ICR2 loss of methylation [ICR2-LoM] and <em class="gene-name">

1667CDKN1C</em>

1668 mutation).[<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

166925</a>

1670] Approximately 15% of cases with clear-cut phenotypes have no molecular defects established so far.[<a href="#cit/section_2.26">

167126</a>

1672,<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

167327</a>

1674]</p>

1675<p id="_1251" tabindex="-1">

1676 The molecular subtypes of the syndrome predispose patients to the development of different tumor histotypes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

167728</a>

1678-<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

167930</a>

1680] </p>

1681<p id="_1180" tabindex="-1">

1682The prevalence of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome has previously been reported as 1% of children with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

168324</a>

1684,<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

168531</a>

1686-<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

168733</a>

1688] However, a 5-year national Dutch cohort study demonstrated that 16% of patients with Wilms tumor (20 of 126) have Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. This study included both patients with clinical diagnoses and patients in which the Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome phenotype was not apparent, such as 11p15 ICR1 gain of methylation in normal renal parenchymal and peripheral blood. Mosaicism likely accounts for the phenotypically occult cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

168934</a>

1690] In aggregate, approximately 10% of patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome will develop Wilms tumor. However, this incidence varies based on epigenotype. Children with ICR1-GoM have the highest risk of developing Wilms tumor (22%&#8211;29%). Children with paternal UPD have a lower risk (7%&#8211;17%), and patients with ICR2-LoM and <em class="gene-name">

1691CDKN1C</em>

1692 mutations have minimal risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

169325</a>

1694,<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

169529</a>

1696,<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

169730</a>

1698] Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome patients with hemihypertrophy have a fourfold increased tumor risk over Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome patients without hemihypertrophy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

169935</a>

1700] For more information, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1203">

1701Genomics of Wilms Tumor</a>

1702 section.</p>

1703</li>

1704</ul>

1705</div>

1706</section>

1707<section id="_2015">

1708<h5 id="_2015_toc">

1709Other syndromic causes of Wilms tumor</h5>

1710<p id="_1262" tabindex="-1">

1711Other syndromic causes of Wilms tumor include the following:</p>

1712<div class="pdq-content-list">

1713<ul id="_1263">

1714<li>

1715<strong>

1716Perlman syndrome.</strong>

1717 This is a rare, autosomal recessively inherited, congenital overgrowth syndrome. It is characterized by fetal gigantism, renal dysplasia and nephroblastomatosis, islet cell hypertrophy, multiple congenital anomalies, and intellectual disability. Survivors have a high risk of developing Wilms tumor (75%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

171836</a>

1719] <p id="_1181" tabindex="-1">

1720Germline inactivating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1721DIS3L2</em>

1722 on chromosome 2q37 are associated with Perlman syndrome. Preliminary data suggest that <em class="gene-name">

1723DIS3L2</em>

1724 plays a role in normal kidney development and in a subset of sporadic Wilms tumor cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

172537</a>

1726]</p>

1727<p id="_2468" tabindex="-1">

1728Heterozygous <em class="gene-name">

1729DIS3L2</em>

1730 constitutional variants appear to have an association with Wilms tumor predisposition. In a 5-year national Dutch cohort study, 4% of patients with Wilms tumors (5 of 126) had <em class="gene-name">

1731DIS3L2</em>

1732 variants. However, penetrance is likely much lower than in homozygous cases (Perlman syndrome).[<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

173334</a>

1734]</p>

1735 </li>

1736<li>

1737<strong>

1738Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome.</strong>

1739 This syndrome is characterized by macroglossia, macrosomia, renal and skeletal abnormalities, and increased risk of embryonal cancers.<p id="_1264" tabindex="-1">

1740The syndrome is caused by mutations or deletions in the <em class="gene-name">

1741GPC3</em>

1742 and <em class="gene-name">

1743GPC4</em>

1744 genes, and these genetic aberrations are believed to enhance the risk of Wilms tumor (8%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.38">

174538</a>

1746]</p>

1747</li>

1748<li>

1749<strong>

1750CLOVES syndrome.</strong>

1751 This syndrome is characterized by the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

1752<ul id="_1865" class="list-dash">

1753<li>

1754<strong>

1755C</strong>

1756ongenital <strong>

1757L</strong>

1758ipomatous <strong>

1759O</strong>

1760vergrowth.</li>

1761<li>

1762<strong>

1763V</strong>

1764ascular malformations.</li>

1765<li>

1766<strong>

1767E</strong>

1768pidermal nevi.</li>

1769<li>

1770<strong>

1771S</strong>

1772keletal/spinal abnormalities. </li>

1773</ul>

1774</div>

1775<p id="_1866" tabindex="-1">

1776This syndrome results from postzygotic, somatic mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1777PIK3CA</em>

1778, which may involve large or small regions of the child.[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

177939</a>

1780]</p>

1781</li>

1782<li>

1783<strong>

1784Sotos syndrome.</strong>

1785 This syndrome is characterized by cerebral gigantism and learning disability, ranging from mild to severe. Sotos syndrome is associated with behavioral problems, congenital cardiac anomalies, neonatal jaundice, and renal anomalies such as Wilms tumor, scoliosis, and seizures. <p id="_1265" tabindex="-1">

1786Mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

1787NSD1</em>

1788 gene are the only known cause of Sotos syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.40">

178940</a>

1790]</p>

1791</li>

1792<li>

1793<strong>

17949q22.3 microdeletion syndrome.</strong>

1795 This syndrome is characterized by craniofacial abnormalities, metopic craniosynostosis, hydrocephalus, macrosomia, and learning disabilities. <p id="_1266" tabindex="-1">

1796Of 44 described patients with 9q22.3 deletions, 7 developed Wilms tumor, and there was an association with overgrowth in 4 of those 7 patients. Although the size of the deletions was variable, all of them encompassed the <em class="gene-name">

1797PTCH1</em>

1798 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

179941</a>

1800]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

180142</a>

1802][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1803Level of evidence C1</a>

1804] According to the authors of this study, surveillance for Wilms tumor should be considered in any patient with 9q22.3 microdeletion syndrome, especially in the presence of overgrowth.[<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

180542</a>

1806][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1807Level of evidence C1</a>

1808] </p>

1809</li>

1810<li>

1811<strong>

1812Bloom syndrome.</strong>

1813 This syndrome is characterized by short stature and being thinner than other family members, sun-sensitive skin changes, and an increased risk of Wilms tumor. <p id="_1267" tabindex="-1">

1814Mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

1815BLM</em>

1816 gene are the only known cause of Bloom syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

181743</a>

1818]</p>

1819</li>

1820<li>

1821<strong>

1822Li-Fraumeni syndrome.</strong>

1823 This syndrome is a rare disorder that greatly increases the risk of developing several types of cancer, particularly in children and young adults.

1824

1825The cancers most often associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome include breast cancer, osteosarcoma, soft tissue sarcoma, brain tumor, leukemia, adrenocortical carcinoma, and Wilms tumor. <p id="_1268" tabindex="-1">

1826The <em>

1827TP53</em>

1828 gene mutation is present in most families with Li-Fraumeni syndrome. The <em class="gene-name">

1829CHEK2</em>

1830 gene mutation is also known to cause Li-Fraumeni syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

183144</a>

1832]</p>

1833</li>

1834<li>

1835<strong>

1836Alagille syndrome.</strong>

1837 This syndrome includes congenital cardiopathy; facial dysmorphology; and vertebral, ocular, and renal abnormalities. It has been reported along with Wilms tumor in two patients who had identified mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

183845</a>

1839]</li>

1840<li>

1841<strong>

1842Bohring-Opitz syndrome.</strong>

1843 This syndrome is a rare genetic condition characterized by distinctive facial features, variable microcephaly, hypertrichosis, nevus flammeus, severe myopia, unusual posture, severe intellectual disability, and feeding issues. <p id="_1269" tabindex="-1">

1844The syndrome is associated with <em class="gene-name">

1845ASXL1</em>

1846 mutations and an estimated incidence of Wilms tumor of 7%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.46">

184746</a>

1848]</p>

1849</li>

1850</ul>

1851</div>

1852</section>

1853</section>

1854<section id="_1092">

1855<h4 id="_1092_toc">

1856Nonsyndromic causes of Wilms tumor</h4>

1857<p id="_1093" tabindex="-1">

1858Nonsyndromic causes of Wilms tumor include the following:</p>

1859<div class="pdq-content-list">

1860<ul id="_1094">

1861<li>

1862<strong>

1863Familial Wilms tumor.</strong>

1864 Despite the number of genes that appear to be involved in the development of

1865Wilms tumor, familial Wilms tumor is uncommon, with approximately 2% of patients

1866having a positive family history of Wilms tumor. Siblings of children with Wilms tumor have a less-than-1% chance of developing Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

186747</a>

1868-<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

186949</a>

1870] The risk of Wilms

1871tumor among offspring of persons who have had unilateral (sporadic)

1872tumors is less than 2%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.50">

187350</a>

1874] <p id="_1095" tabindex="-1">

1875Two distribution loci at 17q12-q21 (<em class="gene-name">

1876FWT1</em>

1877) and 19q13.4 (<em class="gene-name">

1878FWT2</em>

1879) have been identified by genetic linkage studies of families affected by Wilms tumor. Although the genes have yet to be characterized, in siblings with Wilms tumor, loss of function of the transcriptional corepressor TRIM28 was detected, which is located at <em class="gene-name">

1880FWT2</em>

1881.[<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

188251</a>

1883-<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

188453</a>

1885] Occasionally, Wilms tumor families have germline mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1886WT1</em>

1887. In these families, most, but not all, of the family members have genitourinary tract malformations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.54">

188854</a>

1889,<a href="#cit/section_2.55">

189055</a>

1891]</p>

1892<p id="_1135" tabindex="-1">

1893Inactivating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1894CTR9</em>

1895 have been identified in 3 of 35 Wilms tumor families. <em class="gene-name">

1896CTR9</em>

1897 is located at 11p15.3 and is a key component of the polymerase-associated factor 1 (PAF1) complex, which has multiple roles in RNA polymerase II regulation and transcriptional elongation and is implicated in embryonic organogenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

189856</a>

1899] A few families with familial Wilms tumor have germline microdeletion or microinsertion mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

1900H19</em>

1901 region of 11p15.3 that result in hypermethylation of the site.[<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

190257</a>

1903]</p>

1904</li>

1905<li>

1906<strong>

1907Constitutional 11p15 abnormalities.</strong>

1908 Constitutional 11p15 abnormalities have been identified in lymphocyte DNA of 13 of 437 individuals (3%) with sporadic Wilms tumor without features of growth disorders, including 12% of bilateral cases. All were de novo abnormalities and appeared to be postzygotic, except for one novel microdeletion in a child whose mother had the mutation and was not affected; however, a younger brother with the microdeletion had Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. This suggests that constitutional 11p15 analysis should be considered in all individuals with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

190957</a>

1910]</li>

1911<li>

1912<strong>

1913Sporadic aniridia.</strong>

1914 Sporadic aniridia may result from small germline deletions of one copy of the <em class="gene-name">

1915PAX6</em>

1916 gene that includes part or all of the adjacent <em class="gene-name">

1917WT1</em>

1918 gene but does not result in genitourinary abnormalities or intellectual disability (i.e., not obviously WAGR syndrome). Therefore, many patients with sporadic aniridia develop Wilms tumor and are candidates for genetic testing. The relative risk of Wilms tumor in sporadic aniridia is 67-fold.[<a href="#cit/section_2.58">

191958</a>

1920] About one-half of individuals with sporadic aniridia and <em class="gene-name">

1921PAX6</em>

1922 and <em class="gene-name">

1923WT1</em>

1924 deletions develop Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

192559</a>

1926]</li>

1927<li>

1928<strong>

1929Isolated hemihypertrophy (also known as lateralized overgrowth or hemihyperplasia).</strong>

1930 Hemihypertrophy is an asymmetric overgrowth of one or more body parts in the absence of a recognized pattern of malformations, dysplasia, or morphological variants and has been associated with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

193160</a>

1932] It can also be associated with other predisposition syndromes such as Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Clinical signs may not be very evident, and hemihypertrophy may be noted after tumor diagnosis. <p id="_1270" tabindex="-1">

1933In patients with isolated hemihypertrophy and paternal uniparental isodisomy of 11p15.5, the risk of Wilms tumor is estimated to be about 8%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

193461</a>

1935]</p>

1936</li>

1937<li>

1938<strong>

1939Trisomy 18.</strong>

1940[<a href="#cit/section_2.62">

194162</a>

1942]</li>

1943<li>

1944<strong>

1945Fanconi anemia with biallelic mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1946BRCA2</em>

1947 (<em class="gene-name">

1948FANCD1</em>

1949) or <em class="gene-name">

1950PALB2</em>

1951 (<em class="gene-name">

1952FANCN</em>

1953).</strong>

1954 <em class="gene-name">

1955BRCA2</em>

1956 and <em class="gene-name">

1957PALB2</em>

1958 play central roles in homologous recombination DNA repair. Biallelic mutations in either <em class="gene-name">

1959BRCA2</em>

1960 or <em class="gene-name">

1961PALB2</em>

1962 lead to Fanconi anemia and to increased risks of selected childhood cancers, including Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.63">

196363</a>

1964-<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

196565</a>

1966]</li>

1967<li>

1968<strong>

1969Maternal pesticide exposure.</strong>

1970 In a French population study, the maternal use of any household pesticide during pregnancy was associated with a risk of Wilms tumor in children (odds ratio [OR], 1.6). Insecticides were the most commonly reported type of pesticide, and the association with Wilms tumor was stronger when insecticides were used more than once per month.[<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

197166</a>

1972][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1973Level of evidence C1</a>

1974]</li>

1975</ul>

1976</div>

1977</section>

1978</section>

1979<section id="_1203">

1980<h3 id="_1203_toc">

1981Genomics of Wilms Tumor</h3>

1982</section>

1983<section id="_sm_CDR0000777841_13">

1984<h3 id="_sm_CDR0000777841_13_toc">

1985Molecular Features of Wilms Tumor</h3>

1986<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1254" tabindex="-1">

1987A Wilms tumor may arise during embryogenesis on the background of an otherwise genomically normal kidney, or it may arise from nongermline somatic genetic precursor lesions residing in histologically and functionally normal kidney tissue. Hypermethylation of <em class="gene-name">

1988H19</em>

1989, a known component of a subset of Wilms tumors, is a very common genetic abnormality found in these normal-appearing areas of precursor lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.67">

199067</a>

1991]</p>

1992<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_75" tabindex="-1">

1993One study performed genome-wide sequencing, mRNA and miRNA expression, DNA copy number, and methylation analysis on 117 Wilms tumors, followed by targeted sequencing of 651 Wilms tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

199468</a>

1995] The tumors were selected for either favorable histology (FH) Wilms that had relapsed or those with diffuse anaplasia. The study showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

199668</a>

1997]</p>

1998<div class="pdq-content-list">

1999<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_76">

2000<li>

2001Wilms tumors commonly arise through more than one genetic event.</li>

2002<li>

2003Wilms tumors show differences in gene expression and methylation patterns with different genetic aberrations.</li>

2004<li>

2005Wilms tumors have a large number of candidate driver genes, most of which are mutated in less than 5% of Wilms tumors.</li>

2006<li>

2007Wilms tumors have recurrent mutations in genes with common functions, with most involved in either early renal development or epigenetic regulation (e.g., chromatin modifications, transcription elongation, and miRNA).</li>

2008</ul>

2009</div>

2010<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_15" tabindex="-1">

2011Approximately one-third of Wilms tumor cases involve mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2012WT1</em>

2013, <em class="gene-name">

2014CTNNB1</em>

2015, or <em class="gene-name">

2016AMER1</em>

2017 (<em class="gene-name">

2018WTX</em>

2019).[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

202069</a>

2021,<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

202270</a>

2023] Another subset of Wilms tumor cases results from mutations in miRNA processing genes (miRNAPG), including <em class="gene-name">

2024DROSHA</em>

2025, <em class="gene-name">

2026DGCR8</em>

2027, <em class="gene-name">

2028DICER1</em>

2029, and <em class="gene-name">

2030XPO5</em>

2031.[<a href="#cit/section_2.71">

203271</a>

2033-<a href="#cit/section_2.74">

203474</a>

2035] Other genes critical for early renal development that are recurrently mutated in Wilms tumor include <em class="gene-name">

2036SIX1</em>

2037 and <em class="gene-name">

2038SIX2</em>

2039 (transcription factors that play key roles in early renal development),[<a href="#cit/section_2.71">

204071</a>

2041,<a href="#cit/section_2.72">

204272</a>

2043] <em class="gene-name">

2044EP300</em>

2045, <em class="gene-name">

2046CREBBP</em>

2047, and <em class="gene-name">

2048MYCN</em>

2049.[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

205068</a>

2051] Of the mutations in Wilms tumors, 30% to 50% appear to converge on the process of transcriptional elongation in renal development and include the genes <em class="gene-name">

2052MLLT1</em>

2053, <em class="gene-name">

2054BCOR</em>

2055, <em class="gene-name">

2056MAP3K4</em>

2057, <em class="gene-name">

2058BRD7</em>

2059, and <em class="gene-name">

2060HDAC4</em>

2061.[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

206268</a>

2063] Anaplastic Wilms tumor is characterized by the presence of <em class="gene-name">

2064TP53</em>

2065 mutations.</p>

2066<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_21" tabindex="-1">

2067Elevated rates of Wilms tumor are observed in patients with a number of genetic disorders, including WAGR (Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, and range of developmental delays) syndrome (WAGR spectrum), Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, hemihypertrophy, Denys-Drash syndrome, and Perlman syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.75">

206875</a>

2069] Other genetic causes that have been observed in familial Wilms tumor cases include germline mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2070REST</em>

2071 and <em class="gene-name">

2072CTR9</em>

2073.[<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

207456</a>

2075,<a href="#cit/section_2.76">

207676</a>

2077]</p>

2078<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_22" tabindex="-1">

2079The genomic and genetic characteristics of Wilms tumor are summarized below.</p>

2080<section id="_sm_CDR0000777841_16">

2081<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777841_16_toc">

2082<em class="gene-name">

2083WT1</em>

2084 gene</h4>

2085<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_18" tabindex="-1">

2086The

2087<em class="gene-name">

2088WT1</em>

2089 gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 11 (11p13). WT1 is a transcription factor that is required for normal genitourinary development and is important for differentiation of the renal blastema.[<a href="#cit/section_2.77">

209077</a>

2091] <em class="gene-name">

2092WT1</em>

2093 mutations are observed in 10% to 20% of cases of sporadic Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

209469</a>

2095,<a href="#cit/section_2.77">

209677</a>

2097,<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

209878</a>

2099] </p>

2100<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_65" tabindex="-1">

2101Wilms tumor with a <em class="gene-name">

2102WT1</em>

2103 mutation is characterized by the following:</p>

2104<div class="pdq-content-list">

2105<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_19">

2106<li>

2107Evidence of WNT pathway activation by activating mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

2108CTNNB1</em>

2109 gene is common.[<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

211078</a>

2111-<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

211280</a>

2113]</li>

2114<li>

2115Loss of heterozygosity (LOH) at 11p15 is commonly observed, as paternal uniparental disomy for chromosome 11 represents a common mechanism for losing the remaining normal <em class="gene-name">

2116WT1</em>

2117 allele.[<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

211878</a>

2119,<a href="#cit/section_2.81">

212081</a>

2121]</li>

2122<li>

2123Nephrogenic rests are benign foci of embryonal kidney cells that abnormally persist into postnatal life. Intralobar nephrogenic rests occur in approximately 20% of Wilms tumor cases. They are observed at high rates in cases with genetic syndromes that have <em class="gene-name">

2124WT1</em>

2125 mutations such as WAGR and Denys-Drash syndromes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.82">

212682</a>

2127] Intralobar nephrogenic rests are also observed in cases with sporadic <em class="gene-name">

2128WT1</em>

2129 and <em class="gene-name">

2130MLLT1</em>

2131 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.83">

213283</a>

2133,<a href="#cit/section_2.84">

213484</a>

2135] </li>

2136<li>

2137<em class="gene-name">

2138WT1</em>

2139 germline mutations are uncommon (2%&#8211;4%) in nonsyndromic Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.55">

214055</a>

2141,<a href="#cit/section_2.85">

214285</a>

2143]</li>

2144<li>

2145<em class="gene-name">

2146WT1</em>

2147 mutations and 11p15 LOH were associated with relapse in patients with very low-risk Wilms tumor in one study of 56 patients who did not receive chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.86">

214886</a>

2149] These findings need validation but may provide biomarkers for stratifying patients in the future.</li>

2150</ul>

2151</div>

2152<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_20" tabindex="-1">

2153Germline <em class="gene-name">

2154WT1</em>

2155 mutations are more common in children with Wilms tumor <strong>

2156and</strong>

2157 one of the following:</p>

2158<div class="pdq-content-list">

2159<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_23">

2160<li>

2161WAGR syndrome, Denys-Drash syndrome,[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

216221</a>

2163] or Frasier syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

216418</a>

2165]</li>

2166<li>

2167Genitourinary anomalies, including hypospadias and cryptorchidism.</li>

2168<li>

2169Bilateral Wilms tumor.</li>

2170<li>

2171Unilateral Wilms tumor with nephrogenic rests in the contralateral kidney.</li>

2172<li>

2173Stromal and rhabdomyomatous differentiation.</li>

2174</ul>

2175</div>

2176<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_24" tabindex="-1">

2177Germline <em class="gene-name">

2178WT1</em>

2179 point mutations produce genetic syndromes that are characterized by nephropathy, 46XY disorder of sex development, and varying risks of Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

218087</a>

2181,<a href="#cit/section_2.88">

218288</a>

2183] Syndromic conditions with germline <em class="gene-name">

2184WT1</em>

2185 mutations include WAGR syndrome, Denys-Drash syndrome,[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

218621</a>

2187] and Frasier syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

218818</a>

2189]</p>

2190<div class="pdq-content-list">

2191<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_25">

2192<li>

2193<strong>

2194WAGR syndrome.</strong>

2195 Children with WAGR syndrome are at high risk (approximately 50%) of developing Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

21966</a>

2197] WAGR syndrome results from deletions at chromosome 11p13 that involve a set of contiguous genes that include the <em class="gene-name">

2198WT1</em>

2199 and <em class="gene-name">

2200PAX6</em>

2201 genes. <p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_26" tabindex="-1">

2202Inactivating mutations or deletions in the <em class="gene-name">

2203PAX6</em>

2204 gene lead to aniridia, while deletion of <em class="gene-name">

2205WT1</em>

2206 confers the increased risk of Wilms tumor. Loss of the <em class="gene-name">

2207LMO2</em>

2208 gene has been associated with a more frequent development of Wilms tumor in patients with congenital aniridia and WAGR-region deletions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

220989</a>

2210][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2211Level of evidence C1</a>

2212] Sporadic aniridia in which <em class="gene-name">

2213WT1</em>

2214 is not deleted is not associated with increased risk of Wilms tumor. Accordingly, children with familial aniridia, generally occurring for many generations, and without renal abnormalities, have a normal <em class="gene-name">

2215WT1</em>

2216 gene and are not at an increased risk of Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

221731</a>

2218,<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

221990</a>

2220] </p>

2221<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_66" tabindex="-1">

2222Wilms tumor in children with WAGR syndrome is characterized by an excess of bilateral disease, intralobar nephrogenic rests, early age at diagnosis, and stromal-predominant histology in FH tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

222316</a>

2224] The intellectual disability in WAGR syndrome may be secondary to deletion of other genes, including <em class="gene-name">

2225SLC1A2</em>

2226 or <em class="gene-name">

2227BDNF</em>

2228.[<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

222957</a>

2230]</p>

2231</li>

2232</ul>

2233</div>

2234<div class="pdq-content-list">

2235<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_28">

2236<li>

2237<strong>

2238Denys-Drash syndrome.</strong>

2239 This syndrome is characterized by nephrotic syndrome caused by diffuse mesangial sclerosis, XY pseudohermaphroditism, and increased risk of Wilms tumor (&gt;90%). <p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_29" tabindex="-1">

2240<em class="gene-name">

2241WT1</em>

2242 mutations in Denys-Drash syndrome are most often missense mutations in exons 8 and 9, which code for the DNA binding region of <em class="gene-name">

2243WT1</em>

2244.[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

224521</a>

2246]</p>

2247</li>

2248<li>

2249<strong>

2250Frasier syndrome.</strong>

2251 This syndrome is characterized by progressive nephropathy caused by focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, gonadoblastoma, and XY pseudohermaphroditism.<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1257" tabindex="-1">

2252 <em class="gene-name">

2253WT1</em>

2254 mutations in Frasier syndrome typically occur in intron 9 at the KT site, and create an alternative splicing variant, thereby preventing production of the usually more abundant WT1 +KTS isoform.[<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

225523</a>

2256]</p>

2257</li>

2258</ul>

2259</div>

2260<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_81" tabindex="-1">

2261Studies evaluating genotype/phenotype correlations of <em class="gene-name">

2262WT1</em>

2263 mutations have shown that the risk of Wilms tumor is highest for truncating mutations (14 of 17 cases, 82%) and lower for missense mutations (27 of 67 cases, 42%). The risk is lowest for KTS splice site mutations (1 of 27 cases, 4%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

226487</a>

2265,<a href="#cit/section_2.88">

226688</a>

2267] Bilateral Wilms tumor was more common in cases with <em class="gene-name">

2268WT1</em>

2269-truncating mutations (9 of 14 cases) than in cases with <em class="gene-name">

2270WT1</em>

2271 missense mutations (3 of 27 cases).[<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

227287</a>

2273,<a href="#cit/section_2.88">

227488</a>

2275] These genomic studies confirm previous estimates of elevated risk of Wilms tumor for children with Denys-Drash syndrome and low risk of Wilms tumor for children with Frasier syndrome.</p>

2276</section>

2277<section id="_sm_CDR0000777841_33">

2278<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777841_33_toc">

2279<em class="gene-name">

2280CTNNB1</em>

2281 gene</h4>

2282<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_34" tabindex="-1">

2283<em class="gene-name">

2284CTNNB1</em>

2285 is one of the most commonly mutated genes in Wilms tumor, reported to occur in 15% of patients with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

228668</a>

2287,<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

228870</a>

2289,<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

229078</a>

2291,<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

229280</a>

2293,<a href="#cit/section_2.91">

229491</a>

2295] These <em class="gene-name">

2296CTNNB1</em>

2297 mutations result in activation of the WNT pathway, which plays a prominent role in the developing kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_2.92">

229892</a>

2299] <em class="gene-name">

2300CTNNB1</em>

2301 mutations commonly occur with <em class="gene-name">

2302WT1</em>

2303 mutations, and most cases of Wilms tumor with <em class="gene-name">

2304WT1</em>

2305 mutations have a concurrent <em class="gene-name">

2306CTNNB1</em>

2307 mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

230878</a>

2309,<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

231080</a>

2311,<a href="#cit/section_2.91">

231291</a>

2313] Activation of beta-catenin in the presence of intact WT1 protein appears to be inadequate to promote tumor development because <em class="gene-name">

2314CTNNB1</em>

2315 mutations are rarely found in the absence of a <em class="gene-name">

2316WT1</em>

2317 or <em class="gene-name">

2318AMER1</em>

2319 mutation, except when associated with a <em class="gene-name">

2320MLLT1</em>

2321 mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

232270</a>

2323,<a href="#cit/section_2.93">

232493</a>

2325] <em class="gene-name">

2326CTNNB1</em>

2327 mutations appear to be late events in Wilms tumor development because they are found in tumors but not in nephrogenic rests.[<a href="#cit/section_2.83">

232883</a>

2329]</p>

2330</section>

2331<section id="_sm_CDR0000777841_35">

2332<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777841_35_toc">

2333<em class="gene-name">

2334AMER1</em>

2335 (<em class="gene-name">

2336WTX</em>

2337) gene on the X chromosome</h4>

2338<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_36" tabindex="-1">

2339<em class="gene-name">

2340AMER1</em>

2341 is located on the X chromosome at Xq11.1. It is altered in 15% to 20% of Wilms tumor cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

234269</a>

2343,<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

234470</a>

2345,<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

234678</a>

2347,<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

234894</a>

2349,<a href="#cit/section_2.95">

235095</a>

2351] Germline mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2352AMER1</em>

2353 cause an X-linked sclerosing bone dysplasia, osteopathia striata congenita with cranial sclerosis (<a href="http://omim.org/entry/300373" title="http://omim.org/entry/300373">

2354MIM300373</a>

2355).[<a href="#cit/section_2.96">

235696</a>

2357] Despite having germline <em class="gene-name">

2358AMER1</em>

2359 mutations, individuals with osteopathia striata congenita are not predisposed to tumor development.[<a href="#cit/section_2.96">

236096</a>

2361] The AMER1 protein appears to be involved in both the degradation of beta-catenin and in the intracellular distribution of APC protein.[<a href="#cit/section_2.93">

236293</a>

2363,<a href="#cit/section_2.97">

236497</a>

2365] <em class="gene-name">

2366AMER1</em>

2367 is most commonly altered by deletions involving part or all of the <em class="gene-name">

2368AMER1</em>

2369 gene, with deleterious point mutations occurring less commonly.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

237069</a>

2371,<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

237278</a>

2373,<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

237494</a>

2375] Most Wilms tumor cases with <em class="gene-name">

2376AMER1</em>

2377 alterations have epigenetic 11p15 abnormalities.[<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

237878</a>

2379]

2380</p>

2381<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_71" tabindex="-1">

2382<em class="gene-name">

2383AMER1</em>

2384 alterations are equally distributed between males and females, and <em class="gene-name">

2385AMER1</em>

2386 inactivation has no apparent effect on clinical presentation or prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

238769</a>

2388]</p>

2389</section>

2390<section id="_sm_CDR0000777841_37">

2391<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777841_37_toc">

2392Imprinting cluster regions (ICRs) on chromosome 11p15 (<em class="gene-name">

2393WT2</em>

2394) and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome</h4>

2395<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_38" tabindex="-1">

2396A second Wilms tumor locus, <em class="gene-name">

2397WT2</em>

2398, maps to an imprinted region of chromosome 11p15.5. When it is a germline mutation, it causes Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. About 3% of children with Wilms tumor have germline epigenetic or genetic changes at the 11p15.5 growth regulatory locus without any clinical manifestations of overgrowth. Like children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, these children have an increased incidence of bilateral Wilms tumor or familial Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

239957</a>

2400]</p>

2401<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1251" tabindex="-1">

2402Approximately one-fifth of patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome who develop Wilms tumor present with bilateral disease, and metachronous bilateral disease is also observed.[<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

240331</a>

2404-<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

240533</a>

2406] The prevalence of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is about 1% among children with Wilms tumor reported to the National Wilms Tumor Study (NWTS).[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

24074</a>

2408,<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

240933</a>

2410]</p>

2411<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_39" tabindex="-1">

2412Approximately 80% of patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome have a molecular defect of the 11p15 domain.[<a href="#cit/section_2.98">

241398</a>

2414] Various molecular mechanisms underlying Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome have been identified. Some of these abnormalities are genetic (germline mutations of the maternal allele of <em class="gene-name">

2415CDKN1C</em>

2416, paternal uniparental isodisomy of 11p15, or duplication of part of the 11p15 domain) but are more frequently epigenetic (loss of methylation of the maternal ICR2 [<em class="gene-name">

2417CDKN1C</em>

2418 and <em class="gene-name">

2419KCNQ1OT1</em>

2420 genes] or gain of methylation of the maternal ICR1 [<em class="gene-name">

2421IGF2</em>

2422 and <em class="gene-name">

2423H19</em>

2424 genes]).[<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

242557</a>

2426,<a href="#cit/section_2.99">

242799</a>

2428]</p>

2429<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_40" tabindex="-1">

2430Several candidate genes at the <em class="gene-name">

2431WT2</em>

2432 locus comprise the two independent imprinted domains: <em class="gene-name">

2433IGF2</em>

2434 and <em class="gene-name">

2435H19</em>

2436; and <em class="gene-name">

2437CDKN1C </em>

2438 and <em class="gene-name">

2439KCNQ1OT1</em>

2440.[<a href="#cit/section_2.99">

244199</a>

2442] LOH, which exclusively affects the maternal chromosome, has the effect of upregulating paternally active genes and silencing maternally active ones. A loss or switch of the imprint for genes (change in methylation status) in this region has also been frequently observed and results in the same functional aberrations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

244357</a>

2444,<a href="#cit/section_2.98">

244598</a>

2446,<a href="#cit/section_2.99">

244799</a>

2448]</p>

2449<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_41" tabindex="-1">

2450A relationship between epigenotype and phenotype has been shown in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, with a different rate of cancer in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome according to the type of alteration of the 11p15 region.[<a href="#cit/section_2.100">

2451100</a>

2452]</p>

2453<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1228" tabindex="-1">

2454The following four main molecular subtypes of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are characterized by specific genotype-phenotype correlations:</p>

2455<div class="pdq-content-list">

2456<ol id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1250">

2457<li>

2458<strong>

2459ICR1 gain of methylation (ICR1-GoM).</strong>

2460 Five percent to 10% of cases are caused by telomeric ICR1-GoM, which causes both biallelic expression of the <em class="gene-name">

2461IGF2</em>

2462 gene (normally expressed by the paternal allele only) and reduced expression of the oncosuppressor <em class="gene-name">

2463H19</em>

2464 gene. The incidence of Wilms tumor is 22.8%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

2465101</a>

2466]</li>

2467<li>

2468<strong>

2469ICR2 loss of methylation (ICR2-LoM).</strong>

2470 Fifty percent of cases with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are caused by ICR2-LoM, resulting in reduced expression of the <em class="gene-name">

2471CDKN1C</em>

2472 gene, normally expressed by the maternal chromosome only. Tumor incidence is very low (2.5%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

2473101</a>

2474]</li>

2475<li>

2476<strong>

2477Uniparental disomy (UPD).</strong>

2478 Altered expression at both imprinted gene clusters is observed in mosaic UPD of chromosome 11p15.5, accounting for 20% to 25% of the cases. The incidence of Wilms tumor is 6.2%, followed by hepatoblastoma (4.7%) and adrenal carcinoma (1.5%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

2479101</a>

2480] Fewer than 1% of cases with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are caused by chromosomal rearrangements involving the 11p15 region.</li>

2481<li>

2482<strong>

2483<em class="gene-name">

2484CDKN1C</em>

2485 mutations.</strong>

2486 Maternally inheritable <em class="gene-name">

2487CDKN1C</em>

2488 loss-of-function mutations account for approximately 5% of the cases. This type is associated with a 4.3% incidence of neuroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

2489101</a>

2490]</li>

2491</ol>

2492</div>

2493<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1252" tabindex="-1">

2494Other tumors such as neuroblastoma or hepatoblastoma were reported in patients with paternal 11p15 isodisomy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

249525</a>

2496,<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

249729</a>

2498,<a href="#cit/section_2.102">

2499102</a>

2500] For patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, the relative risk of developing hepatoblastoma is 2,280 times that of the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

250133</a>

2502]</p>

2503<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_42" tabindex="-1">

2504Loss of imprinting or gene methylation is rarely found at other loci, supporting the specificity of loss of imprinting at 11p15.5.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

2505103</a>

2506] Interestingly, Wilms tumor in Japanese and East Asian children, which occurs at a lower incidence than in White children, is not associated with either nephrogenic rests or <em class="gene-name">

2507IGF2</em>

2508 loss of imprinting.[<a href="#cit/section_2.104">

2509104</a>

2510]</p>

2511</section>

2512<section id="_sm_CDR0000777841_44">

2513<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777841_44_toc">

2514Other genes and chromosomal alterations</h4>

2515<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_45" tabindex="-1">

2516Additional genes and chromosomal alterations that have been implicated in the pathogenesis and biology of Wilms tumor include the following:</p>

2517<div class="pdq-content-list">

2518<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_46">

2519<li>

2520<strong>

25211q.</strong>

2522 Gain of chromosome 1q is associated with an inferior outcome and is the single most powerful predictor of outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

2523105</a>

2524,<a href="#cit/section_2.106">

2525106</a>

2526] Gain of chromosome 1q is one of the most common cytogenetic abnormalities in Wilms tumor and is observed in approximately 30% of tumors. <p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_49" tabindex="-1">

2527In an analysis of FH Wilms tumor from 1,114 patients from <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

2528NWTS-5 (COG-Q9401/NCT00002611)</a>

2529, 28% of the tumors displayed 1q gain.[<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

2530105</a>

2531] </p>

2532<div class="pdq-content-list">

2533<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_64">

2534<li>

2535The 8-year event-free survival (EFS) rate was 77% for patients with 1q gain and 90% for those lacking 1q gain (<em>

2536P</em>

2537 &lt; .001). Within each disease stage, 1q gain was associated with inferior EFS. </li>

2538<li>

2539The 8-year overall survival (OS) rate was 88% for those with 1q gain and 96% for those lacking 1q gain (<em>

2540P</em>

2541 &lt; .001). OS was significantly inferior in cases with stage I disease (<em>

2542P</em>

2543 &lt; .0015) and stage IV disease (<em>

2544P</em>

2545 = .011).</li>

2546<li>

2547Similar results were reported in the International Society of Paediatric Oncology (SIOP) WT 2001 study of 586 children with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.106">

2548106</a>

2549]</li>

2550</ul>

2551</div>

2552<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1263" tabindex="-1">

2553One study included a cohort of FH Wilms tumor that was enriched for patients who relapsed. The study found that the prevalence of 1q gain was higher in the relapsed Wilms tumor specimens (75%) than in the matched primary samples (47%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

2554107</a>

2555] The increased prevalence of 1q gain at relapse supports its association with poor prognosis and disease progression.</p>

2556</li>

2557<li>

2558<strong>

255916q and 1p.</strong>

2560 Additional tumor-suppressor or tumor-progression genes may lie on chromosomes 16q and 1p, as evidenced by LOH for these regions in 17% and 11% of Wilms tumor cases, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

2561108</a>

2562]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2563<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_51" class="list-dash">

2564<li>

2565 In large NWTS studies, patients with tumor-specific loss of these loci had significantly worse relapse-free survival and OS rates. Combined loss of 1p and 16q are criteria used to select FH Wilms tumor patients for more aggressive therapy in the current Children's Oncology Group (COG) study. However, a U.K. study of more than 400 patients found no significant association between 1p deletion and poor prognosis, but a poor prognosis was associated with 16q LOH.[<a href="#cit/section_2.109">

2566109</a>

2567] </li>

2568<li>

2569An Italian study of 125 patients, using treatment quite similar to that in the COG study, found significantly worse prognosis in those with 1p deletions but not 16q deletions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.110">

2570110</a>

2571] </li>

2572</ul>

2573</div>

2574<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_52" tabindex="-1">

2575These conflicting results may arise from the greater prognostic significance of 1q gain described above. LOH of 16q and 1p loses significance as independent prognostic markers in the presence of 1q gain. However, in the absence of 1q gain, LOH of 16q and 1p retains their adverse prognostic impact.[<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

2576105</a>

2577] The LOH of 16q and 1p appears to arise from complex chromosomal events that result in 1q LOH or 1q gain. The change in 1q appears to be the critical tumorigenic genetic event.[<a href="#cit/section_2.111">

2578111</a>

2579]</p>

2580</li>

2581<li>

2582<strong>

2583miRNAPG.</strong>

2584 Mutations in selected miRNAPG are observed in approximately 20% of Wilms tumor cases and appear to perpetuate the progenitor state.[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

258568</a>

2586,<a href="#cit/section_2.71">

258771</a>

2588-<a href="#cit/section_2.74">

258974</a>

2590] The products of these genes direct the maturation of miRNAs from the initial pre-miRNA transcripts to functional cytoplasmic miRNAs (see Figure 1).[<a href="#cit/section_2.112">

2591112</a>

2592] The most commonly mutated miRNAPG is <em class="gene-name">

2593DROSHA</em>

2594, with a recurrent mutation (E1147K) affecting a metal-binding residue of the RNase IIIb domain, representing about 80% of <em class="gene-name">

2595DROSHA</em>

2596-mutated tumors. Other miRNAPG that are mutated in Wilms tumor include <em class="gene-name">

2597DGCR8</em>

2598, <em class="gene-name">

2599DICER1</em>

2600, <em class="gene-name">

2601TARBP2</em>

2602, <em class="gene-name">

2603DIS3L2</em>

2604, and <em class="gene-name">

2605XPO5</em>

2606. These mutations are generally mutually exclusive, and they appear to be deleterious and result in impaired expression of tumor-suppressing miRNAs. A striking sex bias was noted for patients with mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2607DGCR8</em>

2608 (located on chromosome 22q11), with 38 of 43 cases (88%) arising in girls.[<a href="#cit/section_2.71">

260971</a>

2610,<a href="#cit/section_2.72">

261172</a>

2612]<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_47" tabindex="-1">

2613Germline mutations in miRNAPG are observed for <em class="gene-name">

2614DICER1</em>

2615 and <em class="gene-name">

2616DIS3L2</em>

2617, with mutations in the former causing DICER1 syndrome and mutations in the latter causing Perlman syndrome. </p>

2618<div class="pdq-content-list">

2619<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_72">

2620<li>

2621DICER1 syndrome is typically caused by inherited truncating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2622DICER1</em>

2623, with tumor formation following acquisition of a missense mutation in a domain of the remaining allele of <em class="gene-name">

2624DICER1</em>

2625 (the RNase IIIb domain) responsible for processing miRNAs derived from the 5p arms of pre-miRNAs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.113">

2626113</a>

2627] Tumors associated with DICER1 syndrome include pleuropulmonary blastoma, cystic nephroma, ovarian sex cord&#8211;stromal tumors, multinodular goiter, and embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.113">

2628113</a>

2629] Wilms tumor is an uncommon presentation of the DICER1 syndrome. In one study, three families with DICER1 syndrome included children with Wilms tumor, with two of the Wilms tumor cases showing the typical second <em class="gene-name">

2630DICER1</em>

2631 mutation in the RNase IIIb domain.[<a href="#cit/section_2.114">

2632114</a>

2633] Another study identified <em class="gene-name">

2634DICER1</em>

2635 mutations in 2 of 48 familial Wilms tumor families.[<a href="#cit/section_2.115">

2636115</a>

2637] Large sequencing studies of Wilms tumor cohorts have also observed occasional cases with <em class="gene-name">

2638DICER1</em>

2639 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.72">

264072</a>

2641,<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

264273</a>

2643]</li>

2644<li>

2645Perlman syndrome is a rare overgrowth disorder caused by mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2646DIS3L2</em>

2647, which encodes a ribonuclease that is responsible for degrading pre-let-7 miRNA.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

264837</a>

2649,<a href="#cit/section_2.116">

2650116</a>

2651] Patients with Perlman syndrome have a poor prognosis, with a high neonatal mortality rate. In a survey of published cases of Perlman syndrome (N = 28), in infants who survived beyond the neonatal period, approximately two-thirds developed Wilms tumor, and all patients showed developmental delay. Fetal macrosomia, ascites, and polyhydramnios are frequent manifestations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.117">

2652117</a>

2653]<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_73" tabindex="-1">

2654<figure id="figure_sm_CDR0000777841_55" class="image-center">

2655<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/777941.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2656Enlarge</a>

2657<img id="_sm_CDR0000777841_55" alt="Diagram showing the miRNA processing pathway, which is commonly mutated in Wilms' tumor." title="Diagram showing the miRNA processing pathway, which is commonly mutated in Wilms' tumor." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/777941-750.jpg">

2658<figcaption class="caption-container">

2659Figure 1. The miRNA processing pathway is commonly mutated in Wilms tumor. Expression of mature miRNA is initiated by RNA polymerase&#8211;mediated transcription of DNA-encoded sequences into pri-miRNA, which form a long double-stranded hairpin. This structure is then cleaved by a complex of Drosha and DGCR8 into a smaller pre-miRNA hairpin, which is exported from the nucleus and then cleaved by Dicer (an RNase) and TRBP (with specificity for dsRNA) to remove the hairpin loop and leave two single-stranded miRNAs. The functional strand binds to Argonaute (Ago2) proteins into the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC), where it guides the complex to its target mRNA, while the nonfunctional strand is degraded. Targeting of mRNAs by this method results in mRNA silencing by mRNA cleavage, translational repression, or deadenylation. Let-7 miRNAs are a family of miRNAs highly expressed in ESCs with tumor suppressor properties. In cases in which LIN28 is overexpressed, LIN28 binds to pre-Let-7 miRNA, preventing DICER from binding and resulting in LIN28-activated polyuridylation by TUT4 or TUT7, causing reciprocal DIS3L2-mediated degradation of Let-7 pre-miRNAs. Genes involved in miRNA processing that have been associated with Wilms tumor are highlighted in blue (inactivating) and green (activating) and include DROSHA, DGCR8, XPO5 (encoding exportin-5), DICER1, TARBP2, DIS3L2, and LIN28. Copyright &#169; 2015 <a href="http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/29/5/467.full" title="http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/29/5/467.full">

2660Hohenstein et al.; Published by Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press. Genes Dev. 2015 Mar 1; 29(5): 467&#8211;482. doi: 10.1101/gad.256396.114</a>

2661. This article is distributed exclusively by Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press under a Creative Commons License (Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International), as described at <a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/" title="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/">

2662http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/</a>

2663.

2664</figcaption>

2665</figure>

2666</p>

2667</li>

2668</ul>

2669</div>

2670</li>

2671<li>

2672<strong>

2673<em class="gene-name">

2674SIX1</em>

2675 and <em class="gene-name">

2676SIX2</em>

2677.</strong>

2678 <em class="gene-name">

2679SIX1</em>

2680 and <em class="gene-name">

2681SIX2</em>

2682 are highly homologous transcription factors that play key roles in early renal development and are expressed in the metanephric mesenchyme, where they maintain the mesenchymal progenitor population. In patients with Wilms tumors, the frequency of <em class="gene-name">

2683SIX1</em>

2684 mutations is 3% to 4%, and the frequency of <em class="gene-name">

2685SIX2</em>

2686 mutations is 1% to 3%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.71">

268771</a>

2688,<a href="#cit/section_2.72">

268972</a>

2690]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2691<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1264">

2692<li>

2693 Virtually all <em class="gene-name">

2694SIX1</em>

2695 and <em class="gene-name">

2696SIX2</em>

2697 mutations are in exon 1 and result in a glutamine-to-arginine mutation at position 177 (Q177R).</li>

2698<li>

2699 Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2700WT1</em>

2701, <em class="gene-name">

2702AMER1</em>

2703, and <em class="gene-name">

2704CTNNB1</em>

2705 are infrequent in cases with <em class="gene-name">

2706SIX1</em>

2707, <em class="gene-name">

2708SIX2</em>

2709, or miRNAPG mutations. Conversely, <em class="gene-name">

2710SIX1</em>

2711 or <em class="gene-name">

2712SIX2</em>

2713 mutations and miRNAPG mutations tend to occur together. </li>

2714<li>

2715In Wilms tumor, <em class="gene-name">

2716SIX1</em>

2717 and <em class="gene-name">

2718SIX2</em>

2719 mutations are associated with the high-risk blastemal subtype and the presence of undifferentiated blastema in chemotherapy-na&#239;ve samples.</li>

2720<li>

2721In a study of 82 cases of FH Wilms tumor, <em class="gene-name">

2722SIX1</em>

2723 Q177R hotspot mutations were identified at a higher rate in tumor specimens at relapse (11 cases; 13.4%) than in those at diagnosis (4%). For 45 cases that had both diagnostic and relapse specimens, there were 6 cases with <em class="gene-name">

2724SIX1</em>

2725 Q177R at relapse, 3 of which did not have <em class="gene-name">

2726SIX1</em>

2727 Q177R at diagnosis. This finding suggests that this mutation is not required for tumor development in some individuals with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

2728107</a>

2729]</li>

2730</ul>

2731</div>

2732</li>

2733<li>

2734<strong>

2735<em class="gene-name">

2736MLLT1</em>

2737.</strong>

2738 Approximately 4% of Wilms tumor cases have mutations in the highly conserved YEATS domain of <em class="gene-name">

2739MLLT1</em>

2740 (<em class="gene-name">

2741ENL</em>

2742), a gene known to be involved in transcriptional elongation by RNA polymerase II during early development.[<a href="#cit/section_2.84">

274384</a>

2744] The mutant MLLT1 protein shows altered binding to acetylated histone tails. Patients with <em class="gene-name">

2745MLLT1</em>

2746-mutant tumors present at a younger age and have a high prevalence of precursor intralobar nephrogenic rests, supporting a model whereby activating <em class="gene-name">

2747MLLT1</em>

2748 mutations early in renal development result in the development of Wilms tumor.</li>

2749<li>

2750<strong>

2751<em class="gene-name">

2752TP53</em>

2753 (tumor suppressor gene).</strong>

2754 Most anaplastic Wilms tumor cases show mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

2755TP53</em>

2756 tumor suppressor gene.[<a href="#cit/section_2.118">

2757118</a>

2758-<a href="#cit/section_2.120">

2759120</a>

2760] <em class="gene-name">

2761TP53</em>

2762 may be useful as an unfavorable prognostic marker.[<a href="#cit/section_2.118">

2763118</a>

2764,<a href="#cit/section_2.119">

2765119</a>

2766] <p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_82" tabindex="-1">

2767In a study of 118 prospectively identified patients with diffuse anaplastic Wilms tumor registered on the NWTS-5 trial, 57 patients (48%) demonstrated <em class="gene-name">

2768TP53</em>

2769 mutations, 13 patients (11%) demonstrated <em class="gene-name">

2770TP53</em>

2771 segmental copy number loss without mutations, and 48 patients (41%) lacked both (wild-type <em class="gene-name">

2772TP53</em>

2773 [wt<em class="gene-name">

2774TP53</em>

2775]). All <em class="gene-name">

2776TP53</em>

2777 mutations were detected by sequencing alone. Patients with stage III or stage IV disease with wt<em class="gene-name">

2778TP53</em>

2779 had a significantly lower relapse rate and mortality rate than did patients with <em class="gene-name">

2780TP53</em>

2781 abnormalities (<em>

2782P</em>

2783 = .00006 and <em>

2784P</em>

2785 = .00007, respectively). The TP53 status had no effect on patients with stage I or stage II tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

2786121</a>

2787]</p>

2788<div class="pdq-content-list">

2789<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1258">

2790<li>

2791 In-depth analysis of a subset of 39 patients with diffuse anaplastic Wilms tumor showed that 7 patients (18%) were wt<em class="gene-name">

2792TP53</em>

2793. These wt<em class="gene-name">

2794TP53</em>

2795 tumors demonstrated gene expression evidence of p53 pathway activation. Retrospective pathology review of wt<em class="gene-name">

2796TP53</em>

2797 tumors revealed no or very low volume of anaplasia in six of seven tumors. These data support the key role of TP53 loss in the development of anaplasia in Wilms tumor and support its significant clinical influence in patients who have residual anaplastic disease after surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

2798121</a>

2799]</li>

2800</ul>

2801</div>

2802</li>

2803<li>

2804<strong>

2805<em class="gene-name">

2806FBXW7</em>

2807.</strong>

2808 <em class="gene-name">

2809FBXW7</em>

2810, a ubiquitin ligase component, is an established tumor suppressor gene that has been identified as recurrently mutated at low rates in Wilms tumor and other malignancies. Mutations of this gene have been associated with epithelial-type tumor histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.122">

2811122</a>

2812]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.123">

2813123</a>

2814][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2815Level of evidence C1</a>

2816]</li>

2817<li>

2818<strong>

2819<em class="gene-name">

2820TRIM28</em>

2821.</strong>

2822 <em class="gene-name">

2823TRIM28</em>

2824 encodes a multidomain protein involved in the regulation of many cellular processes and is an autosomal dominant Wilms tumor predisposition gene. <em class="gene-name">

2825TRIM28</em>

2826 accounts for about 8% of familial Wilms tumor and 2% of unselected Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

282753</a>

2828,<a href="#cit/section_2.124">

2829124</a>

2830-<a href="#cit/section_2.126">

2831126</a>

2832]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.123">

2833123</a>

2834][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2835Level of evidence C1</a>

2836]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2837<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1265">

2838<li>

2839 A strong association between <em class="gene-name">

2840TRIM28</em>

2841 mutations and epithelial Wilms tumor has been observed, and most individuals with a <em class="gene-name">

2842TRIM28</em>

2843 mutation have a Wilms tumor of predominantly epithelial histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

284453</a>

2845,<a href="#cit/section_2.124">

2846124</a>

2847,<a href="#cit/section_2.125">

2848125</a>

2849]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.123">

2850123</a>

2851][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2852Level of evidence C1</a>

2853]</li>

2854<li>

2855 In a cohort of 91 affected individuals from 49 families with Wilms tumor pedigrees, 33 individuals were identified as having constitutional cancer-predisposing mutations, 21 of whom had a mutation in <em class="gene-name">

2856TRIM28</em>

2857. There was a strong parent-of-origin effect, with all ten evaluable cases having inherited mutations that were maternally transmitted.[<a href="#cit/section_2.123">

2858123</a>
