2859][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2860Level of evidence C1</a>

2861]</li>

2862<li>

2863Most <em class="gene-name">

2864TRIM28</em>

2865-mutated cases have either frameshift, nonsense, or splice-site mutations in one allele combined with LOH in the second allele, leading to loss of TRIM28 protein expression in the tumor. Immunohistochemistry staining for loss of TRIM28 protein expression can be used to identify most patients whose tumors have <em class="gene-name">

2866TRIM28</em>

2867 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.126">

2868126</a>

2869]</li>

2870</ul>

2871</div>

2872</li>

2873<li>

2874<strong>

28759q22.3 microdeletion syndrome.</strong>

2876 Patients with 9q22.3 microdeletion syndrome have an increased risk of Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

287741</a>

2878] The chromosomal region with germline deletion includes <em class="gene-name">

2879PTCH1</em>

2880, the gene that is mutated in Gorlin syndrome (nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome associated with osteosarcoma). 9q22.3 microdeletion syndrome is characterized by the clinical findings of Gorlin syndrome, as well as developmental delay and/or intellectual disability, metopic craniosynostosis, obstructive hydrocephalus, prenatal and postnatal macrosomia, and seizures. Five patients who presented with Wilms tumor in the context of a constitutional 9q22.3 microdeletion have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

288141</a>

2882,<a href="#cit/section_2.127">

2883127</a>

2884,<a href="#cit/section_2.128">

2885128</a>

2886] </li>

2887<li>

2888<strong>

2889<em class="gene-name">

2890MYCN</em>

2891.</strong>

2892 Genomic alterations involving the <em class="gene-name">

2893MYCN</em>

2894 network (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

2895MYCN</em>

2896, <em class="gene-name">

2897MAX</em>

2898, <em class="gene-name">

2899MGA</em>

2900, <em class="gene-name">

2901NONO</em>

2902) have been reported to occur in 25% to 30% of Wilms tumor cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

2903107</a>

2904] Specific genomic alterations associated with the <em class="gene-name">

2905MYCN</em>

2906 network include the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

2907<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1266">

2908<li>

2909<em class="gene-name">

2910MYCN</em>

2911 copy number gain was observed in approximately 13% of Wilms tumor cases. <em class="gene-name">

2912MYCN</em>

2913 gain was more common in anaplastic cases (7 of 23 cases, 30%) than in nonanaplastic cases (11.2%), and it was associated with poorer relapse-free survival (RFS) and overall survival, independent of histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.129">

2914129</a>

2915] <em class="gene-name">

2916MYCN</em>

2917 tandem duplication was reported in 11 of 82 (13%) FH Wilms tumor specimens from relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

2918107</a>

2919]</li>

2920<li>

2921 Germline copy number gain at <em class="gene-name">

2922MYCN</em>

2923 has been reported in a bilateral Wilms tumor case,[<a href="#cit/section_2.129">

2924129</a>

2925] and germline <em class="gene-name">

2926MYCN</em>

2927 duplication was also reported for a child with prenatal bilateral nephroblastomatosis and a family history of nephroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.130">

2928130</a>

2929]</li>

2930<li>

2931Mutations at codon 44 (p.P44L) of <em class="gene-name">

2932MYCN</em>

2933 are observed in approximately 3% to 4% of Wilms tumor cases at diagnosis [<a href="#cit/section_2.129">

2934129</a>

2935,<a href="#cit/section_2.131">

2936131</a>

2937] and in 8.5% of cases at relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

2938107</a>

2939] In a study of 810 Wilms tumor cases, 24 (3%) had <em class="gene-name">

2940MYCN</em>

2941 P44L hotspot mutations. RFS was significantly lower (68.6%) in patients with P44L mutations than in patients with wild-type <em class="gene-name">

2942MYCN</em>

2943 status (87.1%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.131">

2944131</a>

2945]</li>

2946<li>

2947The MYCN interacting protein MAX was mutated at codon 60 (R60Q) in 7 of 782 Wilms tumor cases (0.9%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.131">

2948131</a>

2949] RFS was significantly lower in patients with the <em class="gene-name">

2950MAX</em>

2951 R60Q hotspot mutation than in patients with wild-type <em class="gene-name">

2952MAX</em>

2953 status.</li>

2954</ul>

2955</div>

2956</li>

2957<li>

2958<strong>

2959<em class="gene-name">

2960CTR9</em>

2961.</strong>

2962 Inactivating <em class="gene-name">

2963CTR9</em>

2964 germline mutations were identified in 4 of 36 familial Wilms tumor pedigrees.[<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

296556</a>

2966,<a href="#cit/section_2.132">

2967132</a>

2968] <em class="gene-name">

2969CTR9</em>

2970, which is located at chromosome 11p15.3, is a key component of the polymerase-associated factor 1 complex (PAF1c), which has multiple roles in RNA polymerase II regulation and is implicated in embryonic organogenesis and maintenance of embryonic stem cell pluripotency.</li>

2971<li>

2972<strong>

2973<em class="gene-name">

2974REST</em>

2975.</strong>

2976 Inactivating germline mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2977REST</em>

2978 (encoding RE1-silencing transcription factor) were identified in four familial Wilms tumor pedigrees.[<a href="#cit/section_2.76">

297976</a>

2980] REST is a transcriptional repressor that functions in cellular differentiation and embryonic development. Most <em class="gene-name">

2981REST</em>

2982 mutations clustered within the portion of REST encoding the DNA-binding domain, and functional analyses showed that these mutations compromise REST transcriptional repression. When screened for <em class="gene-name">

2983REST</em>

2984 mutations, 9 of 519 individuals with Wilms tumor who had no history of relatives with the disease tested positive for the mutation; some had parents who also tested positive.[<a href="#cit/section_2.76">

298576</a>

2986] These observations indicate that <em class="gene-name">

2987REST</em>

2988 is a Wilms tumor predisposition gene associated with approximately 2% of Wilms tumor.</li>

2989</ul>

2990</div>

2991<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_53" tabindex="-1">

2992Figure 2 summarizes the genomic landscape of a selected cohort of Wilms tumor patients selected because they experienced relapse despite showing FH.[<a href="#cit/section_2.84">

299384</a>

2994] The 75 FH Wilms tumor cases were clustered by unsupervised analysis of gene expression data, resulting in six clusters. Five of six <em class="gene-name">

2995MLLT1</em>

2996-mutant tumors with available gene expression data were in cluster 3, and two were accompanied by <em class="gene-name">

2997CTNNB1</em>

2998 mutations. This cluster also contained four tumors with a mutation or small segment deletion of <em class="gene-name">

2999WT1</em>

3000, all of which also had either a mutation of <em class="gene-name">

3001CTNNB1</em>

3002 or small segment deletion or mutation of <em class="gene-name">

3003AMER1</em>

3004. It also contained a substantial number of tumors with retention of imprinting of 11p15 (including all <em class="gene-name">

3005MLLT1</em>

3006-mutant tumors). The miRNAPG-mutated cases clustered together and were mutually exclusive with both <em class="gene-name">

3007MLLT1</em>

3008 and with <em class="gene-name">

3009WT1</em>

3010-, <em class="gene-name">

3011AMER1</em>

3012-, or <em class="gene-name">

3013CTNNB1</em>

3014-mutated cases.</p>

3015<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_56" tabindex="-1">

3016<figure id="figure_sm_CDR0000777841_57" class="image-center">

3017<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/777942.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

3018Enlarge</a>

3019<img id="_sm_CDR0000777841_57" alt="Chart showing unsupervised analysis of gene expression data for clinically distinctive favorable histology Wilms tumor." title="Chart showing unsupervised analysis of gene expression data for clinically distinctive favorable histology Wilms tumor." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/777942-750.jpg">

3020<figcaption class="caption-container">

3021Figure 2. Unsupervised analysis of gene expression data. Non-negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) analysis of 75 FH Wilms tumor resulted in six clusters. Five of six <em class="gene-name">

3022MLLT1</em>

3023 mutant tumors with available gene expression data occurred in NMF cluster 3, and two were accompanied by <em class="gene-name">

3024CTNNB1</em>

3025 mutations. This cluster also contained a substantial number of tumors with retention of imprinting of 11p15 (including all <em class="gene-name">

3026MLLT1</em>

3027-mutant tumors), in contrast to other clusters, where most cases showed 11p15 loss of heterozygosity or retention of imprinting. Almost all miRNAPG-mutated cases were in NMF cluster 2, and most <em class="gene-name">

3028WT1</em>

3029, <em class="gene-name">

3030WTX</em>

3031, and <em class="gene-name">

3032CTNNB1</em>

3033 mutations were in NMF clusters 3 and 4. Copyright &#169; 2015 <a href="http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/151204/ncomms10013/full/ncomms10013.html" title="http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/151204/ncomms10013/full/ncomms10013.html">

3034Perlman, E. J. et al. MLLT1 YEATS domain mutations in clinically distinctive Favourable Histology wilms tumours. Nat. Commun. 6:10013 doi: 10.1038/ncomms10013 (2015).</a>

3035 This article is distributed by Nature Publishing Group, a division of Macmillan Publishers Limited under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License, as described at <a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/" title="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/">

3036http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</a>

3037. </figcaption>

3038</figure>

3039</p>

3040</section>

3041<section id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1267">

3042<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1267_toc">

3043Genomic alterations in Wilms tumor at relapse</h4>

3044<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1268" tabindex="-1">

3045Wilms tumor at relapse appears to maintain most of the genomic alterations present at diagnosis, although there may be changes in the prevalence of alterations in specific genes between diagnosis and relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

3046107</a>

3047] A study from the Children&#8217;s Oncology Group presented whole-genome sequencing (WGS) data on relapse tumor specimens from 51 patients and corresponding diagnostic specimens from 45 of these patients. For an additional 31 patients who had relapse specimens available, a targeted sequencing panel was applied. Key findings included the following:</p>

3048<div class="pdq-content-list">

3049<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1269">

3050<li>

3051The prevalence of 1q gain in relapsed Wilms tumor specimens (75%) was higher than that observed for tumors at diagnosis (47%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

3052107</a>

3053] The increased prevalence of 1q gain at relapse is consistent with its association with poor prognosis and disease progression.</li>

3054<li>

3055<em class="gene-name">

3056SIX1</em>

3057 Q177R hotspot mutations were identified at a higher rate in tumor specimens at relapse (11 of 82 cases; 13.4%) than in those at diagnosis (4%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

3058107</a>

3059] For 45 cases with both diagnostic and relapse specimens, there were 6 cases with <em class="gene-name">

3060SIX1</em>

3061 Q177R at relapse, 3 of which did not have <em class="gene-name">

3062SIX1</em>

3063 Q177R at diagnosis. This is consistent with <em class="gene-name">

3064SIX1</em>

3065 Q177R not being an early tumorigenesis event in some cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

3066107</a>

3067]</li>

3068<li>

3069Genomic alterations in genes associated with the <em class="gene-name">

3070MYCN</em>

3071 network were present in approximately 30% of Wilms tumor cases at relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

3072107</a>

3073] The most common <em class="gene-name">

3074MYCN</em>

3075 network alterations were <em class="gene-name">

3076MYCN</em>

3077 tandem duplication (13%) and <em class="gene-name">

3078MYCN</em>

3079 P44L hotspot mutations (11%). </li>

3080</ul>

3081</div>

3082</section>

3083<section id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1270">

3084<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1270_toc">

3085Genomic alterations in adults with Wilms tumor</h4>

3086<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1271" tabindex="-1">

3087Wilms tumor in patients older than 16 years is rare, with an incidence rate of less than 0.2 cases per 1 million people per year.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

30882</a>

3089] As a result, there are limited data available describing the genomic alterations that are observed in adults with Wilms tumor. </p>

3090<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1272" tabindex="-1">

3091A study of 14 patients with a Wilms tumor diagnosis who were older than 16 years (range, 17&#8211;46 years; median age, 31 years) evaluated exonic mutations for 1,425 cancer-related genes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3092133</a>

3093]</p>

3094<div class="pdq-content-list">

3095<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1275">

3096<li>

3097Five patients (36%) harbored <em class="gene-name">

3098BRAF</em>

3099 V600E mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3100133</a>

3101] While <em class="gene-name">

3102BRAF</em>

3103 V600E mutations are extremely uncommon in pediatric Wilms tumor, they are present in 90% of metanephric adenomas of the kidney, a typically benign condition arising almost exclusively in adults.[<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

3104134</a>

3105]</li>

3106<li>

3107 All five adult cases of Wilms tumor with <em class="gene-name">

3108BRAF</em>

3109 V600E had better-differentiated areas identical to metanephric adenoma adjacent to areas consistent in appearance with epithelial Wilms tumor.</li>

3110<li>

3111 Two of the five cases with <em class="gene-name">

3112BRAF</em>

3113 V600E mutations had <em class="gene-name">

3114TERT</em>

3115 promoter mutations in addition to <em class="gene-name">

3116BRAF</em>

3117 mutations.</li>

3118<li>

3119<em class="gene-name">

3120ASXL1</em>

3121 mutations were observed in 4 of 14 cases, including 1 of 5 cases with <em class="gene-name">

3122BRAF</em>

3123 V600E mutations and 3 of 9 cases without <em class="gene-name">

3124BRAF</em>

3125 V600E mutations. <em class="gene-name">

3126ASXL1</em>

3127 mutations are not common in pediatric Wilms tumor (approximately 2% of cases).[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

312868</a>

3129]</li>

3130<li>

3131 For the nine tumors that did not have <em class="gene-name">

3132BRAF</em>

3133 mutations, some had genomic alterations associated with Wilms tumor in children (e.g., 1q gain and mutations in <em class="gene-name">

3134WT1</em>

3135 [n = 2]).</li>

3136</ul>

3137</div>

3138<p id="_sm_CDR0000777841_1273" tabindex="-1">

3139Another report described renal tumors that had histological overlap between metanephric adenoma and epithelial Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.135">

3140135</a>

3141] While most epithelial Wilms tumors (five of nine) with areas resembling metanephric adenoma were negative for <em class="gene-name">

3142BRAF</em>

3143 V600E mutations, four cases were positive for the <em class="gene-name">

3144BRAF</em>

3145 V600E mutation. Two of the cases with <em class="gene-name">

3146BRAF</em>

3147 V600E mutations occurred in children (aged 3 years and 6 years), and the other two cases occurred in adults. </p>

3148</section>

3149</section>

3150<section id="_583">

3151<h3 id="_583_toc">

3152Bilateral Wilms Tumor</h3>

3153<p id="_997" tabindex="-1">

3154Approximately 5% to 10% of individuals with Wilms tumor have bilateral or multicentric tumors. The prevalence of bilateral involvement is higher in individuals with genetic predisposition syndromes than in those without predisposition syndromes. For example, in 545 cases of bilateral Wilms tumors, bona fide pathogenic germline variants were found in 22% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

3155136</a>

3156] The most common predisposition variants are mutations of <em class="gene-name">

3157WT1</em>

3158 and 11p15 loss of imprinting.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

315924</a>

3160,<a href="#cit/section_2.77">

316177</a>

3162]</p>

3163<p id="_2416" tabindex="-1">

3164Bilateral disease can be synchronous (both kidneys affected at the same time) or metachronous (one affected after the other) and occurs in 6.3% and 0.85% of patients with Wilms tumor, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

31654</a>

3166] In general, perilobar nephrogenic rests are associated with synchronous bilateral Wilms tumor, whereas intralobar nephrogenic rests are more strongly associated with metachronous Wilms tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.137">

3167137</a>

3168]</p>

3169<p id="_999" tabindex="-1">

3170Bilateral Wilms tumors with <em class="gene-name">

3171WT1</em>

3172 mutations are associated with early presentation in pediatric patients (age 10 months vs. age 39 months for those without a mutation) and a high frequency of <em class="gene-name">

3173WT1</em>

3174 nonsense mutations in exon 8. Three percent of patients with bilateral Wilms tumor have affected family members.[<a href="#cit/section_2.138">

3175138</a>

3176]</p>

3177<p id="_1978" tabindex="-1">

3178Genomic analysis of kidney tissue in bilateral Wilms tumor indicates that a clonal expansion early in the nephrogenesis of normal-appearing but genetically aberrant precursor lesions occurred before the divergence of left and right kidney primordia.[<a href="#cit/section_2.67">

317967</a>

3180]</p>

3181</section>

3182<section id="_558">

3183<h3 id="_558_toc">

3184Screening Children Predisposed to Wilms Tumor</h3>

3185<p id="_559" tabindex="-1">

3186The primary purpose of screening is to enable earlier detection of a small and localized tumor (stage I or II), improve prognosis, and use less intensive treatment (such as to facilitate nephron-sparing surgery).[<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

3187139</a>

3188] Children with a significant increased predisposition to develop Wilms tumor (e.g.,

3189most children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome or other overgrowth syndromes, WAGR syndrome, Denys-Drash syndrome, sporadic aniridia, or isolated hemihypertrophy) are usually screened with ultrasonography every 3

3190months until they reach at least age 8 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

319190</a>

3192,<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

3193139</a>

3194]</p>

3195<p id="_675" tabindex="-1">

3196Tumor screening programs for each overgrowth syndrome have been suggested. These programs were based on published age, incidence of tumor type, and recommendations from the 2016 American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Childhood Cancer Predisposition Workshop. Although data about different cancer risks based on genetic or epigenetic subgroups for certain syndromes are emerging, and subgroup-specific recommendations have been developed in Europe, these practices have not been adopted in the United States. The AACR workshop committee proposed a uniform screening approach for all syndromes associated with a greater-than-1% risk of Wilms tumor. Additional screening for hepatoblastoma by serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) measurement and ultrasonography is also recommended for patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, trisomy 18, and Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

3197140</a>

3198]</p>

3199<p id="_1994" tabindex="-1">

3200On the basis of a literature search of patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann spectrum and Wilms tumor where the age at diagnosis was compared against data collected through the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program, screening patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann spectrum seems to significantly decrease the age and stage at the time of diagnosis in this population. Screening until age 7 years is effective in detecting close to 95% of all Wilms tumors in Beckwith-Wiedemann spectrum. Screening until age 30 months may also prove useful for patients with IC2 LoM, consistent with the recommendations for hepatoblastoma screening in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.141">

3201141</a>

3202]</p>

3203<div class="pdq-content-list">

3204<ul id="_1271">

3205<li>

3206<strong>

3207Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.</strong>

3208 Approximately 8% of patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome will develop a malignancy, with the most common being either Wilms tumor or hepatoblastoma, although adrenal tumors can also occur.[<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

3209101</a>

3210] <p id="_1927" tabindex="-1">

3211 Screening for hepatoblastoma or adrenal tumors with abdominal ultrasonography and serum AFP usually begins at birth or when the syndrome is diagnosed and continues until age 4 years. After age 4 years, most hepatoblastomas will have occurred, and imaging may be limited to renal ultrasonography, which is quicker and does not require fasting before the exam.[<a href="#cit/section_2.142">

3212142</a>

3213]</p>

3214<p id="_1995" tabindex="-1">

3215 Screening for Wilms tumor usually continues until age 8 years. Physical examination by a specialist (geneticist or pediatric oncologist) is recommended twice per year, and ongoing education regarding tumor manifestations, reinforcing the rationale for screening and compliance with the screening regimen, is discussed.[<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

3216140</a>

3217]</p>

3218<p id="_1272" tabindex="-1">

3219Proposed screening guidelines for Wilms tumor are available for patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome who have undergone molecular subtyping.[<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

3220101</a>

3221] The four main molecular subtypes of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (ICR1-GoM, ICR2-LoM, UPD, and <em class="gene-name">

3222CDKN1C</em>

3223 mutation) are characterized by specific genotype-phenotype correlations, including tumor risk. For more information about the molecular subtypes, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1203">

3224Genomics of Wilms Tumor</a>

3225 section.</p>

3226<p id="_1273" tabindex="-1">

3227Proposed screening for specific molecular subtypes of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is as follows:</p>

3228<div class="pdq-content-list">

3229<ul id="_1274" class="list-dash">

3230<li>

3231Patients with a defect of the ICR1 region (ICR1-GoM) and UPD should undergo abdominal ultrasonography every 3 months until age 8 to 10 years. A clinical examination of the abdomen and muscle mass occurs monthly for the first year and then at 3-month intervals, between ultrasonography scans, until age 6 years. </li>

3232<li>

3233For patients with loss of imprinting at ICR2 (ICR2-LoM), an abdominal ultrasonography is performed at the time of clinical or molecular diagnosis. Only patients with organomegaly or severe hemihypertrophy require surveillance by ultrasonography scans. Monthly clinical examinations are performed for the first 2 years, followed by clinical examinations every 3 to 6 months until age 6 years.</li>

3234<li>

3235Patients with a <em class="gene-name">

3236CDKN1C</em>

3237 mutation are not at high risk of developing Wilms tumor. There are no data to support routine screening.</li>

3238</ul>

3239</div>

3240</li>

3241<li>

3242<strong>

3243WAGR Syndrome (or WAGR Spectrum).</strong>

3244 Patients with WAGR spectrum tend to experience an earlier age of initial Wilms tumor development compared with patients with nonsyndromic Wilms tumor. Using data from the WAGR Syndrome Patient Registry (n = 91), the reported median age at initial development of Wilms tumor or isolated nephrogenic rests was 19 months (range, 11&#8211;28 months). All patients with reported Wilms tumor developed their initial Wilms tumor by age 8 years, and 95% of patients developed their tumor by age 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

324513</a>

3246] Other investigators have reported that approximately 20% of patients developed their Wilms tumor after age 4 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

324715</a>

3248,<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

324916</a>

3250] <p id="_2442" tabindex="-1">

3251Multiple patients have been diagnosed with the development of Wilms tumor past the age of 7 to 8 years and/or relapse occurring years after initial diagnosis. Some cases labeled as relapses have been de novo disease in the contralateral kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

325216</a>

3253] In the WAGR Syndrome Patient Registry, late presentation of relapse occurred in one participant at age 19 years, 7 months, which was more than 17 years from their first Wilms tumor diagnosis and represented the third occurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

325413</a>

3255]</p>

3256<p id="_2417" tabindex="-1">

3257Investigators from SIOP have reported about the benefit of surveillance in a cohort of 43 patients with WAGR Syndrome and Wilms tumor/nephroblastomatosis enrolled in SIOP treatment studies. Of 39 patients, 27 (69%) were asymptomatic and the tumors were detected by surveillance, whereas 12 patients (31%) presented with a palpable/visible abdominal mass and/or other symptoms. Of these 12 patients, 2 had not been diagnosed with WAGR syndrome. Tumors detected by surveillance had a significantly decreased volume compared with tumors that were symptomatic (18 mL vs. 375 mL; <em>

3258P</em>

3259 = .001), which enabled a high rate of nephron-sparing surgery (85%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.143">

3260143</a>

3261] The authors recommend the use of preoperative chemotherapy as treatment for patients with WAGR syndrome in order to facilitate nephron-sparing surgery. This surgery can improve outcomes for patients with chronic kidney disease associated with WAGR syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.144">

3262144</a>

3263] Preoperative chemotherapy has been reported to decrease tumor size in 50% of WAGR patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.143">

3264143</a>

3265]</p>

3266<p id="_2418" tabindex="-1">

3267 Surveillance options for the WAGR population at age 8 years and older should be discussed with the patient&#8217;s family and multidisciplinary health care team to determine the appropriate follow-up schedule for Wilms tumor monitoring. Factors such as the patient's previous medical history and presence of nephrogenic rests and nephroblastomatosis should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

326813</a>

3269]</p>

3270</li>

3271<li>

3272<strong>

3273Hemihypertrophy (also known as lateralized overgrowth or hemihyperplasia).</strong>

3274 Children with isolated hemihypertrophy are also at risk of developing liver tumors, adrenal tumors, and Wilms tumor (risk, 3%&#8211;4%). Screening with abdominal ultrasonography and serum AFP is suggested until age 4 years. After age 4 years, most hepatoblastomas will have occurred, and imaging may be limited to renal ultrasonography, which is quicker and does not require fasting before the exam.[<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

3275140</a>

3276] <p id="_2443" tabindex="-1">

3277 Hemihypertrophy can occur as part of a syndrome (most commonly Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) or an isolated phenomenon. The Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome International Consensus Group suggested that individuals with florid Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome phenotype and those with isolated hemihypertrophy who have similar molecular findings as those with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome should be considered part of the Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome spectrum and managed according to the subtype of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Molecular testing may be considered for patients with isolated hemihypertrophy based on the clinical scoring system proposed by the Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome International Consensus Group.[<a href="#cit/section_2.145">

3278145</a>

3279]</p>

3280<p id="_2444" tabindex="-1">

3281Children with isolated hemihypertrophy and negative molecular tests may not need surveillance because the risk may be very low. However, more studies of large cohorts of molecularly tested children with isolated hemihypertrophy are needed to determine the risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

328290</a>

3283,<a href="#cit/section_2.145">

3284145</a>

3285]</p>

3286</li>

3287<li>

3288<strong>

3289Sporadic aniridia.</strong>

3290 Newborns born with sporadic aniridia should undergo molecular testing for deletion analysis of <em class="gene-name">

3291PAX6</em>

3292 and <em class="gene-name">

3293WT1</em>

3294, which are consistent with WAGR syndrome. Approximately 30% of patients with sporadic aniridia have WAGR.[<a href="#cit/section_2.146">

3295146</a>

3296] If a deletion of <em class="gene-name">

3297WT1</em>

3298 is observed, the child should be screened with ultrasonography every 3 months until age 8 years, and the parents should be educated about the need for early identification and treatment of Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

329990</a>

3300,<a href="#cit/section_2.147">

3301147</a>

3302,<a href="#cit/section_2.148">

3303148</a>

3304]</li>

3305<li>

3306<strong>

3307Children of survivors of bilateral Wilms tumor.</strong>

3308 Although the risk of Wilms tumor in the children of survivors of bilateral Wilms tumor is unknown and likely varies with the gene in which the mutation occurred, some experts recommend screening such children with serial ultrasonography examinations every 3 months until age 8 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.75">

330975</a>

3310]</li>

3311<li>

3312<strong>

3313Bohring-Opitz syndrome.</strong>

3314 Bohring-Opitz syndrome is a rare genetic condition associated with <em class="gene-name">

3315ASXL1</em>

3316 mutations. Overall, about 7% of individuals with Bohring-Opitz syndrome develop Wilms tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

3317149</a>

3318] Screening with abdominal ultrasonography every 3 to 4 months in the first 8 years of life has been suggested.[<a href="#cit/section_2.46">

331946</a>

3320]</li>

3321<li>

3322<strong>

3323Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome.</strong>

3324 Affected males with Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome with <em class="gene-name">

3325GPC3</em>

3326 mutations or deletions have an approximate 10% risk of Wilms tumor. Regular age-dependent screening for tumors, including abdominal ultrasonography, urinalysis, and biochemical markers, has been recommended for males with Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome, although the true benefit has not been determined. It was previously thought that carrier females were not at increased risk of Wilms tumor and did not require surveillance. However, there are reports of rare cases where Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome may have a significant clinical expression in females and Wilms tumors have occurred.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

332790</a>

3328] In clearly affected females, screening should be considered for embryonic tumors, including Wilms tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.150">

3329150</a>

3330]</li>

3331<li>

3332<strong>

3333Klippel-Tr&#233;naunay syndrome.</strong>

3334 The risk of Wilms tumor in children with Klippel-Tr&#233;naunay syndrome (a unilateral limb overgrowth syndrome) was no different than the risk in the general population when assessed using the NWTS database. Routine ultrasonography surveillance is not recommended.[<a href="#cit/section_2.151">

3335151</a>

3336]</li>

3337<li>

3338<strong>

3339Perlman syndrome.</strong>

3340 Perlman syndrome is a rare congenital overgrowth syndrome that has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. A molecular diagnosis can be made by the presence of inactivating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

3341DIS3L2</em>

3342 on chromosome 2q37.1. Fifty-three percent of children will die in the neonatal period. The kidneys show nephroblastomatosis in about 75% of cases. The incidence of Wilms tumor is 64% in infants who survive beyond the neonatal period.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

334337</a>

3344] It is recommended that these patients be offered regular surveillance similar to that offered to patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

3345140</a>

3346]</li>

3347<li>

3348<strong>

3349DICER1 syndrome.</strong>

3350 Cystic nephroma is seen in 10% of families presenting with pleuropulmonary blastoma, typically occurring before age 4 years. Rare progression to anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney may occur. DICER1 syndrome includes an elevated risk of Wilms tumor, which is not a consequence of a prior cystic nephroma. Surveillance consists of abdominal ultrasonography, which starts with the first chest computed tomography (CT) screening for pleuropulmonary blastoma, and it is done every 6 to 12 months to age 8 years. Surveillance may be continued annually until age 12 years, depending on the individual patient.[<a href="#cit/section_2.152">

3351152</a>

3352] Thirteen years is the oldest reported age of a Wilms tumor diagnosis in a <em class="gene-name">

3353DICER1</em>

3354 mutation carrier.[<a href="#cit/section_2.115">

3355115</a>

3356,<a href="#cit/section_2.153">

3357153</a>

3358]</li>

3359<li>

3360<strong>

3361Germline pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant in Wilms tumor predisposition genes (<em class="gene-name">

3362CTR9</em>

3363, <em class="gene-name">

3364REST</em>

3365, <em class="gene-name">

3366TP53</em>

3367, <em class="gene-name">

3368TRIM28</em>

3369) in the absence of syndrome features or a family history suggestive of any specific cancer predisposition syndrome.</strong>

3370 Surveillance should be considered throughout the period of increased Wilms tumor risk (typically up to age 8 years), but may vary depending on the condition.[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

3371154</a>

3372]</li>

3373</ul>

3374</div>

3375<section id="_1099">

3376<h4 id="_1099_toc">

3377Genetic counseling</h4>

3378<p id="_2419" tabindex="-1">

3379Wilms tumor develops in association with an underlying germline predisposition in 10% to 15% of cases. A genetics referral is recommended for all children with Wilms tumor who have a positive family history of cancer, bilateral kidney involvement, or presence of syndrome-specific features.[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

3380154</a>

3381]</p>

3382<p id="_2420" tabindex="-1">

3383The McGill Interactive Pediatric OncoGenetic Guidelines (MIPOGG) study aims to develop an eHealth tool to assist physicians in identifying children at increased risk of having a cancer predisposition syndrome. Based on a thorough literature review, a decisional algorithm specific to Wilms tumor was developed. This algorithm consists of five tumor-specific criteria (age &lt;2 years, bilaterality/multifocality, stromal-predominant histology, nephrogenic rests, and overgrowth features) and universal criteria, including features of family history suspicious for a cancer predisposition syndrome and congenital anomalies. This tool was applied retrospectively to 180 consecutive pediatric patients with Wilms tumor, diagnosed and/or treated at The Hospital for Sick Children (1997&#8211;2016) who underwent targeted molecular diagnostic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_2.155">

3384155</a>

3385]</p>

3386<div class="pdq-content-list">

3387<ul id="_2421">

3388<li>

3389Application of the algorithm generated a binary recommendation for or against genetic referral for cancer predisposition syndrome evaluations. The algorithm identified 100% of children with Wilms tumor and a confirmed cancer predisposition syndrome (n = 27).</li>

3390<li>

3391Age younger than 2 years, bilaterality/multifocality, and congenital anomalies were strongly associated with pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

3392WT1</em>

3393.</li>

3394<li>

3395Presence of more than one overgrowth feature was strongly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.</li>

3396<li>

3397Stromal-predominant histology did not contribute to cancer predisposition syndrome recognition (and has been removed from the essential criteria). In combination with other suspicious features, stromal histology may increase the likelihood of identifying a <em class="gene-name">

3398WT1</em>

3399-related disorder. </li>

3400<li>

3401Plans are under way to test this tool prospectively in patients diagnosed with Wilms tumor who undergo comprehensive genomic sequencing of their germline DNA.</li>

3402</ul>

3403</div>

3404<p id="_2422" tabindex="-1">

3405If a child is found to harbor a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant in a Wilms tumor predisposition gene, then their parents and close relatives can also be offered testing. Affected individuals should be counseled about the risk of additional neoplasms and oncologic manifestations, as appropriate, as well as the risk to future offspring.[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

3406154</a>

3407]</p>

3408</section>

3409</section>

3410<section id="_898">

3411<h3 id="_898_toc">

3412Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</h3>

3413<p id="_904" tabindex="-1">

3414Most Wilms tumor patients present asymptomatically with an abdominal mass noticed by a parent or pediatrician on a well-child visit. In children with known predisposing clinical syndromes, renal tumors can be found during routine screening. Clinical findings may include the following:</p>

3415<div class="pdq-content-list">

3416<ul id="_905">

3417<li>

3418A lump, swelling, or pain in the abdomen. Most children present with a nontender, large flank mass that is noted when they are bathed or dressed. If noted on physical examination, the mass does not move with respiration in contrast to splenomegaly. Abdominal pain is present in 40% of children.</li>

3419<li>

3420Blood in the urine. Gross hematuria occurs in about 18% of children with Wilms tumor at presentation, and microscopic hematuria is seen in 24% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.156">

3421156</a>

3422]</li>

3423<li>

3424Hypertension. About 25% of children have hypertension at presentation, which is attributed to activation of the renin-angiotensin system.</li>

3425<li>

3426Hypercalcemia. Symptomatic hypercalcemia can sometimes be seen at presentation of rhabdoid tumors.</li>

3427<li>

3428Constitutional symptoms such as fever, anorexia, and weight loss occur in 10% of cases.</li>

3429</ul>

3430</div>

3431<p id="_936" tabindex="-1">

3432Children with Wilms tumor or other renal malignancies may also seek medical attention as a result of the following:</p>

3433<div class="pdq-content-list">

3434<ul id="_1068">

3435<li>

3436Vascular obstruction or metastasis, including pulmonary symptoms such as dyspnea caused by lung metastasis.</li>

3437<li>

3438Abdominal pain caused by liver metastasis, prominent abdominal wall vessels, or varicocele due to inferior vena cava obstruction.</li>

3439<li>

3440Pulmonary embolus (rare).</li>

3441<li>

3442Rapid abdominal enlargement, anemia, and severe pain may be seen in the few children who develop subcapsular hemorrhage.</li>

3443</ul>

3444</div>

3445</section>

3446<section id="_900">

3447<h3 id="_900_toc">

3448Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</h3>

3449<p id="_901" tabindex="-1">

3450Tests and procedures used to diagnose and stage Wilms tumor and other childhood kidney tumors include the following:</p>

3451<div class="pdq-content-list">

3452<ol id="_1004">

3453<li>

3454Physical examination and history. Children with a renal mass are carefully assessed for signs of associated syndromes such as aniridia, developmental delay, hypospadias, cryptorchidism, pseudohermaphrodism, overgrowth, and hemihypertrophy.</li>

3455<li>

3456Complete blood

3457 count.</li>

3458<li>

3459Liver function test.</li>

3460<li>

3461Renal function test.</li>

3462<li>

3463Urinalysis.</li>

3464<li>

3465Abdominal imaging.<div class="pdq-content-list">

3466<ul id="_966">

3467<li>

3468Abdominal x-ray.</li>

3469<li>

3470Ultrasonography exam of the abdomen. Ultrasonography exam of the abdomen is often performed before a more definitive CT scan with contrast or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast of the abdomen. This procedure is unnecessary after the definitive diagnostic study has been performed. </li>

3471<li>

3472CT scan with contrast or MRI of abdomen.[<a href="#cit/section_2.157">

3473157</a>

3474]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3475<ul id="_1232" class="list-dash">

3476<li>

3477CT scan of the abdomen will confirm the renal origin of the mass and determine whether there are bilateral tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.158">

3478158</a>

3479] About 5% of renal masses thought to be Wilms tumor on the basis of clinical and radiological findings are diagnosed as another condition.[<a href="#cit/section_2.159">

3480159</a>

3481] </li>

3482<li>

3483A review of children with bilateral Wilms tumor demonstrated that only 0.25% of bilateral tumors were missed with modern helical CT scans, all of which were small tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.160">

3484160</a>

3485]</li>

3486<li>

3487Preoperative assessment by imaging of intravascular extension of Wilms tumor is essential to guide management. Four percent of Wilms tumor patients present with inferior vena cava or atrial involvement and 11% with renal vein involvement, which may lead to differences in management. Embolization of a caval thrombus to the pulmonary artery is rare but can be lethal, and the presence of a thrombus must be identified preoperatively to prevent this occurrence and guide treatment. A report from the COG shows that CT can accurately identify cavoatrial thrombus, obviating the need for ultrasonography if CT has already been performed.[<a href="#cit/section_2.161">

3488161</a>

3489]</li>

3490<li>

3491Ascites beyond the cul-de-sac is most predictive of preoperative Wilms tumor rupture, regardless of attenuation. In the presence of ascites, fat stranding around the tumor and the presence of retroperitoneal fluid are highly predictive of rupture.[<a href="#cit/section_2.158">

3492158</a>

3493]</li>

3494<li>

3495The concern about CT is radiation exposure, but the procedure is quick, allows continuous imaging of the chest and abdomen, has moderate specificity for detection of preoperative spill, may help distinguish nephrogenic rests from Wilms tumor, and provides excellent pulmonary detail.[<a href="#cit/section_2.158">

3496158</a>

3497,<a href="#cit/section_2.162">

3498162</a>

3499]</li>

3500<li>

3501The main drawback with abdominal MRI is that moderate to deep sedation is often required in young children. However, it provides excellent organ detail in patients with bilateral involvement or liver metastases. Abdominal MRI is preferred for better assessment of potential nephrogenic rests and their distinction from true Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.163">

3502163</a>

3503] If the decision is to perform an abdominal MRI, then a CT scan of the lungs should be done first to avoid obscuration of the lung bases by atelectasis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.164">

3504164</a>

3505] MRI is the preferred imaging modality in children with known bilateral Wilms tumors or known bilateral tumor predisposition.[<a href="#cit/section_2.164">

3506164</a>

3507]</li>

3508</ul>

3509</div>

3510</li>

3511</ul>

3512</div>

3513</li>

3514<li>

3515CT scan of chest. Approximately 15% to 20% of patients will present with metastases. The common sites of metastases for Wilms tumor are the lungs (85%), liver (10%), and bone and spine (rarely). CT scanning provides the most sensitive method of detecting metastatic lung nodules. Approximately 7.5% of patients may present with a pleural effusion.[<a href="#cit/section_2.165">

3516165</a>

3517][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3518Level of evidence C1</a>

3519]</li>

3520<li>

3521Chest x-ray is unnecessary if chest CT is performed initially.</li>

3522<li>

3523Fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) positron emission tomography (PET)-CT. PET scanning is not routinely used in Wilms tumor, although Wilms tumor is 18F-FDG avid. 18F-FDG PET-CT imaging adds clinically applicable information to conventional CT scan imaging. PET-CT may be particularly helpful in patients with bilateral disease or those receiving preoperative chemotherapy. 18F-FDG PET-CT highlights FDG-avid areas in the tumor and metastases, which corresponds to histologically confirmed active disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.166">

3524166</a>

3525]</li>

3526<li>

3527Bone scan or cross-sectional imaging of other sites is reserved for patients with signs or symptoms of distant extrapulmonary metastases.</li>

3528<li>

3529von Willebrand disease work-up. About 4% of patients presenting with Wilms tumor have an acquired form of von Willebrand disease, although many are asymptomatic. von Willebrand multimers bind to Wilms tumor, reducing the plasma concentration to low levels.[<a href="#cit/section_2.167">

3530167</a>

3531] Some clinicians recommend evaluation for von Willebrand disease before surgery, because, although uncommon, it may be associated with substantial bleeding risks and can be managed preemptively. Acquired von Willebrand disease in the context of Wilms tumor will usually resolve once chemotherapy is started or the tumor is resected.[<a href="#cit/section_2.168">

3532168</a>

3533] </li>

3534<li>

3535Biopsy or resection. In children with a renal mass that clinically appears to be resectable or stage I or stage II Wilms tumor, a biopsy is not performed so that tumor cells are not spread during the biopsy. A biopsy would upstage such a patient to stage III. Nephrectomy (in North America) or chemotherapy (in Europe) is performed instead. Therefore, the diagnostic pathology is first seen when the nephrectomy specimen is examined.<p id="_1967" tabindex="-1">

3536Biopsy of a renal mass may be indicated if the mass is atypical by radiographic appearance for Wilms tumor, and the patient is not going to undergo immediate nephrectomy. If a primary nephrectomy cannot be performed, a biopsy, either open or with multiple cores, is required. The contraindications to primary nephrectomy are the following: </p>

3537<div class="pdq-content-list">

3538<ul id="_1928">

3539<li>

3540Extension of tumor thrombus to the level of the hepatic veins. These patients should be considered for tumor resection after neoadjuvant chemotherapy when there is evidence of regression of the vena caval thrombus regardless of the degree of response of the primary tumor.</li>

3541<li>

3542The tumor involves contiguous structures whereby the only means of removing the kidney tumor requires removal of the other structure (e.g., spleen, pancreas, colon but excluding the adrenal gland and diaphragm). While Wilms tumors are frequently adherent to adjacent organs, in most cases, there is not frank invasion by the tumor and it can be dissected freely from the organs. Radical en bloc resection (e.g., partial hepatectomy) is not generally warranted. If removal of a small section of diaphragm, psoas muscle, or tip of the pancreas allows the tumor to be removed intact, this is considered safe and appropriate.</li>

3543<li>

3544The surgeon's judgment that nephrectomy would result in significant or unnecessary morbidity/mortality, significant tumor spill, or residual tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.169">

3545169</a>

3546]</li>

3547<li>

3548If there is pulmonary compromise because of extensive pulmonary metastases or, in rare cases, hepatic disease.</li>

3549</ul>

3550</div>

3551<p id="_1930" tabindex="-1">

3552If a child undergoes a biopsy as the first procedure, they are considered stage III because they have gross residual tumors.</p>

3553<p id="_1929" tabindex="-1">

3554Biopsy tissue from inoperable Wilms tumor obtained before chemotherapy may be used for histological review and initial treatment decisions. However, the use of biopsy to determine histology in an inoperable tumor remains controversial because biopsy may cause local tumor spread and the histological classification of the Wilms tumor cannot be determined by biopsy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.169">

3555169</a>

3556]</p>

3557<p id="_1933" tabindex="-1">

3558Anaplastic histology can be difficult to detect in any biopsy sample because of tumor heterogeneity. Data from NWTS-4 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

3559NWTS-5 (COG-Q9401/NCT00002611)</a>

3560 demonstrated that, because of the histological heterogeneity of Wilms tumor, a significant number of patients have anaplastic histology that is missed during an up-front biopsy whether it be a core needle biopsy or an incisional biopsy [<a href="#cit/section_2.170">

3561170</a>

3562] but revealed at the time of definitive surgery after chemotherapy.</p>

3563<p id="_1005" tabindex="-1">

3564Detection of a contralateral renal lesion in a child with Wilms tumor can change the stage and initial management of the patient, indicating a role for a renal-sparing approach without up-front surgery. The detection of contralateral renal lesions is important at baseline imaging because routine intraoperative exploration of the contralateral kidney is no longer recommended on the basis of the results of the NWTS-4 study.[<a href="#cit/section_2.157">

3565157</a>

3566,<a href="#cit/section_2.160">

3567160</a>

3568] Treatment as a bilateral Wilms tumor should be considered if the initial imaging studies suggests a bilateral process. If the origin of the other lesion is indeterminate, a pathological assessment of that lesion should be considered before proceeding with a nephrectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.157">

3569157</a>

3570,<a href="#cit/section_2.160">

3571160</a>

3572]</p>

3573<p id="_1934" tabindex="-1">

3574Children who have bilateral Wilms tumor are often treated without a biopsy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

3575171</a>

3576] Biopsy can be avoided if the child is of typical age and the tumor has the usual radiographic appearance. This was assessed on the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00945009">

3577AREN0534 (NCT00945009)</a>

3578 study where 187 of 189 patients with Wilms tumor were treated initially without a biopsy. If after 6 weeks of therapy, response was less than 30% by RECIST1.1 criteria, bilateral biopsies were performed to assess for anaplasia, stromal differentiation, and rhabdomyomatous changes. If anaplasia was detected, the chemotherapy treatment was changed. If stromal differentiation or rhabdomyomatous changes were detected, further chemotherapy was unlikely to result in tumor shrinkage and definitive surgery was the suggested approach.[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

3579171</a>

3580]</p>

3581</li>

3582</ol>

3583</div>

3584<p id="_694" tabindex="-1">

3585For patients with suspected Wilms tumor, additional preoperative staging studies are performed to assess lymph node status, intravascular extension, and rupture of Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.159">

3586159</a>

3587] </p>

3588<div class="pdq-content-list">

3589<ul id="_1002">

3590<li>

3591Lymph node sampling is required to locally stage all Wilms tumor patients. Lymph nodes have been shown to be of major prognostic value for both short-term and long-term survival. Gross inspection is notoriously inaccurate, with a false-negative rate of 31.3% and a false-positive rate of 18.1%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.172">

3592172</a>

3593]</li>

3594<li>

3595Intravascular extension of the Wilms tumor. Preoperative assessment of intravascular extension of Wilms tumor is essential to guide management. The presence of intravenous tumor thrombus in the lumen of the renal vein, inferior vena cava, and right atrium has been reported in up to 11.3% of Wilms tumor patients and may lead to differences in management. <p id="_1007" tabindex="-1">

3596In North America, local staging of Wilms tumor is performed with CT or MRI of the abdomen and pelvis. Contrast-enhanced CT for Wilms tumor patients has high sensitivity and specificity for detection of cavoatrial tumor thrombus that may impact surgical approach. Routine Doppler evaluation may be done after CT has been performed but is not necessarily required.[<a href="#cit/section_2.161">

3597161</a>

3598] If the tumor is at or above the hepatic veins, a biopsy with preoperative chemotherapy is suggested because of the lower rate of serious intraoperative complications. Before surgical approach to the renal mass is performed, large tumor thrombi need to be controlled, especially when they extend above the hepatic vein, to avoid embolization of the tumor. In some cases, cardiopulmonary bypass is required.[<a href="#cit/section_2.173">

3599173</a>

3600]</p>

3601</li>

3602<li>

3603Wilms tumors can rupture before surgery. The term rupture is used to imply a break in the tumor capsule before surgery, whereas the term spill refers to a break in the tumor during surgery. Based on their similar diagnostic performances, either CT or MRI can be used to detect rupture. Although imaging findings of rupture have high specificity (88%), the diagnosis of rupture has to be confirmed at surgery. Imaging alone cannot be used for initial staging because of the low sensitivity and specificity for preoperative rupture and lymph node status.[<a href="#cit/section_2.164">

3604164</a>

3605]</li>

3606</ul>

3607</div>

3608</section>

3609<section id="_551">

3610<h3 id="_551_toc">

3611Prognosis and Prognostic Factors for Wilms Tumor</h3>

3612<p id="_552" tabindex="-1">

3613Wilms tumor is a curable disease in most affected children.

3614Since the 1980s, the 5-year survival rate for Wilms tumor with favorable histology (FH) has been consistently greater than 90%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.174">

3615174</a>

3616] This favorable outcome occurred with changes in therapy that included reductions in the length of therapy, dose of radiation, extent of fields irradiated, and the percentage of patients receiving radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.175">

3617175</a>

3618]</p>

3619<p id="_725" tabindex="-1">

3620The prognosis for patients with Wilms tumor depends on the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.176">

3621176</a>

3622-<a href="#cit/section_2.179">

3623179</a>

3624]</p>

3625<div class="pdq-content-list">

3626<ul id="_726">

3627<li>

3628Histopathological features of the tumor (<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_587">

3629FH</a>

3630 vs. <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_589">

3631anaplastic histology</a>

3632). For more information, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_11">

3633Histological Findings in Wilms Tumor</a>

3634 section.</li>

3635<li>

3636Stage of disease at diagnosis.</li>

3637<li>

3638Molecular features of the tumor such as 1q gain and loss of heterozygosity of 1p and 16q. 1q gain, affecting 28% of Wilms tumors, is the most powerful predictor of outcome and is associated with an adverse outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

3639105</a>

3640,<a href="#cit/section_2.106">

3641106</a>

3642,<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

3643108</a>

3644] Loss of heterozygosity of 11p15 and loss of imprinting of 11p15 is associated with relapse in very low-risk patients who do not receive chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

3645108</a>

3646,<a href="#cit/section_2.180">

3647180</a>

3648] For more information, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1203">

3649Genomics of Wilms Tumor</a>

3650 section.</li>

3651<li>

3652Age. Age at presentation is commonly between 2 and 5 years, and the incidence of Wilms tumor in children older than age 10 years is rare. Older age is associated with an adverse prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.181">

3653181</a>

3654]</li>

3655</ul>

3656</div>

3657</section>

3658<section id="_968">

3659<h3 id="_968_toc">

3660Older Adolescents and Adults With Wilms Tumor</h3>

3661<p id="_1900" tabindex="-1">

3662Wilms tumor in patients older than 16 years is rare, with an incidence rate of around 0.2 cases per 1 million per year in patients aged 15 to 39 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

36632</a>

3664] The 5-year relative survival rate is 75% for this group of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

36652</a>

3666] In Europe, the median age at diagnosis for adult patients with Wilms tumor (defined as age &gt;15 years) is 34 years. However, patients older than 60 years have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_2.182">

3667182</a>

3668] Three percent of Wilms tumors occur in adults. Wilms tumor represents less than 1% of all renal tumors in adults and may be an unexpected finding after nephrectomy for presumed renal cell carcinoma, which is the most common adult renal cancer.</p>

3669<p id="_2446" tabindex="-1">

3670Wilms tumor occurring in adults differs from that occurring in children in several ways. Adults rarely present with bilateral disease (&lt;1%). More adult patients had additional primary malignancies (both before and after the diagnosis of Wilms tumor) compared with their pediatric counterparts.[<a href="#cit/section_2.183">

3671183</a>

3672] Wilms tumors occurring in adults have not been shown to develop in association with nephrogenic rests or be associated with developmental conditions such as WAGR, Denys-Drash, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndromes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3673133</a>

3674] For information about the molecular features of Wilms tumor in adults, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1203">

3675Genomics of Wilms Tumor</a>

3676 section.</p>

3677<p id="_2423" tabindex="-1">

3678A situation that is specific to adults is the diagnosis of Wilms tumor in pregnant women. This diagnosis is made incidentally during the ultrasonography monitoring of the pregnancy or because of clinical symptoms such as abdominal pain and fever.[<a href="#cit/section_2.184">

3679184</a>

3680,<a href="#cit/section_2.185">

3681185</a>

3682]</p>

3683<p id="_941" tabindex="-1">

3684The outcomes for adolescent and young adult (AYA) patients (aged 15 to 39 years) and adult patients are inferior to the outcomes for children.</p>

3685<div class="pdq-content-list">

3686<ul id="_1958">

3687<li>

3688 In an analysis of patients with Wilms tumor in the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database, AYA patients (n = 104) had a statistically worse 5-year OS rate (69% vs. 94%; <em>

3689P</em>

3690 &lt; .001) than did pediatric patients (n = 2,574).[<a href="#cit/section_2.186">

3691186</a>

3692][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3693Level of evidence C1</a>

3694]</li>

3695</ul>

3696</div>

3697<p id="_1959" tabindex="-1">

3698The inferior outcome of the adult patients may be multifactorial, including differences in tumor biology between children and adults, incorrect diagnosis, inadequate staging (e.g., more likely to be staged as localized disease or to not receive lymph node sampling), undertreatment/poor compliance (e.g., not receiving radiation therapy), unfamiliarity of medical oncologists and pathologists with Wilms tumors in adults (possibly leading to diagnostic error and delay), delays in initiating the appropriate risk-adapted therapy, and lack of specific treatment protocols for adults.[<a href="#cit/section_2.187">

3699187</a>

3700][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3701Level of evidence C1</a>

3702]</p>

3703<section id="_1961">

3704<h4 id="_1961_toc">

3705Treatment of adults with Wilms tumor</h4>

3706<p id="_1962" tabindex="-1">

3707As Wilms tumor rarely occurs in adults, there is no standard treatment protocol. Better results have been reported for adults when they are treated in pediatric trials. </p>

3708<p id="_2424" tabindex="-1">

3709A Wilms tumor in an adult represents a therapeutic emergency because of the tumor's rapid growth and because urologists and oncologists are more familiar with the indolent growth of renal cell carcinoma.</p>

3710<p id="_2016" tabindex="-1">

3711The National Wilms Tumor Study (NWTS) Group reported the outcomes for adult patients with Wilms tumor from the NWTS-1, -2, and -3 trials.[<a href="#cit/section_2.188">

3712188</a>

3713-<a href="#cit/section_2.190">

3714190</a>

3715] </p>

3716<div class="pdq-content-list">

3717<ul id="_2017">

3718<li>

3719The 3-year OS rate for adults on the NWTS-1 trial was 24% (compared with 74% in children) and improved to a 5-year OS rate of 82.6% on the NWTS-3 trial, although the number of adult patients treated on each trial was 31 or fewer.</li>

3720<li>

3721These data suggest that many adults with Wilms tumor, if treated appropriately, can expect to be cured, especially if the tumor has not spread and/or is completely resected.</li>

3722</ul>

3723</div>

3724<p id="_1963" tabindex="-1">

3725For adults with refractory or recurrent disease, screening for potential therapeutic targets in the tumor should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_2.191">

3726191</a>

3727]</p>

3728<p id="_1901" tabindex="-1">

3729The following recommendations from the renal tumor committees of the International Society of Paediatric Oncology (SIOP) and COG encourage a uniform approach to improve outcome for adults with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.192">

3730192</a>

3731]</p>

3732<div class="pdq-content-list">

3733<ul id="_1902">

3734<li>

3735Consult with a pediatric oncologist who has experience with the treatment of Wilms tumor as soon as a histological diagnosis is suspected.</li>

3736<li>

3737Avoid delaying the start of chemotherapy. Ideally, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy if necessary, should be started by day 14 postnephrectomy, although delaying the start until day 30 is acceptable.</li>

3738<li>

3739Be alert for toxicity of vincristine (neurotoxicity) and dactinomycin (hepatic toxicity) in adults.</li>

3740<li>

3741Register patients in pediatric renal tumor trials if studies are available and the patients are eligible.</li>

3742</ul>

3743</div>

3744<p id="_2447" tabindex="-1">

3745In a series of 14 adult Wilms tumors that were evaluated by expanded targeted sequencing, 5 (36%) demonstrated <em class="gene-name">

3746BRAF</em>

3747 V600E mutations. These tumors contained areas that were morphologically identical to <em class="gene-name">

3748BRAF</em>

3749 V600E&#8211;mutated metanephric adenoma. All of the <em class="gene-name">

3750BRAF</em>

3751 V600E&#8211;mutated Wilms tumors in this cohort occurred in patients older than 30 years. Identifying a <em class="gene-name">

3752BRAF</em>

3753 V600E mutation has therapeutic significance because these patients may respond to therapy with BRAF/MEK inhibitors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3754133</a>

3755] There was one report of a male (aged 51 years) who had a relapsed metastatic Wilms tumor that harbored a <em class="gene-name">

3756BRAF</em>

3757 V600E mutation. The patient was treated with the BRAF inhibitor dabrafenib, and they had a prolonged and dramatic response.[<a href="#cit/section_2.191">

3758191</a>

3759]</p>

3760</section>

3761</section>

3762<section id="_11">

3763<h3 id="_11_toc">

3764Histological Findings in Wilms Tumor</h3>

3765<p id="_12" tabindex="-1">

3766Although most patients with a histological diagnosis of Wilms tumor do well

3767with current treatment, approximately 10% of patients have histopathological

3768features that are associated with a worse prognosis, and in some types, with

3769a high incidence of relapse and death. Wilms tumor can be separated into the following two

3770prognostic groups on the basis of tumor and kidney histopathology:</p>

3771<div class="pdq-content-list">

3772<ul id="_734">

3773<li>

3774<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_587">

3775Favorable histology (FH)</a>

3776.</li>

3777<li>

3778<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_589">

3779Anaplastic histology</a>

3780.</li>

3781</ul>

3782</div>

3783<section id="_587">

3784<h4 id="_587_toc">

3785Favorable histology (FH)</h4>

3786<p id="_588" tabindex="-1">

3787Histologically, Wilms tumor mimics the triphasic development of a normal kidney

3788consisting of blastemal, epithelial (tubules), and stromal cell types. Not all tumors are triphasic, and monophasic patterns may present diagnostic difficulties. </p>

3789<p id="_1017" tabindex="-1">

3790While associations between histological features and prognosis or responsiveness to therapy have been suggested, with the exception of anaplasia, none of these features have reached statistical significance in North American treatment algorithms. Therefore, histological features do not direct the initial therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.193">

3791193</a>

3792] A strong association between the epithelial subtype and <em class="gene-name">

3793TRIM28</em>

3794 mutations has been identified.[<a href="#cit/section_2.123">

3795123</a>

3796][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3797Level of evidence C1</a>

3798]</p>

3799<p id="_2425" tabindex="-1">

3800In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00898365">

3801AREN03B2 (NCT00898365)</a>

3802 study, patients with stage I disease were analyzed on the basis of epithelial histology (n = 177) and treatment. When analyzed by epithelial histology, the 4-year EFS rate was 96%, and the OS rate was 100%. When these patients were analyzed according to treatment, patients treated with vincristine and dactinomycin (regimen EE-4A) (n = 117) had a 4-year EFS rate of 96%, compared with a 4-year EFS rate of 98% for patients who underwent nephrectomy only (n = 57) (<em>

3803P</em>

3804 = .549).[<a href="#cit/section_2.194">

3805194</a>

3806]</p>

3807<p id="_2448" tabindex="-1">

3808In a series of 14 adults (aged 17&#8211;46 years) with Wilms tumors, targeted tumor sequencing revealed <em class="gene-name">

3809BRAF</em>

3810 V600E mutations in 5 of the tumors. All of these tumors had better-differentiated areas that were identical to metanephric adenoma, in combination with epithelial Wilms tumor. Adults who have tumors with this histological manifestation may benefit from sequencing of their tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

3811133</a>

3812]</p>

3813</section>

3814<section id="_589">

3815<h4 id="_589_toc">

3816Anaplastic histology</h4>

3817<p id="_590" tabindex="-1">

3818Anaplastic histology accounts for about 10% of Wilms tumor cases. Anaplastic histology is the single most important histological predictor of response and survival in patients with Wilms tumor. Tumors occurring in older patients (aged 10&#8211;16 years) have a higher incidence of anaplastic histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.195">

3819195</a>

3820] In bilateral tumors, 12% to 14% have been reported to have anaplastic histology in one kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_2.196">

3821196</a>

3822,<a href="#cit/section_2.197">

3823197</a>

3824] </p>

3825<p id="_1018" tabindex="-1">

3826The following two histological criteria must be present to confirm the diagnosis of anaplasia: </p>

3827<div class="pdq-content-list">

3828<ul id="_735">

3829<li>

3830Presence of multipolar polyploid mitotic figures with marked nuclear enlargement.</li>

3831<li>

3832Hyperchromasia. </li>

3833</ul>

3834</div>

3835<p id="_736" tabindex="-1">

3836Changes on 17p consistent with mutations in the <em class="gene-name">

3837TP53</em>

3838 gene have been associated with foci of anaplastic histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.118">

3839118</a>

3840] Focal anaplasia is defined as the presence of one or more sharply localized regions of anaplasia in a primary tumor. All of these factors lend support to the hypothesis that anaplasia evolves as a late event from a subpopulation of Wilms tumor cells that have acquired additional genomic lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.198">

3841198</a>

3842] Focal anaplasia does not confer as poor a prognosis as does diffuse anaplasia.[<a href="#cit/section_2.178">

3843178</a>

3844,<a href="#cit/section_2.199">

3845199</a>

3846,<a href="#cit/section_2.200">

3847200</a>

3848]</p>

3849<p id="_737" tabindex="-1">

3850Anaplasia correlates best with responsiveness to therapy rather than to tumor aggressiveness. It is most consistently associated with poor prognosis when it is diffusely distributed and when

3851identified at advanced stages. These tumors are more resistant to the chemotherapy traditionally used in children with FH Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.178">

3852178</a>

3853] </p>

3854</section>

3855<section id="_2426">

3856<h4 id="_2426_toc">

3857Germline <em class="gene-name">

3858TRIM28</em>

3859 testing</h4>

3860<p id="_2427" tabindex="-1">

3861To identify patients with germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

3862TRIM28</em>

3863, routine assessment of Wilms tumors by immunohistochemistry with the anti-KAP1 antibody should be performed to look for TRIM28 loss. Even though most <em class="gene-name">

3864TRIM28</em>

3865-mutated tumors are epithelial (predominant) Wilms tumors, testing should be considered for all subtypes, because other histological subtypes have been reported to have the <em class="gene-name">

3866TRIM28</em>

3867 variant. Subsequently, genetic analysis of <em class="gene-name">

3868TRIM28</em>

3869 in blood-derived DNA can be performed in all patients who display loss of TRIM28 in the tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.126">

3870126</a>

3871]</p>

3872</section>

3873<section id="_591">

3874<h4 id="_591_toc">

3875Nephrogenic rests</h4>

3876<p id="_592" tabindex="-1">

3877Nephrogenic rests are abnormally retained (past 36 weeks) embryonic kidney precursor cells arranged in clusters. Nephrogenic rests are found in about 1% of unselected pediatric autopsies, 35% of kidneys with unilateral Wilms tumor, and nearly 100% of kidneys with bilateral Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.82">

387882</a>

3879,<a href="#cit/section_2.201">

3880201</a>

3881]

3882 Preoperative chemotherapy does not appear to affect the overall prevalence of nephrogenic rests. Congenital anomalies have been reported in 12% of patients with nephrogenic rests, including in 9% of patients with unilateral Wilms tumor and in 33% of patients with bilateral disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

38838</a>

3884]</p>

3885<p id="_1019" tabindex="-1">

3886The term nephroblastomatosis is defined as the presence of diffuse or multifocal nephrogenic rests. In unilateral Wilms tumors, nephrogenic rests are usually only detectable by histology, whereas in bilateral Wilms tumor, the proliferating nephrogenic rests may be large enough to be seen on imaging.[<a href="#cit/section_2.202">

3887202</a>

3888] Nephrogenic rests can be subclassified according to the anatomical location of the rest (intralobar or perilobar nephrogenic rests) and their growth phase (incipient or dormant nephrogenic rests, hyperplastic nephrogenic rests, and regressing or sclerosing nephrogenic rests). The underlying genetic defects have an impact on the presence of nephrogenic rests.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

38898</a>

3890] <em class="gene-name">

3891WT1</em>

3892-related Wilms tumors will frequently have few intralobar nephrogenic rests located centrally, with or adjacent to the renal medulla. <em class="gene-name">

3893TRIM28</em>

3894-associated or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome&#8211;associated Wilms tumors tend to harbor perilobar nephrogenic rests in the adjacent kidney tissue. Although only a few nephrogenic rests have been assayed, nephrogenic rests seem to carry even fewer mutations than their adjacent Wilms tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.203">

3895203</a>

3896,<a href="#cit/section_2.204">

3897204</a>

3898] </p>

3899<p id="_2428" tabindex="-1">

3900Distinguishing between nephrogenic rests and Wilms tumors by imaging is challenging because there is an overlap in their appearance. A retrospective study evaluated 52 young children (aged &lt;5 years) with nephrogenic rests and small Wilms tumors (all lesions &lt;5 cm) that had been surgically sampled and pathologically evaluated before any medical intervention. The investigators found that a Wilms tumor diagnosis should be favored over a nephrogenic rest diagnosis when a renal mass is spherical, exophytic, and larger than 1.75 cm in maximal diameter. Homogeneity by imaging favors the diagnosis of perilobar nephrogenic rests, whereas intralobar rests and Wilms tumors are more likely to be inhomogeneous.[<a href="#cit/section_2.162">

3901162</a>

3902][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3903Level of evidence C1</a>

3904] </p>

3905<p id="_2019" tabindex="-1">

3906Diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis represents one unique category of nephroblastomatosis that forms a thick rind around one or both kidneys and is considered a preneoplastic condition. Distinguishing between Wilms tumor and diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephrogenic rests may be a challenge, and it is critical to examine the juncture between the lesion and the surrounding renal parenchyma. Incisional biopsies are of no diagnostic value unless they include the margin between the lesion and the normal renal parenchyma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.205">

3907205</a>

3908]</p>

3909<p id="_1020" tabindex="-1">

3910The type and percentage of nephrogenic rests vary in patients with unilateral or bilateral disease. Patients with bilateral Wilms tumor have a higher proportion of perilobar rests (52%)

3911than of intralobar or combined rests (32%) and higher relative proportions of rests, compared with patients with unilateral tumors (18% perilobar and 20% intralobar or both).[<a href="#cit/section_2.206">

3912206</a>

3913] Intralobar nephrogenic rests have been associated with stromal-type Wilms tumor and younger age at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

39148</a>

3915]</p>

3916<p id="_1000" tabindex="-1">

3917Patients with any type of nephrogenic rest in a kidney removed for nephroblastoma are considered at increased risk of tumor formation in the remaining kidney. This risk decreases with patient age.[<a href="#cit/section_2.207">

3918207</a>

3919]</p>

3920<p id="_2429" tabindex="-1">

3921For information about the treatment of bilateral diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_436">

3922Nephroblastomatosis</a>

3923 section.</p>

3924<p id="_738" tabindex="-1">

3925Extrarenal nephrogenic rests are rare and may develop into extrarenal Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.208">

3926208</a>

3927]</p>

3928</section>

3929</section>

3930<section id="_23">

3931<h3 id="_23_toc">

3932Stage Information for Wilms Tumor</h3>

3933<p id="_24" tabindex="-1">

3934 Both the results of the imaging studies and the surgical and pathological findings at nephrectomy are used to determine the stage of disease. The stage is the same for tumors with FH or anaplastic histology. Thus, the stage

3935information is characterized by a statement of both criteria (for example, stage II,

3936FH or stage II, anaplastic histology).[<a href="#cit/section_2.193">

3937193</a>

3938,<a href="#cit/section_2.209">

3939209</a>

3940]</p>

3941<p id="_25" tabindex="-1">

3942 The staging system was originally developed by the NWTS Group and is still used by the COG. The staging system used in North America and incidence by stage are outlined below.[<a href="#cit/section_2.193">

3943193</a>

3944] Lymph node sampling is strongly recommended for all patients, even in the absence of clinically abnormal nodes, to achieve the most accurate stage.</p>

3945<section id="_26">

3946<h4 id="_26_toc">

3947Stage I </h4>

3948<p id="_160" tabindex="-1">

3949In stage I Wilms tumor (43% of patients), all of the following criteria must be met: </p>

3950<div class="pdq-content-list">

3951<ul id="_161">

3952<li>

3953Tumor is limited to the kidney and is completely resected.</li>

3954<li>

3955The renal capsule is intact.</li>

3956<li>

3957The tumor is not ruptured or biopsied before being removed.</li>

3958<li>

3959No involvement of renal sinus vessels.</li>

3960<li>

3961No evidence of the tumor at or beyond the margins of resection. </li>

3962<li>

3963All lymph nodes sampled are negative.</li>

3964</ul>

3965</div>

3966<p id="_1233" tabindex="-1">

3967For a tumor to qualify for certain therapeutic protocols such as very low-risk stage I, regional lymph nodes must be examined microscopically. </p>

3968</section>

3969<section id="_28">

3970<h4 id="_28_toc">

3971Stage II </h4>

3972<p id="_162" tabindex="-1">

3973 In stage II Wilms tumor (20% of patients), the tumor is completely resected, and there is no evidence of tumor at or beyond the margins of resection. The tumor extends beyond the kidney as evidenced by any one of the following criteria: </p>

3974<div class="pdq-content-list">

3975<ul id="_165">

3976<li>

3977There is regional extension of the tumor (i.e., penetration of the renal capsule, or extensive invasion of the soft tissue of the renal sinus, as discussed below).</li>

3978<li>

3979Blood vessels in the nephrectomy specimen outside the renal parenchyma, including those of the renal sinus, contain tumor cells. Margins are clear.</li>

3980<li>

3981Vascular extension of tumor is considered stage II only if it is completely removed en bloc in the nephrectomy specimen.</li>

3982</ul>

3983</div>

3984<p id="_1143" tabindex="-1">

3985All lymph nodes sampled are negative.</p>

3986<p id="_1234" tabindex="-1">

3987Rupture or spillage confined to the flank, including biopsy of the tumor, is now included in stage III by the COG Renal Tumor Committee (COG RTC); however, data to support this approach are controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_2.169">

3988169</a>

3989,<a href="#cit/section_2.210">

3990210</a>

3991]</p>

3992</section>

3993<section id="_33">

3994<h4 id="_33_toc">

3995Stage III </h4>

3996<p id="_166" tabindex="-1">

3997In stage III Wilms tumor (21% of patients), there is postsurgical residual nonhematogenous tumor that is confined to the abdomen. Any one of the following may occur: </p>

3998<div class="pdq-content-list">

3999<ul id="_167">

4000<li>

4001Lymph nodes in the abdomen or pelvis are involved by tumor. (Lymph node involvement in the thorax or other extra-abdominal sites is a criterion for stage IV.)</li>

4002<li>

4003The tumor has penetrated through the peritoneal surface. </li>

4004<li>

4005Tumor implants are found on the peritoneal surface. </li>

4006<li>

4007Gross or microscopic tumor remains postoperatively (e.g., tumor cells are found at the margin of surgical resection on microscopic examination). </li>

4008<li>

4009The tumor is not completely resectable because of local infiltration into vital structures.</li>

4010<li>

4011Tumor rupture before surgery or any spill during surgery is considered stage III.</li>

4012<li>

4013Biopsy is performed, regardless of type&#8212;Tru-cut biopsy, open biopsy, or fine-needle aspiration&#8212;before the tumor is removed.</li>

4014<li>
