4015The tumor is removed in more than one piece (e.g., tumor cells are found in a separately excised adrenal gland; a tumor thrombus in the renal vein is removed separately from the nephrectomy specimen). Extension of the primary tumor in the vena cava into the thoracic vena cava and heart is considered stage III, rather than stage IV, even though outside the abdomen&#8212;and it can even be stage II if completely resected en bloc with the nephrectomy specimen.</li>

4016</ul>

4017</div>

4018<p id="_923" tabindex="-1">

4019Lymph node involvement and microscopic residual disease are reported as highly predictive of outcome in patients with stage III FH Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.211">

4020211</a>

4021]</p>

4022</section>

4023<section id="_40">

4024<h4 id="_40_toc">

4025Stage IV </h4>

4026<p id="_41" tabindex="-1">

4027 In stage IV Wilms tumor (11% of patients), one of the following is present:</p>

4028<div class="pdq-content-list">

4029<ul id="_1275">

4030<li>

4031Hematogenous metastases (lung, liver, bone, brain).</li>

4032<li>

4033Lymph node metastases outside the abdominopelvic region. </li>

4034</ul>

4035</div>

4036<p id="_1276" tabindex="-1">

4037The presence of tumor within the adrenal gland is not interpreted as metastasis and staging depends on all other staging parameters present. According to the criteria described above, the primary tumor is assigned a local stage, which determines local therapy. For example, a patient may have stage IV, local stage III disease.</p>

4038</section>

4039<section id="_42">

4040<h4 id="_42_toc">

4041Stage V (bilateral)</h4>

4042<p id="_43" tabindex="-1">

4043 In stage V Wilms tumor (5% of patients), bilateral involvement by tumor is present at diagnosis. The current paradigm treats all patients with bilateral Wilms tumor the same for the first 6 or 12 weeks. After definitive surgery, the treatment is based on the highest stage of the remaining kidneys and the posttreatment pathology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

4044171</a>

4045]</p>

4046</section>

4047</section>

4048<section id="_386">

4049<h3 id="_386_toc">

4050Treatment of Wilms Tumor</h3>

4051<section id="_48">

4052<h4 id="_48_toc">

4053Treatment option overview for Wilms tumor</h4>

4054<p id="_49" tabindex="-1">

4055Because of the relative rarity of Wilms tumor, all patients with this tumor

4056should be considered for entry into a clinical trial. Treatment planning by a

4057multidisciplinary team of cancer specialists (pediatric surgeon and/or pediatric

4058urologist, pediatric radiation oncologist, and pediatric oncologist) who have

4059experience treating children with Wilms tumor is necessary to determine and implement optimal

4060treatment.

4061</p>

4062<section id="_1996">

4063<h5 id="_1996_toc">

4064COG and SIOP approaches to Wilms tumor treatment</h5>

4065<p id="_50" tabindex="-1">

4066Most randomized clinical studies for treatment of children with Wilms tumor have been conducted by two large clinical groups (COG RTC and SIOP). Differences between the two groups affect staging and classification. There are two standard approaches to Wilms tumor treatment: the COG RTC uses immediate surgery for all unilateral tumors and the SIOP uses preoperative chemotherapy as the first step in treatment. Both groups use postoperative chemotherapy, except for selected cases who do not receive chemotherapy, and in advanced stages, radiation therapy is used in a risk-adapted approach. </p>

4067<div class="pdq-content-list">

4068<ul id="_790">

4069<li>

4070<strong>

4071COG RTC (includes the previous NWTS group):</strong>

4072 The NWTS group established standard treatment for Wilms tumor in

4073North America, consisting of initial nephrectomy (when feasible) followed by chemotherapy and, in some

4074patients, radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.212">

4075212</a>

4076-<a href="#cit/section_2.214">

4077214</a>

4078] This approach allows for early and accurate histological diagnosis, collection of biological materials unaltered by therapy, and staging information, such as the presence of tumor spill or tumor involvement in lymph nodes, before chemotherapy is administered.</li>

4079<li>

4080<strong>

4081SIOP:</strong>

4082 SIOP is a European consortium whose trials provide preoperative chemotherapy before definitive resection for patients with renal tumors. This results in fewer tumor spills during surgery and lower postoperative stage.[<a href="#cit/section_2.215">

4083215</a>

4084] When the histological features of Wilms tumors from patients who underwent immediate surgery were compared with the histological features of patients who received preoperative chemotherapy, preoperative chemotherapy was shown to significantly alter the histology, with fewer blastemal and mixed histology types in the tumors. Additionally, there were fewer stage III tumors in the preoperative chemotherapy group.[<a href="#cit/section_2.216">

4085216</a>

4086]</li>

4087<li>

4088Both SIOP and COG treat infants younger than 6 months with a primary nephrectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.217">

4089217</a>

4090]</li>

4091</ul>

4092</div>

4093<p id="_762" tabindex="-1">

4094This summary focuses on the NWTS (now COG RTC) results and studies. </p>

4095<p id="_1021" tabindex="-1">

4096The major treatment and study conclusions of

4097NWTS-1, NWTS-2, NWTS-3, NWTS-4, and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

4098NWTS-5</a>

4099 are as follows:

4100</p>

4101<div class="pdq-content-list">

4102<ol id="_116">

4103<li>

4104Routine, postoperative radiation therapy of the flank is not necessary for

4105children with stage I tumors or stage II tumors with FH

4106when postnephrectomy combination chemotherapy consisting of vincristine and

4107dactinomycin is administered.[<a href="#cit/section_2.214">

4108214</a>

4109]

4110</li>

4111<li>

4112 The prognosis for patients with stage III FH is best when treatment includes either

4113(a) dactinomycin, vincristine, doxorubicin, and 10.8 Gy of radiation therapy to

4114the flank; or (b) dactinomycin, vincristine, and 20 Gy of radiation therapy

4115to the flank.

4116Whole-abdominal radiation is indicated for extensive intraperitoneal disease or widespread intraperitoneal tumor spill with possible boost to gross residual disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.214">

4117214</a>

4118]</li>

4119<li>

4120 The addition of cyclophosphamide at the protocol dose (10 mg/kg/d for 3 days every 6 weeks) to the combination of vincristine,

4121dactinomycin, and doxorubicin does not improve prognosis for patients with

4122stage IV FH tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.214">

4123214</a>

4124]

4125</li>

4126<li>

4127A single dose of dactinomycin per course (stages I&#8211;II FH,

4128stage I anaplastic histology, stage III FH, stages III&#8211;IV, or stages

4129I&#8211;IV clear cell sarcoma of the kidney) is equivalent to the divided-dose

4130courses, results in the same EFS, achieves greater dose intensity,

4131and is associated with less toxicity and expense.[<a href="#cit/section_2.218">

4132218</a>

4133]

4134</li>

4135<li>

4136 Eighteen weeks of therapy is adequate for patients with stage I and stage II FH, and stage III and IV

4137patients can be treated with 6 months of therapy instead of 15 months.[<a href="#cit/section_2.175">

4138175</a>

4139,<a href="#cit/section_2.212">

4140212</a>

4141,<a href="#cit/section_2.218">

4142218</a>

4143-<a href="#cit/section_2.220">

4144220</a>

4145]

4146</li>

4147<li>

4148Gain of 1q is associated with inferior survival in patients with unilateral FH Wilms tumor. It is the single most powerful predictor of outcome, and in the presence of 1q gain, neither 1p nor 16q loss is significant. In the absence of 1q gain in unilateral FH Wilms tumor, 1p and/or 16q loss retain some prognostic significance and are associated with a higher risk of recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

4149105</a>

4150,<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

4151108</a>

4152]</li>

4153</ol>

4154</div>

4155</section>

4156<section id="_763">

4157<h5 id="_763_toc">

4158Surgery</h5>

4159<p id="_764" tabindex="-1">

4160The following operative principles have also evolved from NWTS (COG) trials: </p>

4161<div class="pdq-content-list">

4162<ol id="_791">

4163<li>

4164The most important role

4165for the surgeon is to ensure complete tumor removal without rupture and assess the extent of disease. Radical nephrectomy and lymph node

4166sampling via a transabdominal or thoracoabdominal incision is the procedure

4167of choice.[<a href="#cit/section_2.221">

4168221</a>

4169] A flank incision is not performed because it provides limited exposure to the kidney. <p id="_1277" tabindex="-1">

4170For patients with resectable tumors, preoperative biopsy or intraoperative biopsy is not performed because either would upstage the tumor in the current COG staging system.[<a href="#cit/section_2.221">

4171221</a>

4172]</p>

4173</li>

4174<li>

4175Routine exploration of the contralateral kidney is not necessary if technically adequate imaging studies do not suggest a bilateral process. If the initial imaging studies suggest bilateral kidney involvement, treatment approaches should facilitate renal-sparing surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_2.160">

4176160</a>

4177]</li>

4178<li>

4179About 2% of Wilms tumor cases have ureteral involvement. The presence of gross hematuria, nonfunctioning kidney, or hydronephrosis suggests the tumor may extend into the ureter, and cystoscopy is recommended. En bloc resection to avoid tumor spill is recommended.[<a href="#cit/section_2.222">

4180222</a>

4181]</li>

4182<li>

4183The surgeon needs to be aware of the risk of intraoperative spill, especially in patients who have right-sided and large tumors, as noted in a review of cases of intraoperative spill among 1,131 patients registered on COG study <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00898365">

4184AREN03B2</a>

4185 (NCT00898365).[<a href="#cit/section_2.223">

4186223</a>

4187]</li>

4188<li>

4189Even if stage IV disease (e.g., pulmonary metastases) is evident on imaging, resection of the renal tumor should be considered. Treatment of local stage I or II Wilms tumor in the setting of distant metastasis does not require local radiation therapy.</li>

4190</ol>

4191</div>

4192<p id="_765" tabindex="-1">

4193Renal-sparing surgery remains controversial and is not supported by the data, except for children with the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.224">

4194224</a>

4195,<a href="#cit/section_2.225">

4196225</a>

4197]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.226">

4198226</a>

4199][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4200Level of evidence C1</a>

4201]</p>

4202<div class="pdq-content-list">

4203<ul id="_766">

4204<li>

4205A solitary kidney.</li>

4206<li>

4207Predisposition to bilateral tumors. Some children who are predisposed to bilateral tumors and who have very small tumors detected by screening ultrasonography may be considered for renal-sparing surgery to preserve renal tissue.[<a href="#cit/section_2.224">

4208224</a>

4209] </li>

4210<li>

4211Horseshoe kidney. Wilms tumor arising in a horseshoe kidney is rare, and accurate preoperative diagnosis is important for planning the operative approach. Primary resection is possible in most cases. Inoperable cases can usually be resected after chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.227">

4212227</a>

4213]</li>

4214<li>

4215Wilms tumor in infants with Denys-Drash or Frasier syndrome (to delay the need for dialysis). </li>

4216</ul>

4217</div>

4218<p id="_767" tabindex="-1">

4219 Renal-sparing surgery does not appear to be feasible for most patients at the time of diagnosis because of the location of the tumor within the kidney, even in patients with very low-risk tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.228">

4220228</a>

4221] In North America, renal-sparing surgery (partial nephrectomy) of unilateral Wilms tumor after administration of chemotherapy to shrink the tumor mass is considered investigational.[<a href="#cit/section_2.229">

4222229</a>

4223,<a href="#cit/section_2.230">

4224230</a>

4225]</p>

4226<p id="_784" tabindex="-1">

4227Wilms tumor rarely invades adjacent organs; therefore, resection of contiguous organs is seldom indicated. There is an increased incidence of complications occurring in more extensive resections that involve removal of additional organs beyond the diaphragm and adrenal gland. This finding has led to the recommendation in current COG protocols that patients in whom nephrectomy will require removal of additional organs should be considered for initial biopsy, neoadjuvant chemotherapy, and then secondary resection.[<a href="#cit/section_2.231">

4228231</a>

4229] Primary resection of liver metastasis is not recommended.[<a href="#cit/section_2.232">

4230232</a>

4231]</p>

4232<section id="_2430">

4233<h6 id="_2430_toc">

4234Lymph node sampling</h6>

4235<p id="_2431" tabindex="-1">

4236Lymph node status is a major long-term predictor of outcome in patients with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.221">

4237221</a>

4238] Data from Wilms tumor studies suggest that the lymph node number and location may impact therapy and outcome, although NWTS and COG renal tumor protocols have never defined the number of lymph nodes or locations of lymph nodes to be sampled.[<a href="#cit/section_2.221">

4239221</a>

4240] The ideal number of lymph nodes that should be sampled remains unknown. </p>

4241<div class="pdq-content-list">

4242<ul id="_2432">

4243<li>

4244The 5-year OS rate was lower for patients with 0 lymph nodes sampled (87% vs. 91% for 1&#8211;5 lymph nodes, 93% for 6&#8211;10 lymph nodes, 95% for &gt;10 lymph nodes; <em>

4245P</em>

4246 = .005). Multivariate analysis confirmed a survival advantage for patients having 1 to 5 lymph nodes sampled (HR, 0.6; <em>

4247P</em>

4248 = .016), 6 to 10 lymph nodes sampled (HR, 0.521; <em>

4249P</em>

4250 = .048), and &gt;10 lymph nodes sampled (HR, 0.403; <em>

4251P</em>

4252 = .039), compared with patients with 0 lymph nodes examined.[<a href="#cit/section_2.233">

4253233</a>

4254]</li>

4255<li>

4256In NWTS-5, failure to sample lymph nodes was associated with higher risk of relapse in stage I and II patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.234">

4257234</a>

4258] AREN0532 showed similar results with a poorer EFS observed for patients who did not have a lymph node biopsy. The EFS for stage III patients without lymph node sampling was 84% (n = 148), compared with 89% for those patients who had lymph node sampling (n = 387) (<em>

4259P</em>

4260 = .067).[<a href="#cit/section_2.235">

4261235</a>

4262]</li>

4263<li>

4264Hilar and periaortic lymph node sampling is appropriate even if the nodes appear normal.[<a href="#cit/section_2.221">

4265221</a>

4266,<a href="#cit/section_2.233">

4267233</a>

4268] Furthermore, any suspicious node basin is sampled. Margins of

4269resection, residual tumor, and any suspicious node basins are marked with

4270titanium clips.

4271 </li>

4272</ul>

4273</div>

4274</section>

4275<section id="_2455">

4276<h6 id="_2455_toc">

4277Pleural effusions</h6>

4278<p id="_2456" tabindex="-1">

4279The presence of a pleural effusion does not appear to necessitate a change in therapy. In a multi-institutional retrospective review of 1,259 children with newly diagnosed Wilms tumor, 94 (7.5%) had a pleural effusion.[<a href="#cit/section_2.165">

4280165</a>

4281][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4282Level of evidence C1</a>

4283]</p>

4284<div class="pdq-content-list">

4285<ul id="_2457">

4286<li>

4287Patients with a pleural effusion were older than those without a pleural effusion (median, 4.3 vs. 3.5 years; <em>

4288P</em>

4289 = .004) and were more likely to present with advanced-stage disease (local stage III, 83% vs. 51.6%; <em>

4290P</em>

4291 = .0001).</li>

4292<li>

4293Only 14 patients underwent a thoracentesis, 3 of whom had pulmonary parenchymal metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis.</li>

4294<li>

4295Thirty patients with a pleural effusion received chest radiation therapy as part of their therapy, 29 of whom had pulmonary or mediastinal metastases. </li>

4296<li>

4297Sixty-four patients with a pleural effusion did not receive chest radiation therapy, 59 of whom did not have associated pulmonary disease at the time of diagnosis. </li>

4298<li>

4299Only three patients with a pleural effusion and no history of pulmonary disease later experienced a relapse with thoracic disease. </li>

4300<li>

4301For the entire cohort of patients with pleural effusions, the EFS rate was 86.2%, and the OS rate was 91.5%.</li>

4302</ul>

4303</div>

4304</section>

4305</section>

4306<section id="_769">

4307<h5 id="_769_toc">

4308Chemotherapy</h5>

4309<p id="_770" tabindex="-1">

4310Preoperative chemotherapy before nephrectomy is indicated in the following situations, which have been listed previously under situations requiring a biopsy:[<a href="#cit/section_2.221">

4311221</a>

4312,<a href="#cit/section_2.231">

4313231</a>

4314,<a href="#cit/section_2.236">

4315236</a>

4316-<a href="#cit/section_2.239">

4317239</a>

4318]</p>

4319<div class="pdq-content-list">

4320<ul id="_519">

4321<li>

4322Wilms tumor in a solitary kidney.</li>

4323<li>

4324Synchronous bilateral Wilms tumor.</li>

4325<li>

4326Extension of tumor thrombus in the inferior vena cava above the level of the hepatic veins. About 4% of Wilms tumor patients present with inferior vena cava or atrial involvement, and 11% of patients present with renal vein involvement. Embolization of a caval thrombus to the pulmonary artery is rare but can be lethal, and the presence of a thrombus must be identified preoperatively to prevent this occurrence and guide treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.161">

4327161</a>

4328,<a href="#cit/section_2.173">

4329173</a>

4330]</li>

4331<li>

4332Tumor involves contiguous structures whereby the only means of removing the kidney tumor requires removal of the other structures (e.g., spleen, pancreas, or colon but excluding the adrenal gland).</li>

4333<li>

4334Inoperable Wilms tumor.</li>

4335<li>

4336Pulmonary compromise resulting from extensive pulmonary metastases.</li>

4337</ul>

4338</div>

4339<p id="_2441" tabindex="-1">

4340For more information, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

4341Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

4342 section.</p>

4343<p id="_1022" tabindex="-1">

4344Preoperative chemotherapy follows a biopsy. The biopsy may be

4345performed through a flank approach.[<a href="#cit/section_2.173">

4346173</a>

4347,<a href="#cit/section_2.240">

4348240</a>

4349-<a href="#cit/section_2.244">

4350244</a>

4351] Adequate tissue is essential for accurate histological assessment and molecular studies. Preoperative chemotherapy includes doxorubicin in addition to vincristine and dactinomycin unless anaplastic histology is present. In these cases, chemotherapy then includes treatment with regimen I (see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_388">

4352Table 2</a>

4353). The chemotherapy generally makes tumor

4354removal easier by decreasing the size and vascular supply of the tumor. Chemotherapy may also reduce the frequency of surgical

4355complications.[<a href="#cit/section_2.169">

4356169</a>

4357,<a href="#cit/section_2.173">

4358173</a>

4359,<a href="#cit/section_2.231">

4360231</a>

4361,<a href="#cit/section_2.236">

4362236</a>

4363,<a href="#cit/section_2.245">

4364245</a>

4365,<a href="#cit/section_2.246">

4366246</a>

4367]</p>

4368<p id="_2394" tabindex="-1">

4369In a meta-analysis that investigated the effect of neoadjuvant chemotherapy on thrombus viability for Wilms tumor where intravascular extension was defined as any Wilms tumor with extension beyond the renal vein. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy was found to be effective in achieving thrombus nonviability in around 50% of patients with tumor extension into the inferior vena cava. No added benefit was identified from extended cycles of neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Most patients received chemotherapy consisting of dactinomycin and vincristine with or without doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_2.247">

4370247</a>

4371]</p>

4372<p id="_957" tabindex="-1">

4373In North America, the use of preoperative chemotherapy in patients with evidence of a contained preoperative rupture has been suggested to avoid intraoperative spill, but this is controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_2.248">

4374248</a>

4375,<a href="#cit/section_2.249">

4376249</a>

4377] The preoperative diagnosis of a contained retroperitoneal rupture on CT is difficult, even for experienced pediatric radiologists.[<a href="#cit/section_2.158">

4378158</a>

4379]</p>

4380<p id="_772" tabindex="-1">

4381All infants younger than 12 months (including newborns) who will be treated with chemotherapy require a 50% reduction in

4382chemotherapy dose compared with the dose given to older children.[<a href="#cit/section_2.250">

4383250</a>

4384] Dosing for infants (younger than 12 months) is calculated per kilogram of weight, not body surface area. This reduction

4385diminishes the toxic effects reported in children in this age group enrolled in

4386NWTS studies while maintaining an excellent overall outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.251">

4387251</a>

4388] </p>

4389<p id="_792" tabindex="-1">

4390Liver

4391function tests in children with Wilms tumor are monitored closely during

4392the early course of therapy because hepatic toxic effects (sinusoidal obstructive syndrome, previously called veno-occlusive

4393disease) have been reported in these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.252">

4394252</a>

4395,<a href="#cit/section_2.253">

4396253</a>

4397] Dactinomycin or doxorubicin should not be

4398administered during radiation therapy. Patients who develop renal failure while undergoing therapy can continue receiving chemotherapy with vincristine, dactinomycin, and doxorubicin. Vincristine and doxorubicin can be given at full doses; however, dactinomycin is associated with severe neutropenia. Reductions in dosing these agents may not be necessary, but accurate pharmacologic and pharmacokinetic studies are needed while the patient is receiving therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.254">

4399254</a>

4400,<a href="#cit/section_2.255">

4401255</a>

4402]</p>

4403<p id="_1925" tabindex="-1">

4404Augmentation of therapy improves EFS for patients with FH Wilms tumor and loss of heterozygosity of 1p and 16q. In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00352534">

4405AREN0532 (NCT00352534)</a>

4406 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379340">

4407AREN0533 (NCT00379340)</a>

4408 trials, patients with stage I and stage II FH Wilms tumor who were treated with the DD-4A regimen (dactinomycin, vincristine, and doxorubicin) demonstrated a 4-year EFS rate of 87.3%, compared with the 4-year EFS rate of 68.8% (<em>

4409P</em>

4410 = .042) for stage I and stage II patients treated on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

4411NWTS-5</a>

4412 trial. Patients with stage III and stage IV disease had a 4-year EFS rate of 90.2% when treated with regimen M (see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_388">

4413Table 2</a>

4414), compared with a 61.3% 4-year EFS rate (<em>

4415P</em>

4416 = .001) for stage III and stage IV patients treated on the NWTS-5 trial. Trends toward improved 4-year OS rates were seen in stage I and II patients and in stage III and IV patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.256">

4417256</a>

4418][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4419Level of evidence C2</a>

4420]</p>

4421<p id="_793" tabindex="-1">

4422Postoperative radiation therapy to the tumor bed is required when a biopsy is performed or in the setting of local tumor stage III. In a study of 1,488 patients with Wilms tumors who underwent surgery and radiation therapy, delay in starting radiation therapy after surgery of greater than 14 days was associated with an increased risk of mortality for patients with nonmetastatic Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.257">

4423257</a>

4424][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4425Level of evidence C1</a>

4426]</p>

4427<p id="_794" tabindex="-1">

4428<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_388">

4429Table 2</a>

4430 describes the accepted chemotherapy regimens used to treat Wilms tumor.</p>

4431<table id="_388" class="table-default expandable-container">

4432<caption>

4433Table 2. Accepted Chemotherapy Regimens for Wilms Tumor</caption>

4434<colgroup>

4435<col width="50.00%">

4436<col width="50.00%">

4437</colgroup>

4438<THead>

4439<tr>

4440<th>

4442<th>

4444</tr>

4445</THead>

4446<tbody>

4447<tr>

4450108</a>

4454</tr>

4490259</a>

4494</tr>

4495</tbody>

4496</table>

4497</section>

4498<section id="_1935">

4499<h5 id="_1935_toc">

4500Radiation therapy</h5>

4501<p id="_1936" tabindex="-1">

4502Radiation therapy is used to improve local control and treat sites of metastatic disease. Radiation therapy has historically been dependent on stage and histology, but more recently is also guided by the tumor molecular signature.[<a href="#cit/section_2.180">

4503180</a>

4504]</p>

4505<section id="_1997">

4506<h6 id="_1997_toc">

4507COG approach</h6>

4508<p id="_1938" tabindex="-1">

4509Up-front surgery provides histological confirmation and tumor extent, providing the rationale for adjuvant therapy, including radiation therapy. Besides histology, postoperative risk factors for worse local control include: (1) incomplete resection, (2) positive margins, and (3) nodal involvement. Radiation therapy is not used in patients with stage I or stage II FH Wilms tumor. For patients with FH stage III Wilms tumor, flank or abdominal radiation therapy is used for treatment. In cases of unfavorable histology (focal or diffuse anaplasia), flank or abdominal radiation therapy is indicated for all patients. For more information, see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1948">

4510Table 3</a>

4511.</p>

4512<p id="_1998" tabindex="-1">

4513Results of NWTS (COG RTC) trials have shown the following:</p>

4514<div class="pdq-content-list">

4515<ul id="_1939">

4516<li>

4517Flank radiation therapy covers the tumor bed, involved nodal region, and entire adjacent vertebral bodies at 10.8 Gy in 1.8-Gy fractions. The dose of radiation therapy is based on the results of the NWTS-3 study in which there was no increase in abdominal relapse for stage III FH patients receiving 10 Gy versus 20 Gy with DD-4A chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.260">

4518260</a>

4519]</li>

4520<li>

4521Whole-abdominal radiation therapy is 10.5 Gy in 1.5-Gy fractions and is used to treat diffuse spill or peritoneal metastasis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.256">

4522256</a>

4523]</li>

4524<li>

4525In the closed COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00335556">

4526AREN0321 (NCT00335556)</a>

4527 study, the radiation therapy dose to the tumor bed was 10.8 Gy in 1.8-Gy fractions, with the exception of patients with stage III diffuse anaplasia, where a dose of 19.8 Gy in 1.8-Gy fractions was used. This remains the current standard of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.259">

4528259</a>

4529]</li>

4530<li>

4531Results of the early NWTS studies (1 and 2) suggested that a radiation therapy delay of more than 10 days after surgery resulted in worse local control, particularly in unfavorable histology Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.261">

4532261</a>

4533,<a href="#cit/section_2.262">

4534262</a>

4535] However, no difference in local control was found if radiation therapy was delayed more than 10 days after surgery for patients with stages II to IV FH tumors treated on the NWTS-3 or NWTS-4 trials.[<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

4536101</a>

4537] More recent data from the National Cancer Database confirmed improved survival in patients with nonmetastatic Wilms tumor who received adjuvant radiation therapy less than or equal to 14 days postoperatively.[<a href="#cit/section_2.257">

4538257</a>

4539] </li>

4540<li>

4541Results from the NWTS-3 and NWTS-4 trials indicated that there was no survival benefit of whole-lung irradiation in the setting of lung metastases seen on CT scan only.[<a href="#cit/section_2.263">

4542263</a>

4543] Current COG guidelines allow for omission of whole-lung irradiation in cases of FH disease without extrapulmonary metastases, loss of heterozygosity at 1p and 16q, and complete response at 6 weeks after vincristine, dactinomycin, and doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_2.180">

4544180</a>

4545] When whole-lung irradiation is given, a dose of 12 Gy in 1.5-Gy fractions is indicated for children older than 12 months and 10.5 Gy in 1.5-Gy fractions for patients younger than 12 months with pulmonary metastasis.</li>

4546<li>

4547Other sites of metastatic disease in Wilms tumor are uncommon and may include liver, extra-abdominal nodes, brain, and bone. In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379340">

4548AREN0533 (NCT00379340)</a>

4549 study, the radiation therapy doses being used for patients younger than 16 years are 19.8 Gy in 1.8-Gy fractions to liver and gross residual nodes, 21.6 Gy in 1.8-Gy fractions to the whole brain with a boost of 10.8 Gy in 1.8-Gy fractions to gross metastatic disease in the brain, and 25.2 Gy in 14 fractions for bone metastasis. For patients older than 16 years, the radiation therapy dose to the whole brain and bone is increased to 30.6 Gy in 1.8-Gy fractions.</li>

4550</ul>

4551</div>

4552<table id="_1948" class="table-default expandable-container">

4553<caption>

4554Table 3. Radiation Therapy Regimens used in Children&#8217;s Oncology Group AREN0532, AREN0533, and AREN0321 Protocols</caption>

4555<colgroup>

4556<col width="20.00%">

4557<col width="20.00%">

4558<col width="20.00%">

4559<col width="20.00%">

4560<col width="20.00%">

4561</colgroup>

4744</table>

4745</section>

4746<section id="_1999">

4747<h6 id="_1999_toc">

4748SIOP approach</h6>

4749<p id="_1940" tabindex="-1">

4750Based on the experience of previous SIOP trials, children who need radiation therapy undergo postoperative treatment to the flank and/or metastatic sites. The SIOP 1 to 9 trials demonstrated that preoperative radiation therapy or preoperative chemotherapy decreased the proportion of patients who developed tumor spillage, from more than 20% to 5%. The noninferiority of preoperative chemotherapy to preoperative radiation therapy in the SIOP 5 trial, and the concern over secondary malignancies with preoperative radiation therapy, led SIOP to recommend preoperative chemotherapy as the standard initial treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.215">

4751215</a>

4752] Over time, the percentage of children who were treated with postoperative radiation therapy decreased, from more than 90% to 15% and 25% in SIOP trials 6 to 9, SIOP 93-01, and SIOP-2001, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_2.213">

4753213</a>

4754]</p>

4755<p id="_2039" tabindex="-1">

4756Abdominal radiation therapy has been omitted for patients with metastatic, local stage III Wilms tumor who had complete necrosis after 6 weeks of preoperative chemotherapy. The outcome of patients with stage IV, local stage III, completely necrotic Wilms tumors was excellent (5-year EFS and OS rates of 95%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.264">

4757264</a>

4758]</p>

4759</section>

4760</section>

4761</section>

4762<section id="_973">

4763<h4 id="_973_toc">

4764Treatment of stage I Wilms tumor</h4>

4765<p id="_974" tabindex="-1">

4766 <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_951">

4767Table 4</a>

4768 provides an overview of the standard treatment options and survival data for patients with <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_26">

4769stage I Wilms tumor</a>

4770, based on published results. </p>

4771<table id="_951" class="table-default expandable-container">

4772<caption>

4773Table 4. Overview of Standard Treatment Options for Stage I Wilms Tumor<span class="sup">

4774a</span>

4775</caption>

4776<colgroup>

4777<col width="24.61%">

4778<col width="17.33%">

4779<col width="26.51%">

4780<col width="31.54%">

4781</colgroup>

4782<THead>

4783<tr>

4784<th>

4785Histology</th>

4786<th>

47874-Year RFS or EFS</th>

4788<th>

47894-Year OS</th>

4790<th>

4791Treatment<span class="sup">

4792b</span>

4793 </th>

4794</tr>

4795</THead>

4797<tr>

4800</tr>

4801<tr>

4802<td colspan="4">

4803<span class="sup">

4804a</span>

4805Source: Grundy et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

4806108</a>

4807] Shamberger et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_2.179">

4808179</a>

4809] Fernandez et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_2.180">

4810180</a>

4811] Dix et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_2.256">

4812256</a>

4814265</a>

4816</tr>

4817<tr>

4818<td colspan="4">

4820b</span>

4821For chemotherapy regimen descriptions, see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_388">

4822Table 2</a>

4823.</td>

4824</tr>

4825<tr>

4826<td colspan="4">

4827<span class="sup">

4828c</span>

4829One patient with a pulmonary relapse 4.12 years after diagnosis.</td>

4830</tr>

4831</TFoot>

4832<tbody>

4833<tr>

4834<td>

4835FH &lt;24 mo/tumor weight &lt;550g</td>

4836<td>

483790%</td>

4838<td>

4839100%</td>

4840<td>

4841Surgery, including lymph node biopsy only</td>

4842</tr>

4843<tr>

4844<td>

4845FH &gt;24 mo/tumor weight &gt;550g</td>

4846<td>

4848<td>

484998%</td>

4850<td>

4852</tr>

4854<td>

4855FH with LOH 1p/16q (n = 8)</td>

4856<td>

4857100% EFS</td>

4858<td>

4859100%</td>

4860<td>

4861Nephrectomy + lymph node sampling followed by regimen DD-4A</td>

4862</tr>

4863<tr>

4864<td>

4865FA</td>

4866<td>

4867100%</td>

4868<td>

4869100% (n = 8)</td>

4870<td>

4871Nephrectomy + lymph node sampling followed by regimen DD-4A and XRT</td>

4872</tr>

4873<tr>

4874<td>

4875DA </td>

4876<td>

4877100%<span class="sup">

4878c</span>

4879</td>

4880<td>

4881 100% (n = 10)</td>

4882<td>

4883Nephrectomy + lymph node sampling followed by regimen DD-4A and XRT </td>

4884</tr>

4885</tbody>

4886</table>

4887<p id="_976" tabindex="-1">

4888Evidence (surgery only for children younger than 2 years at diagnosis with stage I FH tumor that weighed &lt;550 g):</p>

4889<p id="_975" tabindex="-1">

4890In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00352534">

4891AREN0532 (NCT00352534)</a>

4892 trial, the COG validated the findings from the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

4893NWTS-5</a>

4894 trial that nephrectomy only is appropriate therapy for patients younger than 2 years at diagnosis with stage I FH Wilms tumor that weighed less than 550 g.</p>

4895<div class="pdq-content-list">

4896<ol id="_977">

4897<li>

4898The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00352534">

4899AREN0532 (NCT00352534)</a>

4900 trial was designed to confirm the findings from NWTS-5 that adjuvant chemotherapy could be omitted for children younger than 2 years at diagnosis with stage I FH Wilms tumor that weighed less than 550 g. A total of 116 patients met the criteria for very low-risk Wilms tumor and were enrolled on the study.[<a href="#cit/section_2.179">

4901179</a>

4902,<a href="#cit/section_2.180">

4903180</a>

4904,<a href="#cit/section_2.266">

4905266</a>

4906]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4907<ul id="_1306">

4908<li>

4909Twelve patients relapsed.</li>

4910<li>

4911The estimated 4-year EFS rate was 89.7%, and the OS rate was 100%.</li>

4912<li>

491311p15 methylation status was associated with relapse (20% relapse with loss of heterozygosity, 25% relapse with loss of imprinting, and 3.3% relapse with retention of the normal imprinting [<em>

4914P</em>

4915 = .011]).</li>

4916<li>

4917The risk of developing metachronous Wilms tumor is very low in patients with very low-risk Wilms tumor who lack evidence of an underlying syndrome.</li>

4918</ul>

4919</div>

4920</li>

4921</ol>

4922</div>

4923<p id="_2000" tabindex="-1">

4924Evidence (treatment of stage I epithelial-predominant FH Wilms tumor):</p>

4925<div class="pdq-content-list">

4926<ol id="_2001">

4927<li>

4928The COG reported the outcomes for patients of all ages with stage I FH Wilms tumors showing epithelial-predominant histology. Approximately 20% of stage I FH Wilms tumors registered on AREN03B2 were epithelial predominant. In this group of 177 patients with stage I epithelial-predominant FH Wilms tumors, 117 patients were treated with EE-4A, and 57 patients were classified as having a very low-risk Wilms tumor and were treated with observation only.[<a href="#cit/section_2.194">

4929194</a>

4930][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4931Level of evidence C1</a>

4932]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4933<ul id="_1968">

4934<li>

4935The 4-year EFS rate was 96.2%, and the OS rate was 100%.</li>

4936<li>

4937There was no statistical difference in EFS and OS based on age at diagnosis (&lt;48 months and &gt;48 months) or treatment (EE-4A vs. observation only).</li>

4938<li>

4939There were six events: three patients developed contralateral tumors after their initial diagnosis, and two of these patients had received adjuvant chemotherapy for their initial tumors. Three patients developed metastatic disease, and all of these patients had previously received EE-4A as their primary therapy.</li>

4940</ul>

4941</div>

4942</li>

4943</ol>

4944</div>

4945<p id="_2002" tabindex="-1">

4946Evidence (treatment of anaplastic stage I Wilms tumor):</p>

4947<div class="pdq-content-list">

4948<ol id="_2003">

4949<li>

4950The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00335556">

4951AREN0321 (NCT00335556)</a>

4952 study demonstrated that outcomes for patients with stage I anaplastic Wilms tumor were improved with the addition of doxorubicin and flank radiation therapy to vincristine/dactinomycin therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.265">

4953265</a>

4954]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4955<ul id="_1943">

4956<li>

4957The 4-year EFS and OS rate estimates were 100% in AREN0321, compared with 70% and 81.5%, respectively, in an updated analysis of 27 patients from <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

4958NWTS-5</a>

4959 (median follow-up, 13.3 years). One patient with diffuse anaplasia relapsed 4.12 years after diagnosis on the AREN0321 trial.</li>

4960<li>

4961The addition of doxorubicin and radiation therapy to AREN0321 was on the basis of the pattern of relapse observed in stage I anaplastic Wilms tumor in the abdomen and distant sites in the NWTS-5 trial.</li>

4962<li>

4963Retrospective analysis of all patients with stage I anaplastic Wilms tumor treated on NWTS-1 through NWTS-5 and AREN0321 showed a significant improvement in EFS for patients treated with doxorubicin (4-year EFS rate, 97.2% vs. 77.5%; <em>

4964P</em>

4965 = .01), but no difference in EFS according to flank radiation therapy was shown (4-year EFS rate, 91.7% vs. 80.2%; <em>

4966P</em>

4967 = .15).</li>

4968<li>

4969The rate of local recurrence was low (3.6%) and appeared to be similar for patients who received flank radiation therapy (4%) and patients who did not receive flank radiation therapy (6.2%). Local relapse occurred only in patients with diffuse anaplasia.</li>

4970</ul>

4971</div>

4972</li>

4973</ol>

4974</div>

4975<section id="_TrialSearch_973_sid_3">

4976<h5 id="_TrialSearch_973_sid_3_toc">

4977Current Clinical Trials</h5>

4978<p id="_TrialSearch_973_22" tabindex="-1">

4979Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

4980advanced clinical trial search</a>

4981 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

4982General information</a>

4983 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

4984</section>

4985</section>

4986<section id="_978">

4993stage II Wilms tumor</a>

5091<section id="_2004">

5092<h5 id="_2004_toc">

5093Treatment of stage II patients with intraoperative spill</h5>

5094<p id="_981" tabindex="-1">

5095In a review of 499 patients from the NWTS-4 trial with stage II FH Wilms tumor, 95 of the patients experienced tumor spill. The 8-year RFS and OS rates for patients who experienced intraoperative tumor spill and were treated with vincristine and dactinomycin without flank radiation therapy were lower (75.7% and 90.3%, respectively) than the rates for those who did not experience tumor spill (85% and 95.6%, respectively). None of these differences achieved statistical significance.[<a href="#cit/section_2.210">

5096210</a>

5097]</p>

5098<p id="_980" tabindex="-1">

5099On the NWTS-3, NWTS-4, and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

5100NWTS-5</a>

5101 trials, patients with intraoperative spill were divided into two groups: (1) those with diffuse spillage involving the whole abdominal cavity; and (2) those with local spillage confined to the flank. Patients with diffuse spillage were treated with radiation therapy to the entire abdomen and three-drug chemotherapy (vincristine, dactinomycin, and doxorubicin), whereas patients with local spillage were treated with vincristine and dactinomycin only. On the basis of an analysis of patients treated on NWTS-3 and NWTS-4 indicating that patients with stage II disease and local spillage had inferior OS compared with patients with stage II disease without local spillage, COG studies treat patients with local spillage with doxorubicin and flank radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.267">

5102267</a>

5103] This approach is controversial and has not been tested; therefore, it should not be considered standard. </p>

5104</section>

5105<section id="_TrialSearch_978_sid_4">

5106<h5 id="_TrialSearch_978_sid_4_toc">

5107Current Clinical Trials</h5>

5108<p id="_TrialSearch_978_22" tabindex="-1">

5109Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

5110advanced clinical trial search</a>

5111 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

5112General information</a>

5113 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

5114</section>

5115</section>

5128 section.</p>

5308<section id="_2005">

5309<h5 id="_2005_toc">

5310Radiation therapy</h5>

5311<p id="_1924" tabindex="-1">

5312Early initiation of radiation therapy is a critical component of multimodal therapy for patients with nonmetastatic Wilms tumor. In a review of 1,488 patients with Wilms tumor who underwent surgery and radiation therapy, a surgery-to-radiation therapy interval of greater than 14 days was associated with an increased risk of mortality (hazard ratio, 2.13; <em>

5313P</em>

5314 = .013). This underscores the importance of initiating radiation therapy within 14 days of surgery, which is specified in Wilms tumor treatment protocols.[<a href="#cit/section_2.257">

5315257</a>

5316][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5317Level of evidence C1</a>

5318]</p>

5319</section>

5320<section id="_2006">

5321<h5 id="_2006_toc">

5322Loss of heterozygosity of 1p or 16q</h5>

5323<p id="_984" tabindex="-1">

5324Loss of heterozygosity of 1p or 16q was shown to influence EFS but not OS in 588 patients with stage III FH Wilms tumor treated on the COG AREN0532 protocol. When combined, lymph node status and loss of heterozygosity status provided a strong predictor of excellent EFS and OS when both were absent. The 4-year EFS rate was 97%, and the OS rate was 99%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.235">

5325235</a>

5326][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5327Level of evidence B4</a>

5328] The outcome was poorer for patients having both positive lymph nodes and loss of heterozygosity of 1p or 16q, with a 4-year EFS rate of 74%. However, the 4-year OS rate was not influenced, at 92%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.235">

5329235</a>

5330] On the basis of these results, therapy was augmented for patients with loss of heterozygosity of 1p/16q for patients enrolled on the AREN0533 trial. Patients with stage III and stage IV Wilms tumor with loss of heterozygosity were treated with regimen M. The 4-year EFS rate was 90.2%, and the OS rate was 96.1%, compared with a 4-year EFS rate of 61.3% (<em>

5331P</em>

5332 = .001) and a 4-year OS rate of 86.0% (<em>

5333P</em>

5334 = .087) for patients in the NWTS-5 trial. There was a suggestion of improvement in survival; however, the study was not powered to detect differences in survival.[<a href="#cit/section_2.256">

5335256</a>

5336][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5337Level of evidence C2</a>

5338]</p>

5339</section>

5340<section id="_TrialSearch_982_sid_5">

5341<h5 id="_TrialSearch_982_sid_5_toc">

5342Current Clinical Trials</h5>

5343<p id="_TrialSearch_982_22" tabindex="-1">

5344Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

5345advanced clinical trial search</a>

5346 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

5347General information</a>

5348 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

5349</section>

5350</section>

5358stage IV Wilms tumor</a>

5359, based on published results. </p>
