5461Nephrectomy + lymph node sampling, followed by abdominal XRT<span class="sup">

5462b</span>

5463 and regimen DD-4A</td>

5464</tr>

5465<tr>

5466<td>

5467FH (no LOH of 1p and 16q) with isolated lung nodules with incomplete response to DD-4A</td>

5468<td>

546999% EFS</td>

5470<td>

547195%</td>

5472<td>

5473Nephrectomy + lymph node sampling, followed by abdominal XRT<span class="sup">

5474b</span>

5475 and bilateral pulmonary XRT<span class="sup">

5476c</span>

5477 and regimen M</td>

5478</tr>

5479<tr>

5480<td>

5481FH (LOH of 1p and 16q) with isolated lung nodules (n = 18)</td>

5482<td>

5483100%</td>

5484<td>

5485100%</td>

5486<td>

5487Nephrectomy + lymph node sampling followed by abdominal XRT<strong>

5488</strong>

5489 and bilateral pulmonary XRT<span class="sup">

5490c</span>

5491 and regimen M</td>

5492</tr>

5493<tr>

5494<td>

5495FH (with LOH of 1p and/or 16q) (n = 20)</td>

5496<td>

549795% EFS</td>

5498<td>

5499100%</td>

5500<td>

5501Nephrectomy + lymph node sampling, abdominal XRT<span class="sup">

5502b</span>

5503 radiation to sites of metastases<span class="sup">

5504b</span>

5505, and regimen M</td>

5506</tr>

5507<tr>

5508<td>

5509FA</td>

5510<td>

551161%

5512EFS</td>

5513<td>

551472% (n = 11)</td>

5515<td>

5516Nephrectomy + lymph node sampling, followed by abdominal XRT,<span class="sup">

5517b</span>

5518 radiation to sites of metastases, bilateral pulmonary XRT,<span class="sup">

5519c</span>

5520 and regimen DD-4A</td>

5521</tr>

5522<tr>

5523<td>

5524DA</td>

5525<td>

552633% EFS</td>

5527<td>

552833% (n = 10)</td>

5529<td>

5530Immediate nephrectomy + lymph node sampling followed by abdominal XRT,<span class="sup">

5531b</span>

5532 radiation to sites of metastases, whole-lung XRT,<span class="sup">

5533c</span>

5534 and regimen I</td>

5535</tr>

5536<tr>

5537<td>

5538DA (preoperative treatment)</td>

5539<td>

554060% EFS</td>

5541<td>

554270% (n = 10)</td>

5543<td>

5544Preoperative treatment with regimen UH2 followed by nephrectomy + lymph node sampling, followed by abdominal XRT,<span class="sup">

5545b</span>

5546 radiation to sites of metastases, and whole-lung XRT<span class="sup">

5547c</span>

5548 </td>

5549</tr>

5550</tbody>

5551</table>

5552<p id="_988" tabindex="-1">

5553Stage IV disease is defined by the presence of hematogenous metastases to the lung, liver, bone, brain, or other sites, with the lung being the most common site. The presence of liver metastases at diagnosis is not an independent adverse prognostic factor in patients with stage IV Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.232">

5554232</a>

5555]</p>

5556<section id="_2433">

5557<h5 id="_2433_toc">

5558Chromosome 1q gain</h5>

5559<p id="_2434" tabindex="-1">

5560In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379340">

5561AREN0533 (NCT00379340)</a>

5562 trial, 30% of patients with stage IV pulmonary disease had 1q gain. These patients trended toward worse EFS, regardless of lung response and whether they received regimen DD-4A or M.[<a href="#cit/section_2.258">

5563258</a>

5564] Patients in this trial with stage IV lung-only disease who had a rapid complete response to DD-4A and did not receive pulmonary radiation had a lower EFS compared with patients without 1q gain (4-year EFS rates, 57% vs. 86%; <em>

5565P</em>

5566 = .0013). The 4-year overall survival rate, although not statistically significant, was better in patients without 1q gain compared with patients with 1q gain and pulmonary disease (97% vs. 89%; <em>

5567P</em>

5568 = .16).[<a href="#cit/section_2.258">

5569258</a>

5570] Patients who were slow incomplete responders with pulmonary-only disease and 1q gain (treated with DD-4A followed by pulmonary radiation therapy and regimen M) had 4-year EFS and OS rates of 86% and 93%, respectively. In comparison, patients with slow incomplete response without 1q gain had 4-year EFS and OS rates of 92% and 96%, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_2.258">

5571258</a>

5572]</p>

5573</section>

5574<section id="_2007">

5575<h5 id="_2007_toc">

5576Treatment of pulmonary nodules and metastases</h5>

5577<p id="_2008" tabindex="-1">

5578Historically, chest x-rays were used to detect pulmonary metastases. The introduction of CT created controversy because many patients had lung nodules detected by chest CT scans that were not seen on chest x-rays. Management of newly diagnosed patients with FH Wilms tumor who have lung nodules detected only by CT scans (with negative chest x-ray) has elicited controversy as to whether they need to be treated with additional intensive treatment that is accompanied by acute and late toxicities.</p>

5579<p id="_989" tabindex="-1">

5580Evidence (treatment of pulmonary nodules detected by chest CT scan only):</p>

5581<div class="pdq-content-list">

5582<ol id="_990">

5583<li>

5584A retrospective review of 186 patients from NWTS-4 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

5585NWTS-5</a>

5586 with CT-only&#8211;detected lung nodules reported on the use of doxorubicin, vincristine, and dactinomycin versus the use of two drugs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.268">

5587268</a>

5588]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5589<ul id="_800">

5590<li>

5591Patients who received doxorubicin, vincristine, and dactinomycin with or without lung irradiation had a 5-year EFS rate of 80% versus an EFS rate of 56% for patients receiving only two drugs (<em>

5592P</em>

5593 = .004). </li>

5594<li>

5595There was no difference in EFS according to whether the lung was irradiated.</li>

5596<li>

5597There was no difference in the 5-year OS rate (87% vs. 86%).</li>

5598</ul>

5599</div>

5600</li>

5601</ol>

5602</div>

5603<p id="_992" tabindex="-1">

5604Retrospective studies from Europe have examined the impact of omitting pulmonary radiation in patients with pulmonary metastases diagnosed by chest x-ray. European investigators omitted radiation from the treatment of most patients with Wilms tumor and pulmonary metastases as identified on chest x-ray who were treated on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003804">

5605SIOP-93-01 (NCT00003804)</a>

5606 trial. The European approach to renal tumors differs from the approach used in North America. All patients who were shown to have a renal tumor by imaging underwent 9 weeks of prenephrectomy chemotherapy consisting of vincristine, dactinomycin, and doxorubicin. </p>

5607<p id="_993" tabindex="-1">

5608Evidence (omission of pulmonary irradiation):</p>

5609<div class="pdq-content-list">

5610<ol id="_994">

5611<li>

5612In a retrospective SIOP study, 234 newly diagnosed patients with Wilms tumor presenting with pulmonary metastases were treated according to the response of the pulmonary metastases to the prenephrectomy chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.269">

5613269</a>

5614] <div class="pdq-content-list">

5615<ol id="_1023" class="lower-alpha">

5616<li>

5617Patients who were in complete remission (67%) after 6 weeks of therapy continued with the same chemotherapy and did not require radiation to their lungs. <div class="pdq-content-list">

5618<ul id="_1024">

5619<li>

5620The 5-year EFS rate was 77%, and the OS rate was 88%.</li>

5621</ul>

5622</div>

5623</li>

5624<li>

5625Patients who had residual pulmonary metastases were evaluated for metastasectomy.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5626<ul id="_1025">

5627<li>

5628Thirty-seven patients (17%) obtained complete remission with surgery, and their outcome was similar to that of the group of patients who were treated with chemotherapy. Tumor viability in the resected pulmonary metastases was not a factor for omitting radiation therapy.</li>

5629<li>

5630 The 5-year EFS rate was 84%, and the OS rate was 92%.</li>

5631</ul>

5632</div>

5633</li>

5634<li>

5635Patients with residual pulmonary metastases that were incompletely resected or inoperable received more aggressive chemotherapy consisting of ifosfamide/anthracycline alternating with carboplatin/etoposide for 9 weeks. <div class="pdq-content-list">

5636<ul id="_1026">

5637<li>

5638Patients showing a complete remission at that time were spared pulmonary radiation and continued with chemotherapy, whereas patients with residual pulmonary metastases continued with additional chemotherapy (to complete 34 weeks) and pulmonary irradiation. The 5-year OS rate was 48%, compared with the OS rates for patients who responded to chemotherapy alone (88%) and those who underwent metastasectomy (92%) (<em>

5639P</em>

5640 &lt; .001).</li>

5641<li>

5642Patients with high-risk histologies, such as anaplastic Wilms tumor, were treated with more aggressive chemotherapy but had a poorer outcome, compared with that of patients with nonanaplastic histologies (5-year OS rate, 33% vs. 87%; <em>

5643P</em>

5644 &lt; .001).</li>

5645</ul>

5646</div>

5647</li>

5648</ol>

5649</div>

5650</li>

5651<li>

5652Based on the European experience, the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379340">

5653AREN0533 (NCT00379340)</a>

5654 study applied a new strategy for patients with FH Wilms tumor and isolated lung metastases to improve EFS while reducing exposure to lung irradiation. Therapy was adjusted on the basis of lung nodule response and tumor-specific loss of heterozygosity at 1p and 16q.[<a href="#cit/section_2.258">

5655258</a>

5656][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5657Level of evidence C2</a>

5658]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5659<ul id="_1868">

5660<li>

5661Of the 292 patients enrolled in the study, 133 patients (42%) showed a complete lung nodule response after 6 weeks of DD-4A (vincristine, dactinomycin, doxorubicin) and continued receiving the same chemotherapy without lung radiation therapy. The 4-year EFS rate was 80%, and OS rate was 96%.</li>

5662<li>

5663Patients who had an incomplete lung nodule response (n = 145) or loss of heterozygosity at 1p/16q (n = 18) received lung radiation therapy and four cycles of cyclophosphamide/etoposide in addition to the DD-4A drugs (regimen M). The 4-year EFS rate was 89%, and the OS rate was 95% for the incomplete lung nodule response group without loss of heterozygosity. Of the patients with pulmonary metastases only and loss of heterozygosity, the 4-year EFS and OS rates were 100%.</li>

5664<li>

5665In a post hoc analysis of 1q gain in 212 patients enrolled in AREN0533 who had DNA available, patients with lung nodule complete remission with 1q gain had a significantly worse 4-year EFS rate (57% vs. 86%, <em>

5666P</em>

5667 = .001) and trend toward inferior OS rates (89% vs. 97%). Relapses were predominantly pulmonary. There was no difference in outcome for patients with incomplete lung nodule response on the basis of 1q gain.</li>

5668<li>

5669Regimen M has a higher potential for late effects (increased risk of secondary leukemias and risk of infertility related to a cumulative dose of cyclophosphamide of 8.8 g/m<span class="sup">

56702</span>

5671).</li>

5672<li>

5673COG showed that initial lung radiation therapy could be avoided in approximately 40% of patients. OS was excellent; however, there was a trend toward more events than expected (expected, 15% and observed, 20%; <em>

5674P</em>

5675 = .052).</li>

5676</ul>

5677</div>

5678</li>

5679</ol>

5680</div>

5681<p id="_1869" tabindex="-1">

5682Although fewer patients were spared pulmonary radiation when treated in the COG trial than in the European trials, it is important to note several differences between the studies and why the studies cannot be directly compared.[<a href="#cit/section_2.258">

5683258</a>

5684,<a href="#cit/section_2.269">

5685269</a>

5686] Patients in Europe receive a more dose-dense regimen of dactinomycin and doxorubicin before their pulmonary metastases are reevaluated than do patients in North America (135 ug/kg dactinomycin and 100 mg/m<span class="sup">

56872</span>

5688 doxorubicin in Europe, compared with 45 ug/kg dactinomycin and 45 mg/m<span class="sup">

56892</span>

5690 of doxorubicin in North America). European studies allow lung radiation therapy to be omitted for patients with a complete remission achieved by chemotherapy or pulmonary metastasectomy, whereas radiation therapy was only omitted in the United States for patients with a complete remission using chemotherapy alone. Imaging studies were not centrally reviewed in the European studies, whereas they were in the United States, and the definition of complete remission may have been more stringent in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379340">

5691AREN0533 (NCT00379340)</a>

5692 trial.</p>

5693</section>

5694<section id="_2458">

5695<h5 id="_2458_toc">

5696Liver metastases at diagnosis</h5>

5697<p id="_2459" tabindex="-1">

5698The liver is an infrequent site of metastases at diagnosis for patients with stage IV FH Wilms tumor. In 634 patients with stage IV FH Wilms tumor from the NWTS-4 and -5 studies, 96 (15%) presented with liver involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_2.232">

5699232</a>

5700] The impact of liver metastases at diagnosis on patient care management has not been studied in a prospective manner. Most reported experiences come from single institutions and/or retrospective studies that do not include more modern surgical approaches or contemporary risk stratification parameters. In aggregate, there are not sufficient data to support liver metastases as an unfavorable site for metastatic disease, although there were some early SIOP studies that conflicted with this finding.[<a href="#cit/section_2.232">

5701232</a>

5702,<a href="#cit/section_2.270">

5703270</a>

5704-<a href="#cit/section_2.274">

5705274</a>

5706]</p>

5707<section id="_2460">

5708<h6 id="_2460_toc">

5709NWTS</h6>

5710<p id="_2461" tabindex="-1">

5711A retrospective analysis of 742 patients with stage IV Wilms tumor who were treated on the NWTS-4 and -5 trials examined the outcomes of patients with and without lung metastases alone. The study also investigated survival outcomes for these patients according to whether they underwent a resection of their hepatic tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.232">

5712232</a>

5713]</p>

5714<div class="pdq-content-list">

5715<ul id="_2462">

5716<li>

5717Twenty-two patients underwent primary liver resections (18 wedge resections and 4 lobectomies). After chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy, 13 patients underwent liver resections (7 wedge resections, 5 lobectomies, and 1 trisegmentectomy).</li>

5718<li>

5719Seventy-one patients (67%) did not undergo surgery for their liver disease. In 14 patients, the liver disease responded completely to chemotherapy alone.</li>

5720<li>

5721Eighty-two patients received abdominal radiation therapy.</li>

5722<li>

5723The EFS rate was 75% for patients with metastatic FH Wilms tumor. For patients with lung-only metastases (n = 513), the EFS rate was 76%. For patients with liver metastases without lung metastases (n = 34), the EFS rate was 76%. The EFS rate was 70% (n = 62) for patients with both liver and lung metastases, compared with 64% for patients (n = 25) with other sites of metastases. There were no significant differences between the stage IV groups of patients (<em>

5724P</em>

5725 = .60).</li>

5726<li>

5727The EFS rate was 86% for patients who underwent primary resection of the liver metastases (n = 22), compared with 68% for patients who did not have a primary resection of the liver metastases (<em>

5728P</em>

5729 = .09).</li>

5730<li>

5731No significant difference in EFS was observed for patients treated with chemotherapy alone compared with patients treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy (<em>

5732P</em>

5733 = .63). The EFS rates were 64% for patients who did not receive abdominal radiation therapy, 77% for patients who received abdominal radiation therapy without a boost, and 72% for patients who received abdominal radiation therapy with a boost (<em>

5734P</em>

5735 = .05).</li>

5736<li>

5737Adult patients comprised part of the study population (&lt;10% were older than 12 years and 3% were older than 16 years).</li>

5738<li>

5739Based on these data, the authors concluded that liver metastasis at diagnosis is not an independent adverse prognostic factor for patients with stage IV disease. They also suggested that there is no reason to perform hepatic resection in the up-front setting. These two studies occurred between the 1960s and 1990s. During this time, hepatic resection techniques and approaches changed based on a better understanding of the liver anatomy. Furthermore, contemporary risk stratification approaches that include tumor cytogenetics were not evaluated in these studies nor were more conventional radiation techniques such as IMRT, which has the potential to provide better protection to normal tissues.[<a href="#cit/section_2.275">

5740275</a>

5741]</li>

5742</ul>

5743</div>

5744</section>

5745<section id="_2463">

5746<h6 id="_2463_toc">

5747SIOP</h6>

5748<p id="_2464" tabindex="-1">

5749The SIOP/Gesellschaft f&#252;r P&#228;diatrische H&#228;matologie und Onkologie (GPOH) group has recommended a more aggressive surgical approach. This recommendation was based on the reported outcomes of 29 patients treated on the SIOP93-01/GPOH and SIOP2001/GPOH trials that enrolled 1,365 patients between 1994 and 2004. Two of the patients had diffuse anaplasia.[<a href="#cit/section_2.271">

5750271</a>

5751]</p>

5752<div class="pdq-content-list">

5753<ul id="_2465">

5754<li>

5755The 5-year OS rate was 62.6% for patients with hepatic metastases, whereas the OS rate was 76.3% for all patients with stage IV disease. Within the group of patients with liver metastases, 14 did not undergo liver resections. Four of the patients (13%) responded to chemotherapy and were still alive at the time of the publication. </li>

5756<li>

5757Fifteen patients underwent liver surgery (11 primary liver resections, 6 complete resections, and 5 incomplete resections). All six patients who had a complete resection survived.</li>

5758<li>

5759As a result of these findings, the authors recommended an aggressive initial surgical approach for patients with liver disease. However, it is important to remember that SIOP patients receive preoperative chemotherapy before nephrectomy and/or resection of metastatic lesions.</li>

5760</ul>

5761</div>

5762<p id="_2466" tabindex="-1">

5763The French cohort enrolled on the SIOP2001 trial included 131 patients with stage IV FH Wilms tumor. Of these patients, 18 (14%) had liver metastases at diagnosis, including 4 (3%) with isolated liver metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.274">

5764274</a>

5765]</p>

5766<div class="pdq-content-list">

5767<ul id="_2492">

5768<li>

5769The 5-year EFS rate was 83%, and the OS rate was 88% for this cohort of patients with liver metastases. </li>

5770<li>

5771The authors concluded that liver involvement does not appear to be an adverse prognostic marker in patients with metastatic Wilms tumors, although there was a small number of patients in this study.</li>

5772</ul>

5773</div>

5774</section>

5775</section>

5776<section id="_2009">

5777<h5 id="_2009_toc">

5778Treatment of stage IV diffuse anaplastic Wilms tumor</h5>

5779<p id="_1965" tabindex="-1">

5780In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00335556">

5781AREN0321 (NCT00335556)</a>

5782 study, the combination of vincristine and irinotecan (VI) was tested in an up-front window for patients with diffuse anaplastic Wilms tumor and measurable disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.259">

5783259</a>

5784][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5785Level of evidence C2</a>

5786]</p>

5787<div class="pdq-content-list">

5788<ul id="_2018">

5789<li>

5790Fourteen patients with stage IV diffuse anaplastic Wilms tumor with measurable disease received the window therapy; one patient achieved a complete response (CR), ten patients achieved partial responses (PRs), and no patients had stable disease. This resulted in a CR and PR rate of 79%.</li>

5791<li>

5792Patients who responded to VI in the window therapy had VI incorporated into their regimen (UH2).</li>

5793<li>

5794Because of the observed cardiac/pulmonary toxicities encountered in this trial, the study was interrupted and amended with reduced doses of doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide (when combined with carboplatin).</li>

5795<li>

5796Further study of the modified regimen is planned in patients with newly diagnosed diffuse anaplastic Wilms tumor.</li>

5797</ul>

5798</div>

5799</section>

5800<section id="_2020">

5801<h5 id="_2020_toc">

5802Treatment options under clinical evaluation</h5>

5803<p id="_1833" tabindex="-1">

5804Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

5805NCI website</a>

5806. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

5807ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

5808.</p>

5809<p id="_2021" tabindex="-1">

5810The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

5811</section>

5812<div class="pdq-content-list">

5813<ul id="_2022">

5814<li>

5815<strong>

5816<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT04322318">

5817AREN1921 (NCT04322318)</a>

5818</strong>

5819 (A Study of Combination Chemotherapy for Patients With Newly Diagnosed Diffuse Anaplastic Wilms Tumors and Relapsed Favorable-Histology Wilms Tumors)<strong>

5820:</strong>

5821 This clinical trial aims to improve survival by intensifying treatment for patients with diffuse anaplastic Wilms tumors. This trial will expand on the overall improvement observed with the revised UH1/UH2 regimen from the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00335556">

5822AREN0321</a>

5823 trial, which was modified along with the addition of vincristine/irinotecan.</li>

5824</ul>

5825</div>

5826<section id="_TrialSearch_986_sid_6">

5827<h5 id="_TrialSearch_986_sid_6_toc">

5828Current Clinical Trials</h5>

5829<p id="_TrialSearch_986_22" tabindex="-1">

5830Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

5831advanced clinical trial search</a>

5832 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

5833General information</a>

5834 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

5835</section>

5836</section>

5837<section id="_601">

5838<h4 id="_601_toc">

5839Treatment of stage V Wilms tumor and those predisposed to developing bilateral Wilms tumor</h4>

5840<p id="_945" tabindex="-1">

5841Currently, there is not a standard approach for the treatment of <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_42">

5842stage V Wilms tumor</a>

5843 (bilateral Wilms tumor at diagnosis) and those predisposed to developing bilateral Wilms tumor. However, for the first time, a prospective study of the treatment of patients with bilateral Wilms tumor has been completed and provides guidance for the approach.[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

5844171</a>

5845]</p>

5846<p id="_637" tabindex="-1">

5847Management of a child with bilateral Wilms tumor is very challenging. The goals of therapy are to eradicate all tumor and to preserve as much normal renal tissue as possible, with the hope of decreasing the risk of chronic renal failure among these children.[<a href="#cit/section_2.276">

5848276</a>

5849] </p>

5850<p id="_807" tabindex="-1">

5851Historically, based on the NWTS-4 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

5852NWTS-5</a>

5853 trials and trials performed in Europe, patients with bilateral Wilms tumor have had a lower EFS and OS than have patients with localized Wilms tumor. The NWTS-4 study reported that the 8-year EFS rate for patients with bilateral FH Wilms tumor was 74%, and the OS rate was 89%; for patients with anaplastic histology, the EFS rate was 40%, and the OS rate was 45%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.197">

5854197</a>

5855] The NWTS-5 study reported that the 4-year EFS rate for all bilateral Wilms tumor patients was 56%, and the OS rate was 81%; the 4-year EFS rates for patients with FH (65%), focal anaplastic histology (76%), and diffuse anaplastic histology (25%) were also reported.[<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

5856108</a>

5857,<a href="#cit/section_2.178">

5858178</a>

5859] Similar outcomes for patients with bilateral Wilms tumor have been reported in Europe.[<a href="#cit/section_2.196">

5860196</a>

5861,<a href="#cit/section_2.277">

5862277</a>

5863] In a single-institution experience in the Netherlands (N = 41), there was significant morbidity in terms of renal failure (32%) and secondary tumors (20%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.277">

5864277</a>

5865] The incidence of end-stage renal failure in the Dutch study may be a reflection of a longer follow-up period.</p>

5866<p id="_1299" tabindex="-1">

5867Treatment options for stage V (bilateral) Wilms tumor include the following:</p>

5868<div class="pdq-content-list">

5869<ol id="_1300">

5870<li>

5871<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_774">

5872Preoperative chemotherapy and resection</a>

5873.</li>

5874<li>

5875<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_778">

5876Renal transplant</a>

5877.</li>

5878</ol>

5879</div>

5880<section id="_774">

5881<h5 id="_774_toc">

5882Preoperative chemotherapy and resection</h5>

5883<p id="_1872" tabindex="-1">

5884For patients with bilateral Wilms tumor, the goal of therapy is to preserve as much renal tissue as possible without compromising overall outcome. This approach is used to avoid the late effect of end-stage renal disease, which can be caused by underlying germline genetic aberrations and treatment-related loss of functional renal tissue. End-stage renal disease occurs more frequently in patients with bilateral Wilms tumor (12% nonsyndromic) than in patients with unilateral Wilms tumor (&lt;1%). Functional renal outcome is considerably better after bilateral nephron-sparing surgery than after other types of surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

5885171</a>

5886]</p>

5887<p id="_1278" tabindex="-1">

5888Traditionally, patients have undergone bilateral renal biopsies, with staging of each kidney followed by preoperative chemotherapy. In the first prospective multi-institutional treatment trial (COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00945009">

5889AREN0534 [NCT00945009]</a>

5890), pretreatment biopsies were not required if results of imaging tests were consistent with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

5891171</a>

5892] This approach was taken because the bilateral occurrence of non-Wilms renal tumors is very low. Also, core-needle and wedge biopsies are not highly successful in identifying anaplasia in Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.170">

5893170</a>

5894] In the setting of an unusual clinical situation, such as age older than 10 years or atypical imaging features, when a diagnosis other than Wilms should be considered, a tissue diagnosis is obtained.[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

5895171</a>

5896]</p>

5897<p id="_1279" tabindex="-1">

5898For patients who are treated with preoperative chemotherapy, the tumor pathology needs to be evaluated after 4 to 8 weeks. For patients not treated in a clinical trial, the ideal time to perform a biopsy or resection is unknown because minimal shrinkage may reflect chemotherapy-induced differentiation or anaplastic histology. A planned attempt at resection or biopsy of apparently unresectable tumor is undertaken no later than 12 weeks from diagnosis. Continuing therapy without evaluating tumor pathology in a patient with bilateral Wilms tumor may miss anaplastic histology or chemotherapy-induced differentiation (including rhabdomyomatous differentiation) and thus increase toxicity for the patient without providing additional benefit for tumor control. Anaplastic histology occurs in 10% of patients with bilateral Wilms tumor, and these tumors respond poorly to chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.197">

5899197</a>

5900]</p>

5901<p id="_1280" tabindex="-1">

5902Once the diagnosis is confirmed, a complete resection is performed. Histological confirmation of the diagnosis is not straightforward. In a series of 27 patients from the NWTS-4 study, discordant pathology (unilateral anaplastic tumor) was seen in 20 cases (74%), which highlights the need to obtain tissue from both kidneys. Seven children who were later diagnosed with diffuse anaplastic tumors had core biopsies performed to establish the diagnosis; however, anaplasia was not found. Anaplasia was identified in only three of the nine patients when an open-wedge biopsy was performed and in seven of nine patients who had a partial or complete nephrectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.197">

5903197</a>

5904]</p>

5905<p id="_1281" tabindex="-1">

5906The decision to administer chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy after biopsy or a second-look

5907operation is dependent on the tumor's response to initial therapy. More aggressive

5908therapy is required for patients with inadequate response to initial therapy

5909observed at the second procedure or in the setting of anaplasia.[<a href="#cit/section_2.209">

5910209</a>

5911,<a href="#cit/section_2.278">

5912278</a>

5913,<a href="#cit/section_2.279">

5914279</a>

5915]</p>

5916<p id="_1840" tabindex="-1">

5917End-stage renal disease is the most clinically significant morbidity in patients with bilateral Wilms tumor and can be caused by underlying germline genetic aberrations, as well as treatment-related loss of functional renal tissue. Long-term monitoring of renal function is required after treatment for bilateral disease.</p>

5918<p id="_808" tabindex="-1">

5919Evidence (preoperative chemotherapy and resection for bilateral Wilms tumor):</p>

5920<div class="pdq-content-list">

5921<ol id="_809">

5922<li>

5923The first prospective study in bilateral Wilms tumor (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00945009">

5924AREN0534 [NCT00945009]</a>

5925) aimed to improve EFS and OS while preserving renal tissue by intensifying preoperative chemotherapy (using three drugs&#8212;vincristine, dactinomycin, and doxorubicin), completing definitive surgery by 12 weeks from diagnosis, and modifying postoperative chemotherapy on the basis of histological response.[<a href="#cit/section_2.171">

5926171</a>

5927]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.280">

5928280</a>

5929][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5930Level of evidence C2</a>

5931]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5932<ul id="_1841">

5933<li>

5934For the arm that treated children with bilateral Wilms tumor, results showed that central review of imaging, surgical resection within 12 weeks of diagnosis, and response-based and histology-based postoperative therapy improved EFS and OS, when compared with the historical outcomes of children with bilateral Wilms tumor.</li>

5935<li>

5936For the 180 patients with bilateral Wilms tumor, the 4-year EFS rate was 81% (95% confidence interval [CI], 74%&#8211;87%), and the OS rate was 95% (95% CI, 91%&#8211;99%). The above-described approach with risk assignment for treatment based on both staging and postoperative histopathology yielded excellent outcomes for patients with bilateral Wilms tumors but did not improve outcome for patients with diffuse anaplasia. Seven patients who had completely necrotic tumors had a 4-year EFS rate of 100%. Of 118 patients who had tumors with intermediate-risk histopathology, the 4-year EFS rate was 82% and the OS rate was 97%. Fourteen patients with blastemal-type tumors had a 4-year EFS rate of 79% and an OS rate of 93%. Patients who had complete necrosis were assigned to the low-risk category and those with blastemal-type histopathology to the high-risk category for subsequent treatments. For 18 patients who had diffuse anaplasia, the 4-year EFS rate was 61% and the OS rate was 72%. For seven patients who had focal anaplasia, the EFS rate was 71% and the OS rate was 100%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.280">

5937280</a>

5938][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5939Level of evidence C2</a>

5940] Because biopsy was not performed before treatment in this series, some of the patients enrolled may have had only nephrogenic rests and not a true Wilms tumor. This finding may have improved these survival figures over historical controls.</li>

5941<li>

5942One of the aims of the study was that 75% of patients undergo definitive surgery by 12 weeks. After induction chemotherapy, 163 of 189 patients (84%) underwent definitive surgical treatment in at least one kidney by 12 weeks, and 39% of patients retained parts of both kidneys.</li>

5943<li>

5944Chemotherapy after surgery was tailored according to histological response. The 4-year EFS rate was 84.1% for FH tumors, 58.2% for anaplastic histology tumors, and 82% for blastemal-type tumors.</li>

5945<li>

5946Because of the higher risk of renal failure in patients with bilateral Wilms tumor than in patients with unilateral Wilms tumor, one of the goals of the study was that 50% of the patients undergo bilateral nephron-sparing surgery. This threshold was not met, with only 39% of patients successfully treated with bilateral nephron-sparing surgery.</li>

5947<li>

5948Based on the above study, the recommendation was to continue with three-drug preoperative chemotherapy for 6 to 12 weeks followed by nephron-sparing surgery whenever possible. After resection, postoperative therapy is based on the histology of the resected specimen. The disappointing use of nephron-sparing surgery in this study may have been because of the level of experience of the surgeons in this multi-institutional study.</li>

5949</ul>

5950</div>

5951</li>

5952<li>

5953In a retrospective review of 49 patients with Wilms tumor who received preoperative therapy according to the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003804">

5954SIOP-93-01 (NCT00003804)</a>

5955 guidelines, the timing of surgery was determined when there was no longer imaging evidence of tumor regression. The mean treatment duration was 80 days before renal-sparing surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_2.281">

5956281</a>

5957] <div class="pdq-content-list">

5958<ul id="_810">

5959<li>

5960The 5-year EFS rate was 83.4%, and the OS rate was 89.5%.</li>

5961<li>

5962All but one of the patients had renal-sparing surgery in at least one kidney.</li>

5963<li>

5964Despite the good survival, 14% of the patients developed end-stage renal disease.</li>

5965</ul>

5966</div>

5967</li>

5968<li>

5969In a retrospective review from St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, investigators described their experience with preoperative chemotherapy followed by renal-sparing procedures in children with bilateral FH Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.282">

5970282</a>

5971]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5972<ul id="_811">

5973<li>

5974In one series, 39 of 42 patients with bilateral FH Wilms tumor underwent successful bilateral renal-sparing procedures after receiving preoperative chemotherapy. Three patients underwent unilateral nephrectomy with contralateral nephron-sparing surgery. Three patients required early (within 4 months) repeat nephron-sparing surgery for residual tumor. In the long term, seven patients had local tumor recurrence, and three patients had intestinal obstruction.</li>

5975<li>

5976The OS rate was 86% (mean follow-up, 4.1 years). Of the six patients who died, five had diffuse anaplastic histology.</li>

5977<li>

5978All of the patients had an estimated glomerular filtration rate of more than 60 mL/min/1.73m<span class="sup">

59792</span>

5980 at the last follow-up; none of the patients developed end-stage renal disease.</li>

5981<li>

5982The authors concluded that bilateral renal-sparing surgery is almost always feasible and can be done safely with good oncologic outcomes in patients with synchronous, bilateral Wilms tumor. It should be considered even if preoperative imaging studies suggest that the lesions are unresectable. Sparing of renal parenchyma is likely to help preserve renal function in children who are at significant risk of chronic renal insufficiency. Careful long-term follow-up is required to fully assess the potential progression of renal dysfunction.</li>

5983<li>

5984A follow-up review of these patients revealed the following: 8 of 36 patients underwent repeat nephron-sparing surgery, and an additional two patients required a third nephron-sparing surgery. Six of these patients were alive without disease at the 4.5-year follow-up. The two patients who died had blastemal-predominant histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.283">

5985283</a>

5986]</li>

5987</ul>

5988</div>

5989</li>

5990</ol>

5991</div>

5992<p id="_1907" tabindex="-1">

5993For information about recurrent disease, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1966">

5994Treatment and outcomes of recurrent Wilms tumor</a>

5995 section.</p>

5996</section>

5997<section id="_1979">

5998<h5 id="_1979_toc">

5999Treatment of patients with multicentric or bilaterally predisposed unilateral Wilms tumors</h5>

6000<p id="_1980" tabindex="-1">

6001On the basis of an identified subpopulation of patients with Wilms tumor who are at risk for metachronous disease, coupled with an increased risk of end-stage renal disease, the COG conducted the largest prospective study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00945009">

6002AREN0534 [NCT00945009]</a>

6003) of these patients. The goal of this study was to preserve renal tissue while maintaining excellent overall outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

60044</a>

6005,<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

600690</a>

6007]</p>

6008<p id="_1981" tabindex="-1">

6009Patients were identified by the treating institution as having a predisposition syndrome. Induction chemotherapy was determined by the presence of localized or metastatic disease found on imaging (and histology if a biopsy had been performed) at the time of diagnosis. Surgery, including renal-sparing surgery, was based on the radiographic response at 6 or 12 weeks, and additional chemotherapy was determined by histology. Patients with favorable histology and stage III or IV disease or any patient with anaplasia received radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.144">

6010144</a>

6011][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6012Level of evidence C1</a>

6013]</p>

6014<div class="pdq-content-list">

6015<ul id="_1982">

6016<li>

6017Thirty-four patients were enrolled with the following underlying conditions: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (n = 9), hemihypertrophy (n = 9), multicentric tumors (n = 10), WAGR syndrome (n = 2), solitary kidney (n = 2), Denys-Drash syndrome (n = 1), and Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome (n = 1).</li>

6018<li>

6019The 4-year EFS and OS rates were 94% and 100%, respectively, with a median follow-up of 4.49 years. Two patients relapsed (one in the tumor bed and one in the abdomen); none of the deaths occurred during induction.</li>

6020<li>

6021Prenephrectomy chemotherapy facilitated renal preservation in 22 of 34 patients (65%). Eleven partial nephrectomies were performed after two cycles of chemotherapy, and nine partial nephrectomies were performed after four cycles of chemotherapy. Two of the tumors completely resolved after treatment with chemotherapy and required no subsequent surgery.</li>

6022<li>

6023There were 22 patients with a known predisposition syndrome for which routine ultrasonography screening would have been expected. Sixteen of these patients had stage I disease, three had stage II disease, and three had stage III disease. Thirteen of the tumors were detected through routine ultrasonography.</li>

6024<li>

6025These results suggest that a standardized treatment approach that includes preoperative chemotherapy, surgical resection within 6 to 12 weeks, and histology-based postoperative chemotherapy results in excellent EFS, OS, and preservation of renal parenchyma.</li>

6026</ul>

6027</div>

6028</section>

6029<section id="_778">

6030<h5 id="_778_toc">

6031Renal transplant</h5>

6032<p id="_779" tabindex="-1">

6033Renal transplant for children with stage V Wilms tumor is usually delayed until 1 to 2 years have passed without evidence of malignancy because most relapses occur within 2 years of diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.284">

6034284</a>

6035] Similarly, renal transplant for children with Denys-Drash syndrome and Wilms tumor, all of whom require bilateral nephrectomy, is generally delayed 1 to 2 years after completion of initial treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.284">

6036284</a>

6037]</p>

6038</section>

6039<section id="_403">

6040<h5 id="_403_toc">

6041Treatment options under clinical evaluation</h5>

6042<p id="_2023" tabindex="-1">

6043Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

6044NCI website</a>

6045. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

6046ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

6047.</p>

6048<section id="_TrialSearch_403_sid_10">

6049<h6 id="_TrialSearch_403_sid_10_toc">

6050Current Clinical Trials</h6>

6051<p id="_TrialSearch_403_22" tabindex="-1">

6052Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

6053advanced clinical trial search</a>

6054 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

6055General information</a>

6056 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

6057</section>

6058</section>

6059</section>

6060<section id="_1966">

6061<h4 id="_1966_toc">

6062Treatment and outcomes of recurrent Wilms tumor</h4>

6063<p id="_2449" tabindex="-1">

6064 Patients with recurrent Wilms tumor should consider enrolling in available phase I and phase II clinical trials. Other treatment options for recurrent Wilms tumor are discussed below.</p>

6065<p id="_2450" tabindex="-1">

6066Palliative care remains a central focus of management regardless of whether disease-directed therapy is pursued at the time of progression. This ensures that quality of life is maximized while attempting to reduce symptoms and stress related to the terminal illness.</p>

6067<section id="_895">

6068<h5 id="_895_toc">

6069Prognosis, prognostic factors, and risk categories for recurrent Wilms tumor</h5>

6070<p id="_531" tabindex="-1">

6071Approximately 15% of patients with FH Wilms tumor and 50% of patients with anaplastic histology Wilms tumor experience recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_2.175">

6072175</a>

6073] The most common site of relapse is lung, followed by abdomen/flank and liver. Recurrence in the brain (0.5%) or bone is rare in children with Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.285">

6074285</a>

6075,<a href="#cit/section_2.286">

6076286</a>

6077] Historically, the salvage rate for patients with recurrent FH Wilms tumor was 25% to 40%. As a result of modern treatment combinations, the outcome after recurrence has improved to up to 60%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.287">

6078287</a>

6079,<a href="#cit/section_2.288">

6080288</a>

6081] </p>

6082<p id="_2037" tabindex="-1">

6083About 95% of first Wilms tumor recurrences occur within 2 years of initial diagnosis. Relapse more than 5 years after diagnosis is considered a late recurrence and is rare. In the largest retrospective study of more than 1,300 children enrolled in various Wilms tumor trials, the median time to late recurrence after first recurrence was 13 years (range, 5&#8211;17 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.289">

6084289</a>

6085,<a href="#cit/section_2.290">

6086290</a>

6087]</p>

6088<p id="_1049" tabindex="-1">

6089A number of potential prognostic features influencing postrecurrence outcomes have been analyzed, but it is difficult to determine whether these factors are independent of each other. Also, the following prognostic factors appear to be changing as therapy for primary and recurrent Wilms tumor evolves:</p>

6090<div class="pdq-content-list">

6091<ul id="_532">

6092<li>

6093Anaplastic histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.291">

6094291</a>

6095]</li>

6096<li>

6097Advanced tumor stage.[<a href="#cit/section_2.291">

6098291</a>

6099]</li>

6100<li>

6101Sex. Sex was predictive of outcome, with males faring worse than females.[<a href="#cit/section_2.287">

6102287</a>

6103,<a href="#cit/section_2.292">

6104292</a>

6105]</li>

6106</ul>

6107</div>

6108<p id="_533" tabindex="-1">

6109The NWTS-5 trial showed that time to recurrence and site of recurrence are no longer prognostically significant.[<a href="#cit/section_2.287">

6110287</a>

6111,<a href="#cit/section_2.292">

6112292</a>

6113] However, in a SIOP study, patients who experienced a pulmonary relapse within 12 months of diagnosis had a poorer prognosis (5-year OS rate, 47%) than did patients who experienced a pulmonary relapse 12 months or more after diagnosis (5-year OS rate, 75%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.293">

6114293</a>

6115]</p>

6116<p id="_534" tabindex="-1">

6117On the basis of these results, the following three risk categories have been identified:</p>

6118<div class="pdq-content-list">

6119<ul id="_535">

6120<li>

6121<strong>

6122Standard risk:</strong>

6123 Patients with FH Wilms tumor who relapse after therapy with only vincristine and/or dactinomycin. These patients account for approximately 30% of recurrences and are expected to have EFS rates of 70% to 80%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.288">

6124288</a>

6125] </li>

6126<li>

6127<strong>

6128High risk:</strong>

6129 Patients with FH Wilms tumor who relapse after therapy with three or more agents. These patients account for 45% to 50% of children with Wilms tumor who relapse and have survival rates in the 40% to 50% range.[<a href="#cit/section_2.288">

6130288</a>

6131]</li>

6132<li>

6133<strong>

6134Very high risk:</strong>

6135 Patients with recurrent anaplastic or blastemal-predominant Wilms tumor. These patients account for 10% to 15% of all Wilms tumor relapses and are expected to have survival rates in the 10% range.[<a href="#cit/section_2.178">

6136178</a>

6137,<a href="#cit/section_2.288">

6138288</a>

6139]</li>

6140</ul>

6141</div>

6142</section>

6143<section id="_593">

6144<h5 id="_593_toc">

6145Treatment of standard-risk relapsed Wilms tumor</h5>

6146<p id="_594" tabindex="-1">

6147In children who had small stage I Wilms tumor and were treated with surgery alone, the EFS rate was 84%. All but one child who relapsed was salvaged with treatment tailored to the site of recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_2.179">

6148179</a>

6149,<a href="#cit/section_2.292">

6150292</a>

6151]</p>

6152<p id="_927" tabindex="-1">

6153Successful retreatment can be accomplished for Wilms tumor patients whose initial therapy consisted of immediate nephrectomy followed by chemotherapy with vincristine and dactinomycin and who relapse.</p>

6154<p id="_865" tabindex="-1">

6155Treatment options for standard-risk relapsed Wilms tumor include the following:</p>

6156<div class="pdq-content-list">

6157<ol id="_866">

6158<li>

6159<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1064">

6160Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy</a>

6161.</li>

6162</ol>

6163</div>

6164<section id="_1064">

6165<h6 id="_1064_toc">

6166Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy</h6>

6167<p id="_867" tabindex="-1">

6168Evidence (surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy):</p>

6169<div class="pdq-content-list">

6170<ol id="_868">

6171<li>

6172Fifty-eight patients were treated on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

6173NWTS-5</a>

6174 relapse protocol with surgical excision when feasible, radiation therapy, and courses of vincristine, doxorubicin, and cyclophosphamide alternating with etoposide and cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_2.292">

6175292</a>

6176] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6177<ul id="_869">

6178<li>

6179The 4-year EFS rate after relapse was 71%, and the OS rate was 82%. </li>

6180<li>

6181For patients whose site of relapse was only the lungs, the 4-year EFS rate was 68%, and the OS rate was 81%.</li>

6182</ul>

6183</div>

6184</li>

6185<li>

6186The SIOP Renal Tumor Study Group (SIOP-RTSG) analyzed the outcomes of low- and intermediate-risk patients (n = 109) who relapsed after treatment with vincristine and dactinomycin for primary Wilms tumor from their SIOP 93-01 and SIOP 2001 studies.[<a href="#cit/section_2.294">

6187294</a>

6188][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6189Level of evidence: C1</a>

6190]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6191<ul id="_2415">

6192<li>

6193The postrelapse 5-year EFS rate was 72.3%, and the OS rate was 79.3%.</li>

6194<li>

6195Patients treated with vincristine, dactinomycin, and doxorubicin (VAD) did not fare worse than patients treated with more intensive therapies (such as cyclophosphamide, carboplatin, etoposide, and doxorubicin or ifosfamide, carboplatin, and etoposide [ICE] backbones; hazard ratio for EFS, 0.611; hazard ratio for OS, 0.438).</li>

6196<li>

6197There was no survival difference between patients treated with VAD compared with ICE-based regimens. </li>

6198<li>

6199The type of alkylating agent (ifosfamide or cyclophosphamide) used in more intensive treatment regimens did not affect survival rates.</li>

6200<li>

6201Incorporation of high-dose hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) to consolidate relapse treatment did not improve the outcome for standard-risk relapse patients.</li>

6202<li>

6203Future studies may be able to identify patients who may benefit from VAD treatment rather than more intensive treatment with combination chemotherapy including cyclophosphamide, carboplatin, etoposide, and doxorubicin.</li>

6204</ul>

6205</div>

6206</li>

6207</ol>

6208</div>

6209</section>

6210</section>

6211<section id="_595">

6212<h5 id="_595_toc">

6213Treatment of high-risk and very high-risk relapsed Wilms tumor</h5>

6214<p id="_870" tabindex="-1">

6215Treatment options for high-risk and very high-risk relapsed Wilms tumor include the following:</p>

6216<div class="pdq-content-list">

6217<ol id="_871">

6218<li>

6219<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_872">

6220Chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiation therapy</a>

6221.</li>

6222<li>

6223<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_876">

6224HSCT</a>

6225.</li>

6226</ol>

6227</div>

6228<section id="_872">

6229<h6 id="_872_toc">

6230Chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiation therapy</h6>

6231<p id="_873" tabindex="-1">

6232Evidence (chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiation therapy):</p>

6233<div class="pdq-content-list">

6234<ol id="_874">

6235<li>

6236Approximately 50% of unilateral Wilms tumor patients who relapse or progress after initial treatment with vincristine, dactinomycin, and doxorubicin and radiation therapy can be successfully re-treated. Sixty patients with unilateral Wilms tumor were treated on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

6237NWTS-5</a>

6238 relapse protocol with alternating courses of cyclophosphamide/etoposide and carboplatin/etoposide, surgery, and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.287">

6239287</a>

6240][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6241Level of evidence B4</a>

6242] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6243<ul id="_875">

6244<li>

6245 The 4-year EFS rate for patients with high-risk Wilms tumor was 42%, and the OS rate was 48%.</li>

6246<li>

6247High-risk patients who relapsed in the lungs only had a 4-year EFS rate of 49% and an OS rate of 53%.</li>

6248</ul>

6249</div>

6250</li>

6251</ol>

6252</div>

6253<p id="_1050" tabindex="-1">

6254Patients with stage II, stage III, and stage IV anaplastic tumors at diagnosis have a very poor prognosis upon recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_2.178">

6255178</a>

6256] The

6257combination of ifosfamide, etoposide, and carboplatin demonstrated activity

6258in this group of patients, but significant hematologic toxic effects have been

6259observed.[<a href="#cit/section_2.295">

6260295</a>

6261]</p>

6262</section>

6263<section id="_876">

6264<h6 id="_876_toc">

6265HSCT</h6>

6266<p id="_1051" tabindex="-1">

6267High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous HSCT has been used for recurrent high-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.296">

6268296</a>

6269,<a href="#cit/section_2.297">

6270297</a>

6271]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.298">

6272298</a>

6273,<a href="#cit/section_2.299">

6274299</a>

6275][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6276Level of evidence C1</a>

6277]</p>

6278<p id="_877" tabindex="-1">

6279Evidence (HSCT):</p>

6280<div class="pdq-content-list">

6281<ol id="_878">

6282<li>

6283Investigators used the European Blood and Marrow Transplantation Registry to examine the outcomes of children with Wilms tumor (n = 69) who received high-dose chemotherapy with autologous HSCT as consolidation during first or second remission. Different high-dose chemotherapy regimens were used, containing either melphalan (n = 34) or thiotepa (n = 14).[<a href="#cit/section_2.300">

6284300</a>

6285][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6286Level of evidence C1</a>

6287]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6288<ul id="_2053">

6289<li>

6290The 5-year OS and EFS probabilities were 0.67 (&#177; 0.06) and 0.63 (&#177; 0.06), respectively (median observation time, 7.8 years).</li>

6291<li>

6292Children who underwent transplantation in first remission had 5-year EFS and OS probabilities of 0.69 and 0.72, respectively.</li>

6293<li>

6294The use of melphalan alone for high-dose chemotherapy led to noninferior survival rates, compared with other drugs or drug combinations, and to better engraftment, compared with thiotepa-containing regimens.</li>

6295</ul>

6296</div>

6297</li>

6298<li>

6299Similar outcome results were reported in a series of 54 patients with Wilms tumor who received high-dose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell rescue (first-line therapy, n = 13; recurrence therapy, n = 41).[<a href="#cit/section_2.299">

6300299</a>

6301][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6302Level of evidence C1</a>

6303]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6304<ul id="_2393">

6305<li>

6306For patients treated at the time of recurrence, the 5-year EFS and OS rates were 57% and 69%, respectively (median follow-up, 7 years).</li>

6307</ul>

6308</div>

6309</li>

6310<li>

6311The outcomes of 253 patients with relapsed Wilms tumor who received high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous HSCT between 1990 and 2013 were reported to and reviewed by the Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplantation Research.[<a href="#cit/section_2.301">

6312301</a>

6313]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6314<ul id="_1899">

6315<li>

6316The 5-year estimate for EFS was 36%, and the 5-year estimate for OS was 45%.</li>

6317<li>

6318Relapse of primary disease was the cause of death in 81% of the population.</li>

6319</ul>

6320</div>

6321</li>

6322</ol>

6323</div>

6324<p id="_1052" tabindex="-1">

6325 No randomized trials comparing chemotherapy and transplant have been reported, and case series suffer from selection bias.</p>

6326<p id="_880" tabindex="-1">

6327 Patients in whom such salvage

6328attempts fail should be offered treatment on available phase I or phase II

6329clinical trials.</p>

6330</section>

6331</section>

6332<section id="_1824">

6333<h5 id="_1824_toc">

6334Treatment options under clinical evaluation for recurrent Wilms tumor</h5>

6335<p id="_1835" tabindex="-1">

6336Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

6337NCI website</a>

6338. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

6339ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

6340.</p>

6341<p id="_1825" tabindex="-1">

6342The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

6343<div class="pdq-content-list">

6344<ul id="_1826">

6345<li>

6346<strong>

6347<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT04322318">

6348AREN1921 (NCT04322318)</a>

6349</strong>

6350 (A Study of Combination Chemotherapy for Patients With Newly Diagnosed Diffuse Anaplastic Wilms Tumor and Relapsed Favorable-Histology [FH] Wilms Tumor)<strong>

6351:</strong>

6352 Patients with standard-risk relapsed FH Wilms tumor (pretreated with two drugs) will receive chemotherapy consisting of vincristine/doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide alternating with cyclophosphamide/carboplatin/etoposide alternating with vincristine/irinotecan. Patients with high-risk relapsed FH Wilms tumor (pretreated with three drugs) and very high-risk relapsed FH Wilms tumor (pretreated with &#8805; four drugs) will be treated with cyclophosphamide and topotecan added to a backbone of ifosfamide, carboplatin, and etoposide.</li>

6353<li>

6354<strong>

6355<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03155620">

6356APEC1621 (NCT03155620)</a>

6357</strong>

6358 (Pediatric MATCH: Targeted Therapy Directed by Genetic Testing in Treating Pediatric Patients with Relapsed or Refractory Advanced Solid Tumors, Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas, or Histiocytic Disorders)<strong>

6359:</strong>

6360 NCI-COG Pediatric Molecular Analysis for Therapeutic Choice (MATCH), referred to as Pediatric MATCH, will match targeted agents with specific molecular changes identified in a patient's tumor (refractory or recurrent). Children and adolescents aged 1 to 21 years are eligible for the trial.<p id="_2397" tabindex="-1">

6361Patients with tumors that have molecular variants addressed by open treatment arms in the trial may enroll in treatment on Pediatric MATCH. Additional information can be obtained on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match">

6362NCI website</a>

6363 and <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620">

6364ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

6365.</p>

6366

6367</li>

6368</ul>

6369</div>

6370</section>

6371</section>

6372<section id="_1072">

6373<h4 id="_1072_toc">

6374Follow-up after treatment</h4>

6375<p id="_1073" tabindex="-1">

6376For patients who have completed therapy for Wilms tumor and exhibit features consistent with genetic predisposition, such as bilateral Wilms tumor, screening involves renal ultrasonography examination every 3 months for metachronous tumors during the risk period for that particular syndrome (5 years for <em class="gene-name">

6377WT1</em>

6378-related syndromes; 8 years for Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome).</p>

6379</section>

6380<section id="_760">

6381<h4 id="_760_toc">

6382Late effects after Wilms tumor therapy</h4>

6383<p id="_761" tabindex="-1">

6384Children treated for Wilms tumor are

6385at increased risk of developing the following:</p>

6386<div class="pdq-content-list">

6387<ul id="_1028">

6388<li>

6389<strong>

6390Premature mortality after Wilms tumor diagnosis. </strong>

6391 Long-term morbidity and mortality among unilateral, nonsyndromic Wilms tumor survivors were evaluated in the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS). Among 2,008 survivors, 142 deaths occurred (standardized mortality ratio [SMR], 2.9 [95% CI, 2.5&#8211;3.5]; 35-year cumulative incidence of death, 7.8% [95% CI, 6.3%&#8211;9.2%]). The most frequent causes of death were subsequent malignant neoplasms (SMNs) (n = 42), Wilms tumor relapse (n = 30), and cardiac related (n = 9). Survivors who were treated with vincristine and dactinomycin (VA) alone had comparable risk for all-cause mortality (SMR,1.0) and health-related late mortality (SMR, 1.5) relative to the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.302">

6392302</a>

6393]</li>

6394<li>

6395<strong>

6396Chronic health conditions.</strong>

6397 Findings from the same CCSS study are as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_2.302">

6398302</a>

6399]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6400<ul id="_2491">

6401<li>

6402Of unilateral Wilms tumor survivors (n = 2,008), the 35-year cumulative incidence of any grades 3 to 5 chronic health condition was 34.1% among Wilms tumor survivors and 14.8% among siblings.</li>

6403<li>

6404Survivors treated with VA alone had a modestly increased risk of developing grades 3 to 5 chronic health conditions compared with siblings (RR, 1.5).</li>

6405<li>

6406Risks of grades 3 to 5 chronic health conditions, including intestinal obstruction (8.1%), kidney failure (2.4%), premature ovarian insufficiency (7.3%) and heart failure (4.0%), increased by treatment intensity in a dose-dependent manner and by exposure to doxorubicin and/or radiation therapy. This risk was most pronounced among survivors with high-risk disease, including those with early relapse (&lt;5 years). </li>

6407<li>

6408Compared with siblings, survivors treated with VA showed a higher risk of intestinal obstruction (RR, 9.4) and kidney failure (RR, 11.9) but the magnitude of the risk was lower than that for more intensive treatment groups. </li>

6409<li>

6410Both whole-lung and whole-abdomen radiation therapy were associated with increased risks of SMNs, heart failure, and intestinal obstruction, and the magnitude of risk increased with rising doses. </li>

6411<li>

6412Whole-abdomen or flank radiation therapy higher than 20 Gy was associated with an increased risk of intestinal obstruction compared with no radiation therapy, whereas radiation therapy doses of 20 Gy or less were not associated with any chronic health condition.</li>

6413</ul>

6414</div>

6415</li>

6416<li>

6417<strong>

6418SMNs.</strong>

6419[<a href="#cit/section_2.303">

6420303</a>

6421,<a href="#cit/section_2.304">

6422304</a>

6423] In the CCSS study of Wilms tumor survivors (n = 2,008), 82 developed SMNs (standardized incidence ratio [SIR], 4.1), representing a cumulative incidence rate of 6.1%. Breast (SIR, 6.9), thyroid (SIR, 4.7) and intestinal/colorectal (SIR, 12.0) were the most frequently reported cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.302">

6424302</a>

6425] The cumulative incidence of invasive breast cancer in Wilms tumor survivors who had received pulmonary radiation for metastatic Wilms tumor is nearly 15% by age 40 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.305">

6426305</a>

6427]</li>

6428<li>

6429<strong>

6430Congestive heart failure.</strong>

6431 The risk of congestive heart failure is influenced by dose of doxorubicin received, radiation to the heart, and female sex.[<a href="#cit/section_2.306">

6432306</a>

6433] CCSS investigators reported that cumulative doxorubicin doses of 250 mg/m<span class="sup">

64342</span>

6435 or higher were associated with a nearly 5-fold rate of development of heart failure, compared with no doxorubicin exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.302">

6436302</a>

6437]</li>

6438<li>

6439<strong>

6440Infertility for patients who received whole-abdomen irradiation and/or cyclophosphamide.</strong>

6441[<a href="#cit/section_2.307">

6442307</a>

6443,<a href="#cit/section_2.308">

6444308</a>

6445] The 35-year cumulative incidence rate of premature ovarian insufficiency was 7.3%. Whole-abdomen radiation therapy was associated with an increased risk of premature ovarian insufficiency, with a greater risk with increasing dose (&#8804;20 Gy: RR, 13.1; &gt;20 Gy: RR, 36.5).[<a href="#cit/section_2.302">

6446302</a>

6447] Female survivors of Wilms tumor diagnosed before age 40 years from a St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study experienced increased premature ovarian insufficiency compared with controls (9.3% vs. 0.6%; <em>

6448P</em>

6449 &lt; .01), likely because of abdominal irradiation that exposed the ovaries. None of the females exposed to hemiabdominal radiation therapy experienced premature ovarian insufficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_2.304">

6450304</a>

6451] </li>

6452<li>

6453<strong>

6454Complications of pregnancy.</strong>

6455[<a href="#cit/section_2.309">

6456309</a>

6457] </li>

6458<li>

6459<strong>

6460Late kidney failure.</strong>

6461 Based on the CCSS study, the cumulative incidence of late kidney failure among survivors was 2.4% (approximately a 10-fold increased rate relative to siblings). No single chemotherapy or radiation therapy&#8211;related exposure was associated with kidney failure, which suggests that nephrectomy may be the primary risk factor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.302">

6462302</a>

6463] Rates of late kidney failure increase with advancing age. This finding highlights the importance of long-term monitoring of kidney function in these patients, particularly when the patients have other comorbidities. The cumulative incidence of end-stage renal disease caused by chronic renal failure at 20 years from diagnosis of Wilms tumor is 3.1% for patients with bilateral Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_2.206">

6464206</a>

6465]</li>

6466<li>

6467<strong>

6468Neurocognitive impairment.</strong>

6469 Among 264 long-term Wilms tumor survivors participating in a St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study who completed neurocognitive testing, 19.7% had grades 2 to 3 executive function impairment, compared with 12% of controls (<em>

6470P</em>

6471 &lt; .01). In survivors, processing speed (19.7% vs. 8.4%) and memory (20.9% vs. 9.9%) showed a higher prevalence of moderate to severe impairments, compared with controls (<em>

6472P</em>

6473 &lt; .01). Only impairments in processing speed were associated with the presence of grades 2 to 4 cardiovascular disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.304">

6474304</a>

6475]</li>

6476<li>

6477<strong>

6478Physical performance.</strong>

6479 In the CCSS study, survivors were more likely to report poor physical functioning (OR, 2.9) than siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_2.302">

6480302</a>

6481] In a St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study, 270 long-term Wilms tumor survivors completed function testing and were observed to have excess impairments in aerobic function, mobility, strength, endurance and flexibility, compared with controls. There were no clear associations between these outcomes and treatment exposures.[<a href="#cit/section_2.304">

6482304</a>

6483]</li>

6484</ul>

6485</div>

6486<p id="_67" tabindex="-1">

6487Late renal effects in patients with Wilms and underlying genetic abnormalities include the following:</p>

6488<div class="pdq-content-list">

6489<ul id="_68">

6490<li>

6491Children with WAGR syndrome or other germline <em class="gene-name">

6492WT1</em>

6493 mutations are monitored throughout their lives because they are at increased risk of

6494developing hypertension, nephropathy, and renal failure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.206">

6495206</a>

6496]</li>

6497<li>

6498Patients with

6499Wilms tumor and aniridia without genitourinary abnormalities are at lower

6500risk but are monitored for nephropathy or renal failure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.310">

6501310</a>

6502]</li>

6503<li>

6504Children with Wilms tumor and any genitourinary anomalies are also at increased risk of late renal failure and are monitored. Features associated with germline <em class="gene-name">

6505WT1</em>

6506 mutations that increase the risk of developing renal failure include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.206">

6507206</a>

6508]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6509<ul id="_69">

6510<li>

6511 Stromal predominant histology.</li>

6512<li>

6513Bilateral disease.</li>

6514<li>

6515Intralobar nephrogenic rests.</li>

6516<li>

6517Wilms tumor diagnosed before age 2 years.</li>

6518</ul>

6519</div>

6520</li>

6521</ul>

6522</div>

6523<p id="_1030" tabindex="-1">

6524For a full discussion of the late effects of cancer treatment in children and adolescents, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq">

6525 Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

6526.</p>

6527</section>

6528</section>

6590[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6591</li>

6592<li id="section_2.16">

6593Breslow NE, Norris R, Norkool PA, et al.: Characteristics and outcomes of children with the Wilms tumor-Aniridia syndrome: a report from the National Wilms Tumor Study Group. J Clin Oncol 21 (24): 4579-85, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14673045&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14673045&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6594[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6596<li id="section_2.17">

7715Pein F, Michon J, Valteau-Couanet D, et al.: High-dose melphalan, etoposide, and carboplatin followed by autologous stem-cell rescue in pediatric high-risk recurrent Wilms' tumor: a French Society of Pediatric Oncology study. J Clin Oncol 16 (10): 3295-301, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9779704&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9779704&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7716[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7717</li>

7718<li id="section_2.298">

7719Rossoff J, Tse WT, Duerst RE, et al.: High-dose chemotherapy and autologous hematopoietic stem-cell rescue for treatment of relapsed and refractory Wilms tumor: Re-evaluating outcomes. Pediatr Hematol Oncol 35 (5-6): 316-321, 2018 Aug - Sep.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30681039&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30681039&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7720[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7721</li>

7722<li id="section_2.299">

7723Delafoy M, Verschuur A, Scheleirmacher G, et al.: High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell rescue in Wilms tumors: French report on toxicity and efficacy. Pediatr Blood Cancer 69 (3): e29431, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34811873&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34811873&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7724[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7725</li>

7726<li id="section_2.300">

7727Spreafico F, Dalissier A, P&#246;tschger U, et al.: High dose chemotherapy and autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation for Wilms tumor: a study of the European Society for Blood and Marrow Transplantation. Bone Marrow Transplant 55 (2): 376-383, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31534191&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31534191&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7728[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7729</li>

7730<li id="section_2.301">

7731Malogolowkin MH, Hemmer MT, Le-Rademacher J, et al.: Outcomes following autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplant for patients with relapsed Wilms' tumor: a CIBMTR retrospective analysis. Bone Marrow Transplant 52 (11): 1549-1555, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28869618&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28869618&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7732[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7733</li>

7734<li id="section_2.302">

7735Weil BR, Murphy AJ, Liu Q, et al.: Late Health Outcomes Among Survivors of Wilms Tumor Diagnosed Over Three Decades: A Report From the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. J Clin Oncol 41 (14): 2638-2650, 2023.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=36693221&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=36693221&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7736[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7737</li>

7738<li id="section_2.303">

7739Wong KF, Reulen RC, Winter DL, et al.: Risk of Adverse Health and Social Outcomes Up to 50 Years After Wilms Tumor: The British Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. J Clin Oncol 34 (15): 1772-9, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27022116&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27022116&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7740[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7741</li>

7742<li id="section_2.304">

7743Foster KL, Salehabadi SM, Green DM, et al.: Clinical Assessment of Late Health Outcomes in Survivors of Wilms Tumor. Pediatrics 150 (5): , 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=36300342&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=36300342&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7744[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7745</li>

7746<li id="section_2.305">

7747Lange JM, Takashima JR, Peterson SM, et al.: Breast cancer in female survivors of Wilms tumor: a report from the national Wilms tumor late effects study. Cancer 120 (23): 3722-30, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25348097&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25348097&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7748[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7749</li>

7750<li id="section_2.306">

7751Green DM, Grigoriev YA, Nan B, et al.: Congestive heart failure after treatment for Wilms' tumor: a report from the National Wilms' Tumor Study group. J Clin Oncol 19 (7): 1926-34, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11283124&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11283124&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7752[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7753</li>

7754<li id="section_2.307">

7755Practice Committee of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine. Electronic address: asrm@asrm.org: Fertility preservation in patients undergoing gonadotoxic therapy or gonadectomy: a committee opinion. Fertil Steril 112 (6): 1022-1033, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31843073&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31843073&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7756[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7757</li>

Lancet Oncol 15 (11): 1215-23, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25239573&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25239573&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7761</li>

J Clin Oncol 28 (17): 2824-30, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20458053&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20458053&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7764[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7765</li>

7767Breslow NE, Takashima JR, Ritchey ML, et al.: Renal failure in the Denys-Drash and Wilms' tumor-aniridia syndromes. Cancer Res 60 (15): 4030-2, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10945603&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10945603&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7768[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7769</li>

7770</ol>

7771</div>

7772

7773 </section>

7774

7775

7776

7777 <section id="_432">

7778

7779 <h2>

7780Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC)</h2>

7781

7782 <div id="_section_432" class="pdq-sections">

7783<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

7784<h6>

7785In This Section</h6>

7786<ul>

7787<li>

7788<a href="#_742_toc">

7789Incidence of RCC</a>

7790</li>

7791<li>

7792<a href="#_744_toc">

7793Conditions Associated With RCC</a>

7794</li>

7795<li>

7796<a href="#_746_toc">

7797Genetic Testing for Children and Adolescents With RCC</a>

7798</li>

7799<li>

7800<a href="#_1204_toc">

7801Genomics of RCC<ul>

7802<li>

7803<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777844_13_toc">

7805</li>

7806</ul>

7807</a>

7808</li>

7809<li>

7810<a href="#_748_toc">

7811Histology of RCC</a>

7812</li>

7813<li>

7814<a href="#_753_toc">

7816</li>

7817<li>

7820</li>

7821<li>

7822<a href="#_257_toc">

7823Treatment of RCC<ul>

7824<li>

7825<a href="#_1054_toc">

7826Radical nephrectomy with lymph node sampling</a>

7827</li>

7828<li>

7829<a href="#_1056_toc">

7830Renal-sparing surgery with lymph node sampling</a>

7831</li>

7832<li>

7833<a href="#_1058_toc">
