7835</li>

7836</ul>

7837</a>

7838</li>

7839<li>

7841Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for RCC</a>

7842</li>

7845Current Clinical Trials</a>

7846</li>

7847</ul>

7848</nav>

7849<section id="_742">

7850<h3 id="_742_toc">

7851Incidence of RCC</h3>

7852<p id="_743" tabindex="-1">

7853Malignant epithelial tumors arising in the kidneys of children account for more than 5% of new pediatric renal tumors; therefore, they are more common than clear cell sarcoma of the kidney or rhabdoid tumors of the kidney. The annual incidence rate is approximately 4 cases per 1 million children, compared with an incidence of Wilms tumor of the kidney that is at least 29-fold higher.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

78541</a>

7855] </p>

7856<p id="_1283" tabindex="-1">

7857Renal cell carcinoma (RCC), the most common primary malignancy of the kidney in adults, is rare in children younger than 15 years. In the older age group of adolescents (aged 15&#8211;19 years), approximately two-thirds of renal malignancies are RCC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

78582</a>

7859] In one study, children and adolescents with RCC (n = 515) presented with more advanced disease than those aged 21 to 30 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

78601</a>

7861]</p>

7862</section>

7863<section id="_744">

7864<h3 id="_744_toc">

7865Conditions Associated With RCC</h3>

7866<p id="_745" tabindex="-1">

7867Conditions associated with RCC include the following: </p>

7868<div class="pdq-content-list">

7869<ul id="_600">

7870<li>

7871<strong>

7872von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease.</strong>

7873 VHL disease is an autosomal dominant condition in which blood vessels in the retina and cerebellum grow excessively.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

78743</a>

7875] The gene for VHL disease is located on chromosome 3p26 and is a tumor-suppressor gene, which is either mutated or deleted in patients with the syndrome. <p id="_641" tabindex="-1">

7876Testing for the <em class="gene-name">

7877VHL</em>

7878 gene is available.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

78794</a>

7880] Annual screening with abdominal ultrasonography or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is recommended, beginning at age 8 to 11 years. Annual screening is used to detect clear cell renal carcinoma in these individuals when the lesions are smaller than 3 cm, and thus, renal-sparing surgery can be performed.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

78815</a>

7882]</p>

7883<p id="_1113" tabindex="-1">

7884For more information, see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/renal-cell-carcinoma-genetics/vhl-syndrome">

7885Von Hippel-Lindau Disease</a>

7886.</p>

7887</li>

7888<li>

7889<strong>

7890Tuberous sclerosis.</strong>

7891 In tuberous sclerosis, the renal lesions may actually be epithelioid angiomyolipoma (also called perivascular epithelioid cell tumor or PEComa), which is associated with aggressive or malignant behavior and expresses melanocyte and smooth muscle markers.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

78926</a>

7893,<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

78947</a>

7895]</li>

7896<li>

7897<strong>

7898Familial RCC.</strong>

7899 Familial RCC has been associated with an inherited chromosome translocation involving chromosome 3.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

79008</a>

7901] A high incidence of chromosome 3 abnormalities has also been demonstrated in nonfamilial renal tumors.<p id="_645" tabindex="-1">

7902<em class="gene-name">

7903SDHB</em>

7904, <em class="gene-name">

7905SDHC</em>

7906, and <em class="gene-name">

7907SDHD</em>

7908 are Krebs cycle enzyme genes that have been associated with the development of familial RCC occurring with pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma. Germline mutations in a subunit of the gene have been reported in individuals with renal cancer and no history of pheochromocytoma.[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

79099</a>

7910,<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

791110</a>

7912]</p>

7913</li>

7914<li>

7915<strong>

7916Renal medullary carcinoma.</strong>

7917 A rare subtype of RCC, renal medullary carcinoma may be associated with sickle cell hemoglobinopathy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

791811</a>

7919]

7920 Renal medullary carcinomas are highly aggressive malignancies characterized clinically by an advanced stage at the time of detection, with widespread metastases and lack of response to chemotherapy

7921and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

792212</a>

7923,<a href="#cit/section_3.13">

792413</a>

7925][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7926Level of evidence C1</a>

7927] Survival is poor and ranges from 2 weeks to 15 months, with a mean survival of 4 months.[<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

792811</a>

7929,<a href="#cit/section_3.13">

793013</a>

7931-<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

793216</a>

7933] </li>

7934<li>

7935<strong>

7936Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC).</strong>

7937 This is an autosomal dominant syndrome caused by heterozygous pathogenic germline variants in the <em class="gene-name">

7938FH</em>

7939 gene (located on chromosome region 1q42.1).[<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

794017</a>

7941,<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

794218</a>

7943] It is characterized by cutaneous and uterine leiomyomas and an increased risk of developing RCC, which is usually an adult-onset disease (median age of onset, 40&#8211;41 years). Twelve RCCs have been reported in <em class="gene-name">

7944FH</em>

7945 mutation carriers younger than 20 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

794619</a>

7947][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7948Level of evidence C1</a>

7949] The absolute risk of developing an RCC is estimated to be 10% to 15%.[<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

795020</a>

7951,<a href="#cit/section_3.21">

795221</a>

7953] HLRCC-related RCC tends to be aggressive and can metastasize even when the primary tumor is small.[<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

795417</a>

7955,<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

795622</a>

7957,<a href="#cit/section_3.23">

795823</a>

7959] Histologically, papillary type 2 RCC or a complex tumor architecture with multiple histological patterns are suggestive of HLRCC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

796019</a>

7961][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7962Level of evidence C1</a>

7963] Genetic testing for <em class="gene-name">

7964FH</em>

7965 mutations and renal MRI surveillance, from the age of 8 to 10 years and onwards, is advised for family members of individuals with HLRCC. If renal cysts are detected, closer monitoring may be indicated.[<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

796620</a>

7967]; [<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

796819</a>

7969][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7970Level of evidence C1</a>

7971]</li>

7972<li>

7973<strong>

7974Previous treatment for childhood cancer.</strong>

7975 Survivors of childhood cancer who were treated with radiation and/or chemotherapy are at a higher risk of developing renal cancers than are the general population. Highest risk has been observed among neuroblastoma survivors who received renal-directed radiation therapy of 5 Gy or more or platinum-based chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

797624</a>

7977] Renal cancers have also been reported after treatment for rhabdomyosarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, primitive neuroectodermal tumors (PNET), and Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_3.25">

797825</a>

7979-<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

798030</a>

7981] For more information, see the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_116">

7982Subsequent Neoplasms</a>

7983 section in Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer.</li>

7984</ul>

7985</div>

7986</section>

7987<section id="_746">

7988<h3 id="_746_toc">

7989Genetic Testing for Children and Adolescents With RCC</h3>

7990<p id="_747" tabindex="-1">

7991Indications for germline genetic testing of children and adolescents with RCC to check for a related syndrome are described in <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_642">

7992Table 8</a>

7993. For more information, see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/renal-cell-carcinoma-genetics">

7994Genetics of Renal Cell Carcinoma</a>

7995.</p>

7996<table id="_642" class="table-default expandable-container">

7997<caption>

7998Table 8. Indications for Germline Genetic Analysis (Screening) of Children and Adolescents with RCC<span class="sup">

7999a</span>

8000</caption>

8001<colgroup>

8002<col width="25.00%">

8003<col width="25.00%">

8004<col width="25.00%">

8005<col width="25.00%">

8006</colgroup>

8007<THead>

8008<tr>

8009<th>

8010 Indication for Testing</th>

8011<th>

8012Tumor Histology</th>

8013<th>

8014Gene Test</th>

8015<th>

8016Related Syndrome</th>

8017</tr>

8018</THead>

8019<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

8020<tr>

8021<td colspan="4">

8022RCC = renal cell carcinoma; VHL = von Hippel-Lindau.</td>

8023</tr>

8024<tr>

8025<td colspan="4">

8026<span class="sup">

8027a</span>

8028Adapted from Linehan et al.[<a href="#cit/section_3.31">

802931</a>

8030]</td>

8031</tr>

8032</TFoot>

8033<tbody>

8034<tr>

8035<td>

8037<td>

8042 gene</td>

8077BHD</em>

8089FH</em>

8093</tr>

8097<td>

8098Clear cell or chromophobe</td>

8099<td>

8100<em class="gene-name">

8101SDHB</em>

8102 gene, <em class="gene-name">

8103SDHC</em>

8104 gene, <em class="gene-name">

8105SDHD</em>

8106 gene</td>

8107<td>

8108Hereditary paraganglioma/pheochromocytoma syndrome</td>

8109</tr>

8110</tbody>

8111</table>

8112</section>

8113<section id="_1204">

8114<h3 id="_1204_toc">

8115Genomics of RCC</h3>

8116<section id="_sm_CDR0000777844_13">

8117<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777844_13_toc">

8118Molecular features of renal cell carcinoma</h4>

8119<p id="_sm_CDR0000777844_15" tabindex="-1">

8120Translocation-positive carcinomas of the kidney are recognized as a distinct form of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and may be the most common form of RCC in children, accounting for 40% to 50% of pediatric RCC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

812132</a>

8122]; [<a href="#cit/section_3.33">

812333</a>

8124][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8125Level of evidence C1</a>

8126] In a Children's Oncology Group (COG) prospective clinical trial of 120 childhood and adolescent patients with RCC, nearly one-half of patients had translocation-positive RCC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.34">

812734</a>

8128,<a href="#cit/section_3.35">

812935</a>

8130] These carcinomas are characterized by translocations involving the<em class="gene-name">

8131 TFE3</em>

8132 gene located on Xp11.2. The <em class="gene-name">

8133TFE3</em>

8134 gene may partner with one of the following genes:</p>

8135<div class="pdq-content-list">

8136<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777844_16">

8137<li>

8138<em class="gene-name">

8139ASPSCR</em>

8140 in t(X;17)(p11.2;q25).</li>

8141<li>

8142<em class="gene-name">

8143PRCC</em>

8144 in t(X;1)(p11.2;q21).</li>

8145<li>

8146<em class="gene-name">

8147SFPQ</em>

8148 in t(X;1)(p11.2;p34).</li>

8149<li>

8150<em class="gene-name">

8151NONO</em>

8152 in inv(X;p11.2;q12).</li>

8153<li>

8154<em class="gene-name">

8155CLTC</em>

8156 in t(X;17)(p11;q23).</li>

8157<li>

8158<em class="gene-name">

8159VCP</em>

8160 in t(x;9)(p11.23;p13.3).[<a href="#cit/section_3.36">

816136</a>

8162]</li>

8163</ul>

8164</div>

8165<p id="_sm_CDR0000777844_27" tabindex="-1">

8166In a single-institution investigation, molecular data from 22 patients with translocation-positive RCCs were pooled with previously published data. Investigators found that certain copy-number variations were associated with disease aggressiveness in patients with translocation-positive RCCs. Tumors bearing 9p loss, 17q gain, or a genetically high burden of copy-number variations were associated with poor survival in these patients. Three pediatric patients who had an indolent disease course were included in the study and were found to have lower copy-number burdens, which supports the less-aggressive disease course in these patients, as compared with adult patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.37">

816737</a>

8168][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8169Level of evidence C1</a>

8170]</p>

8171<p id="_sm_CDR0000777844_17" tabindex="-1">

8172Another less-common translocation subtype, t(6;11)(p21;q12), involving a <em class="gene-name">

8173TFEB</em>

8174 gene fusion, induces overexpression of TFEB. The translocations involving <em class="gene-name">

8175TFE3</em>

8176 and <em class="gene-name">

8177TFEB</em>

8178 induce overexpression of these proteins, which can be identified by immunohistochemistry.[<a href="#cit/section_3.38">

817938</a>

8180]</p>

8181<p id="_sm_CDR0000777844_18" tabindex="-1">

8182Previous exposure to chemotherapy is the only known risk factor for the development of Xp11 translocation RCCs. In one study, the postchemotherapy interval ranged from 4 to 13 years. All reported patients received either a DNA topoisomerase II inhibitor or an alkylating agent.[<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

818339</a>

8184,<a href="#cit/section_3.40">

818540</a>

8186]</p>

8187<p id="_sm_CDR0000777844_19" tabindex="-1">

8188Controversy exists as to the biological behavior of translocation RCC in children and young adults. Whereas some series have suggested a good prognosis when translocation-positive RCC is treated with surgery alone despite presenting at a more advanced stage (III/IV), a meta-analysis reported that these patients have poorer outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.41">

818941</a>

8190-<a href="#cit/section_3.43">

819143</a>

8192] The outcomes for these patients are being studied in the ongoing COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00898365">

8193AREN03B2 (NCT00898365)</a>

8194 biology and classification study. Vascular endothelial growth factor receptor&#8211;targeted therapies and mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors seem to be active in Xp11 translocation metastatic RCC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.44">

819544</a>

8196] Recurrences have been reported 20 to 30 years after initial resection of the translocation-associated RCC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

819727</a>

8198] </p>

8199<p id="_sm_CDR0000777844_22" tabindex="-1">

8200Diagnosis of Xp11 translocation RCC needs to be confirmed by a molecular genetic approach, rather than using <em class="gene-name">

8201TFE3</em>

8202 immunohistochemistry alone, because reported cases have lacked the translocation.</p>

8203<p id="_sm_CDR0000777844_25" tabindex="-1">

8204 There is a rare subset of RCC cases that is positive for <em class="gene-name">

8205TFE3</em>

8206 and lack a <em class="gene-name">

8207TFE3</em>

8208 translocation, showing an <em class="gene-name">

8209ALK</em>

8210 translocation instead. This subset of cases represents a newly recognized subgroup within RCC that is estimated to involve 15% to 20% of unclassified pediatric RCC. In the eight reported cases in children aged 6 to 16 years, the following was observed:[<a href="#cit/section_3.45">

821145</a>

8212-<a href="#cit/section_3.48">

821348</a>

8214]</p>

8215<div class="pdq-content-list">

8216<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777844_23">

8217<li>

8218<em class="gene-name">

8219ALK</em>

8220 was fused to <em class="gene-name">

8221VCL</em>

8222 in a t(2;10)(p23;q22) translocation (n = 3). The <em class="gene-name">

8223VCL</em>

8224 translocation cases all occurred in children with the sickle cell trait, whereas none of the <em class="gene-name">

8225TPM3</em>

8226 translocation cases did.</li>

8227<li>

8228<em class="gene-name">

8229ALK</em>

8230 was fused to <em class="gene-name">

8231TPM3</em>

8232 (n = 3).</li>

8233<li>

8234<em class="gene-name">

8235ALK</em>

8236 was fused to <em class="gene-name">

8237HOOK1</em>

8238 on 1p32 (n = 1).</li>

8239<li>

8240t(1;2) translocation fusing <em class="gene-name">

8241ALK</em>

8242 and <em class="gene-name">

8243TPM3</em>

8244 (n = 1).</li>

8245</ul>

8246</div>

8247</section>

8248</section>

8249<section id="_748">

8250<h3 id="_748_toc">

8251Histology of RCC</h3>

8252<p id="_749" tabindex="-1">

8253Pediatric RCC differs histologically from the adult counterpart. Although the two main morphological subgroups of papillary and clear cell can be identified, about 25% of RCCs show heterogeneous features that do not fit into either of these categories.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

82543</a>

8255] Childhood RCCs are more frequently of the papillary subtype (20%&#8211;50% of pediatric RCCs) and can sometimes occur in the setting of Wilms tumor, metanephric adenoma, and metanephric adenofibroma.[<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

825649</a>

8257] </p>

8258<p id="_1078" tabindex="-1">

8259RCC in children and young adults has a different genetic and morphological spectrum than that seen in older adults.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

82603</a>

8261,<a href="#cit/section_3.40">

826240</a>

8263,<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

826449</a>

8265,<a href="#cit/section_3.50">

826650</a>

8267]</p>

8268</section>

8269<section id="_753">

8270<h3 id="_753_toc">

8271Prognosis and Prognostic Factors for RCC</h3>

8272<p id="_1284" tabindex="-1">

8273Prognostic factors for RCC include the following:</p>

8274<div class="pdq-content-list">

8275<ul id="_1285">

8276<li>

8277Stage of disease.</li>

8278<li>

8279Lymph node involvement.</li>

8280</ul>

8281</div>

8282<p id="_754" tabindex="-1">

8283The primary prognostic factor for RCC is stage of disease. In 304 children and adolescents with RCC identified in the National Cancer Database, the median age was 13 years; 39% of patients presented with localized stage I disease, 16% with stage II disease, 33% with stage III disease, and 12% with stage IV disease. The 5-year overall survival (OS) rates were 100% for patients with stage I and stage II disease, 71% for stage III disease, and 8% for stage IV disease.[<a href="#cit/section_3.51">

828451</a>

8285] Age and sex had no significant impact on survival. Survival was negatively impacted by increasing tumor size (<em>

8286P</em>

8287 &lt; .001), positive nodal status (<em>

8288P</em>

8289 = .001), and higher pathological stage (<em>

8290P</em>

8291 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_3.51">

829251</a>

8293] The data attained in this article from the National Cancer Database are limited, as some patient details are not available and follow-up is incomplete. Tumor size of 4 cm or smaller may or may not impact survival and local lymph node involvement may not be as significant in children. </p>

8294<p id="_834" tabindex="-1">

8295An important difference between the outcomes in children and adults with RCC is the prognostic significance of local lymph node involvement. Adults presenting with RCC and involved lymph nodes have a 5-year OS rate of approximately 20%, but the literature suggests that 72% of children with RCC and local lymph node involvement at diagnosis (without distant metastases) survive their disease.[<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

829632</a>

8297]</p>

8298<div class="pdq-content-list">

8299<ul id="_2391">

8300<li>

8301In another series of 49 patients from a population-based cancer registry, the findings were similar. In this series, 33% of the patients had papillary subtype, 22% had translocation subtype, 6% had clear-cell subtype, and 16% were unclassified. The survival rates at 5 years were 96% for patients with localized disease, 75% for patients with positive regional lymph nodes, and 33% for patients with distant metastatic RCC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

830252</a>

8303]</li>

8304<li>

8305A series from the International Society of Paediatric Oncology (SIOP) included 111 pediatric patients with RCC registered in the SIOP and UK-IMPORT databases. In the 65 patients that could be tested for transcription factor E3 and/or EB, translocation-positive RCC was the most frequent subtype (56%), followed by the papillary subtype (30%), and the clear-cell subtype (6%). In the remaining 57 patients that could not undergo translocation testing, the most common histologies were papillary (45%) and clear cell (23%). The estimated 5-year OS rates were 96.8% for patients with localized disease, 92.3% for patients with regionally advanced disease, and 45.6% for patients with metastatic disease.[<a href="#cit/section_3.33">

830633</a>

8307][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8308Level of evidence C1</a>

8309]</li>

8310</ul>

8311</div>

8312<p id="_2010" tabindex="-1">

8313 In a COG prospective clinical trial of 40 patients with small (7 cm) primary tumors whose lymph nodes were adequately sampled, 19 had positive nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.34">

831434</a>

8315] Outcome results of this trial are pending. </p>

8316</section>

8317<section id="_961">

8318<h3 id="_961_toc">

8319Clinical Features and Diagnostic Evaluation of RCC</h3>

8320<p id="_1032" tabindex="-1">

8321RCC may present with the following:</p>

8322<div class="pdq-content-list">

8323<ul id="_1079">

8324<li>

8325Abdominal mass.</li>

8326<li>

8327Abdominal pain.</li>

8328<li>

8329Hematuria.</li>

8330</ul>

8331</div>

8332<p id="_962" tabindex="-1">

8333For more information about the clinical features and diagnostic evaluation of childhood kidney tumors, see the sections on <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_898">

8334Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

8335 and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

8336Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

8337. For more information about the staging evaluation, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/kidney-treatment-pdq#_7">

8338Stage Information for Renal Cell Cancer</a>

8339 section in Renal Cell Cancer Treatment.</p>

8340</section>

8341<section id="_257">

8342<h3 id="_257_toc">

8343Treatment of RCC</h3>

8344<p id="_835" tabindex="-1">

8345Survival of patients with RCC is affected by stage of disease at presentation and the completeness of resection at radical nephrectomy. In a COG prospective clinical trial of patients with newly diagnosed RCC, 68 patients (aged &lt;30 years) were enrolled over a 6-year period. Complete surgical resection was attempted in all patients, regardless of the stage of their disease. Eight patients who had an incomplete surgical resection received chemotherapy. The 4-year event-free survival (EFS) rate was 80.2%, and the 4-year OS rate was 84.8%. For the 16 patients with N1M0 disease who underwent complete resection and no adjuvant therapy, the 4-year EFS and OS rates were 87.5% and 87.1%, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

834653</a>

8347][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8348Level of evidence C1</a>

8349] </p>

8350<p id="_836" tabindex="-1">

8351Standard treatment options for RCC include the following:</p>

8352<div class="pdq-content-list">

8353<ol id="_837">

8354<li>

8355<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1054">

8356Radical nephrectomy with lymph node sampling</a>

8357.</li>

8358<li>

8359<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1056">

8360Renal-sparing surgery with lymph node sampling</a>

8361.</li>

8362</ol>

8363</div>

8364<section id="_1054">

8365<h4 id="_1054_toc">

8366Radical nephrectomy with lymph node sampling</h4>

8367<p id="_1055" tabindex="-1">

8368The primary treatment for RCC includes total surgical removal of the kidney and associated lymph nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.34">

836934</a>

8370]</p>

8371<p id="_2392" tabindex="-1">

8372Pediatric patients with translocation-positive RCC often have a better outcome than adult patients, which is generally attributed to a smaller percentage of distant metastasis in pediatric patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.41">

837341</a>

8374] In younger patients, the disease is often managed with surgery alone. Of three pediatric patients (aged 3&#8211;12 years) in one study, two had previously received chemotherapy to treat retinoblastoma and neuroblastoma. All three patients underwent surgery only and remained disease free. These patients had a lower copy-number burden than the adults in the series.[<a href="#cit/section_3.37">

837537</a>

8376][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8377Level of evidence C1</a>

8378]</p>

8379</section>

8380<section id="_1056">

8381<h4 id="_1056_toc">

8382Renal-sparing surgery with lymph node sampling</h4>

8383<p id="_1057" tabindex="-1">

8384Renal-sparing surgery may be considered for carefully selected patients with low-volume localized disease. In two small series, patients who had partial nephrectomies seemed to have outcomes equivalent to those who had radical nephrectomies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.34">

838534</a>

8386]</p>

8387</section>

8388<section id="_1058">

8389<h4 id="_1058_toc">

8390Other approaches</h4>

8391<p id="_1059" tabindex="-1">

8392As with adult RCC, there is no standard treatment for unresectable metastatic disease in children. The response to radiation therapy is poor, and chemotherapy is not effective. Immunotherapy with agents such as interferon-alpha and interleukin-2 may have some effect on cancer control.[<a href="#cit/section_3.54">

839354</a>

8394,<a href="#cit/section_3.55">

839555</a>

8396] Spontaneous regression of pulmonary metastasis rarely occurs with resection of the primary tumor. </p>

8397<p id="_1060" tabindex="-1">

8398Several targeted therapies (e.g., sorafenib, sunitinib, bevacizumab, temsirolimus, pazopanib, axitinib, and everolimus) have been approved for use in adults with RCC. However, these agents have not been tested in pediatric patients with RCC. Case reports of pediatric and adolescent patients with <em class="gene-name">

8399TFE3</em>

8400 translocation&#8211;positive RCC suggest responsiveness to multiple tyrosine kinase inhibitors.[<a href="#cit/section_3.35">

840135</a>

8402,<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

840356</a>

8404,<a href="#cit/section_3.57">

840557</a>

8406]; [<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

840758</a>

8408][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8409Level of evidence C1</a>

8410] Disease regression and improvement in symptoms have been reported with the use of cabozantinib in pediatric patients with translocation-positive RCC expressing MET.[<a href="#cit/section_3.59">

841159</a>

8412] Any RCC that is positive for <em class="gene-name">

8413TFE3</em>

8414 and lacks a translocation should be tested for ALK expression and translocation. Recognition of this subtype may lead to consideration of ALK inhibitor therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.45">

841545</a>

8416]</p>

8417<p id="_1235" tabindex="-1">

8418For more information about the use of targeted therapies, see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/kidney-treatment-pdq">

8419Renal Cell Cancer Treatment</a>

8420.</p>

8421</section>

8422</section>

8423<section id="_1895">

8424<h3 id="_1895_toc">

8425Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for RCC</h3>

8426<p id="_1896" tabindex="-1">

8427Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

8428NCI website</a>

8429. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

8430ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

8431.</p>

8432<p id="_1897" tabindex="-1">

8433The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

8434<div class="pdq-content-list">

8435<ul id="_1898">

8436<li>

8437<strong>

8438<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03595124">

8439AREN1721 (NCT03595124)</a>

8440</strong>

8441 (Axitinib and Nivolumab in Treating Participants With Unresectable or Metastatic <em class="gene-name">

8442TFE</em>

8443/Translocation RCC [tRCC])<strong>

8444:</strong>

8445

8446

8447<em class="gene-name">

8448TFE</em>

8449/tRCC is a distinct, typically translocation-associated RCC with characteristic morphology and immunohistochemical expression of <em class="gene-name">

8450TFE3</em>

8451 or <em class="gene-name">

8452TFEB</em>

8453. Nearly 50% of pediatric RCCs are tRCC, and it accounts for 1% to 5% of RCCs overall, typically in the adolescent and young adult population. This is the first prospective therapeutic study of patients with tRCC. Patients aged 12 months and older who have histologically confirmed unresectable <em class="gene-name">

8454TFE</em>

8455/tRCC or metastatic <em class="gene-name">

8456TFE</em>

8457/tRCC diagnosed using WHO-defined criteria are eligible. Patients may be newly diagnosed or have received previous cancer therapy and must have measurable disease. Patients will be randomly assigned at the time of enrollment to one of two therapeutic arms: nivolumab or a combination of axitinib and nivolumab.</li>

8458<li>

8459<strong>

8460<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT05286801">

8461PEPN2121 (NCT05286801)</a>

8462</strong>

8463 (Tiragolumab and Atezolizumab for the Treatment of Relapsed or Refractory <em class="gene-name">

8464SMARCB1</em>

8465- or <em class="gene-name">

8466SMARCA4</em>

8467-Deficient Tumors)<strong>

8468:</strong>

8469 This study is evaluating the combination of a PD-L1 targeting antibody (atezolizumab) with a TIGIT targeting antibody (tiragolumab) for patients with <em class="gene-name">

8470SMARCB1</em>

8471- or <em class="gene-name">

8472SMARCA4</em>

8473-deficient tumors. Patients with renal medullary carcinoma may be eligible for this study.</li>

8474</ul>

8475</div>

8476</section>

8477<section id="_TrialSearch_432_sid_3">

8478<h3 id="_TrialSearch_432_sid_3_toc">

8479Current Clinical Trials</h3>

8480<p id="_TrialSearch_432_22" tabindex="-1">

8481Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8482advanced clinical trial search</a>

8483 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8484General information</a>

8485 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8486</section>

8516[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

Genes Chromosomes Cancer 55 (10): 814-7, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27225638&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27225638&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8680[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8681</li>

8682<li id="section_3.49">

8683Estrada CR, Suthar AM, Eaton SH, et al.: Renal cell carcinoma: Children's Hospital Boston experience. Urology 66 (6): 1296-300, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16360460&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16360460&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8684[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8685</li>

8686<li id="section_3.50">

8687Carcao MD, Taylor GP, Greenberg ML, et al.: Renal-cell carcinoma in children: a different disorder from its adult counterpart? Med Pediatr Oncol 31 (3): 153-8, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9722897&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9722897&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8688[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8689</li>

8690<li id="section_3.51">

8691Rialon KL, Gulack BC, Englum BR, et al.: Factors impacting survival in children with renal cell carcinoma. J Pediatr Surg 50 (6): 1014-8, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25805005&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25805005&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8692[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8693</li>

8694<li id="section_3.52">

8695Selle B, Furtw&#228;ngler R, Graf N, et al.: Population-based study of renal cell carcinoma in children in Germany, 1980-2005: more frequently localized tumors and underlying disorders compared with adult counterparts. Cancer 107 (12): 2906-14, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17109448&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17109448&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8696[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8697</li>

8698<li id="section_3.53">

8699Geller JI, Cost NG, Chi YY, et al.: A prospective study of pediatric and adolescent renal cell carcinoma: A report from the Children's Oncology Group AREN0321 study. Cancer 126 (23): 5156-5164, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32926409&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32926409&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8700[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8701</li>

8702<li id="section_3.54">

8703Fyfe G, Fisher RI, Rosenberg SA, et al.: Results of treatment of 255 patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma who received high-dose recombinant interleukin-2 therapy. J Clin Oncol 13 (3): 688-96, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7884429&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7884429&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8704[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8705</li>

8706<li id="section_3.55">

8707Coppin C, Porzsolt F, Awa A, et al.: Immunotherapy for advanced renal cell cancer. Cochrane Database Syst Rev (1): CD001425, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15674877&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15674877&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8708[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8709</li>

8710<li id="section_3.56">

8711De Pasquale MD, Pessolano R, Boldrini R, et al.: Continuing response to subsequent treatment lines with tyrosine kinase inhibitors in an adolescent with metastatic renal cell carcinoma. J Pediatr Hematol Oncol 33 (5): e176-9, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21552143&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21552143&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8712[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8713</li>

8714<li id="section_3.57">

8715Chowdhury T, Prichard-Jones K, Sebire NJ, et al.: Persistent complete response after single-agent sunitinib treatment in a case of TFE translocation positive relapsed metastatic pediatric renal cell carcinoma. J Pediatr Hematol Oncol 35 (1): e1-3, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22995920&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22995920&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8716[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8717</li>

8718<li id="section_3.58">

8719Ray S, Jones R, Pritchard-Jones K, et al.: Pediatric and young adult renal cell carcinoma. Pediatr Blood Cancer 67 (11): e28675, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32869954&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32869954&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8720[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8721</li>

8722<li id="section_3.59">

8723Wedekind MF, Ranalli M, Shah N: Clinical efficacy of cabozantinib in two pediatric patients with recurrent renal cell carcinoma. Pediatr Blood Cancer 64 (11): , 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28417541&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28417541&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8724[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8725</li>

8726</ol>

8727</div>

8728

8729 </section>

8730

8731

8732

8733 <section id="_17">

8734

8735 <h2>

8736Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</h2>

8737

8738 <div id="_section_17" class="pdq-sections">

8739<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8740<h6>

8741In This Section</h6>

8742<ul>

8743<li>

8744<a href="#_885_toc">

8745General Information About Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</a>

8746</li>

8747<li>

8748<a href="#_1205_toc">

8749Genomics of Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney<ul>

8750<li>

8751<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777847_13_toc">

8752Molecular features of rhabdoid tumors of the kidney</a>

8753</li>

8754</ul>

8755</a>

8756</li>

8757<li>

8758<a href="#_1105_toc">

8759Genetic Testing and Surveillance of Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</a>

8760</li>

8761<li>

8762<a href="#_1287_toc">

8763Prognosis and Prognostic Factors for Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</a>

8764</li>

8765<li>

8766<a href="#_103_toc">

8767Treatment of Rhabdoid Tumor of the Kidney</a>

8768</li>

8769<li>

8770<a href="#_1236_toc">

8771Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</a>

8772</li>

8773<li>

8774<a href="#_TrialSearch_17_sid_4_toc">

8775Current Clinical Trials</a>

8776</li>

8777</ul>

8778</nav>

8779<section id="_885">

8780<h3 id="_885_toc">

8781General Information About Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</h3>

8782<p id="_373" tabindex="-1">

8783Rhabdoid tumors are extremely aggressive malignancies that generally occur in infants and young children. The most common locations are the kidney (termed malignant rhabdoid tumors) and the central nervous system (CNS) (atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor), although rhabdoid tumors can also arise in most soft tissue sites. Relapses occur early (median time from diagnosis, 8 months).[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

87841</a>

8785,<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

87862</a>

8787] For information about the treatment of CNS disease, see <a href="/types/brain/hp/child-cns-atrt-treatment-pdq">

8788Childhood Central Nervous System Atypical Teratoid/Rhabdoid Tumor Treatment</a>

8789.</p>

8790<p id="_374" tabindex="-1">

8791A distinct clinical presentation that suggests a diagnosis of rhabdoid tumor of the kidney includes the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

87923</a>

8793] </p>

8794<div class="pdq-content-list">

8795<ul id="_1080">

8796<li>

8797Fever.</li>

8798<li>

8799Hematuria.</li>

8800<li>

8801Young age (mean age, 11 months).</li>

8802<li>

8803Advanced tumor stage at presentation.</li>

8804</ul>

8805</div>

8806<p id="_1123" tabindex="-1">

8807For more information about the clinical features and diagnostic evaluation of childhood kidney tumors, see the sections on <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_898">

8808Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

8809 and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

8810Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

8811.</p>

8812<p id="_1081" tabindex="-1">

8813Approximately two-thirds of patients will present with advanced-stage disease. Bilateral cases have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

88141</a>

8815] Rhabdoid tumors of the kidney tend to metastasize to the lungs and the brain. As many as 10% to 15% of patients with rhabdoid tumors of the kidney also have CNS lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

88164</a>

8817] The staging system used for rhabdoid tumor of the kidney is the same system used for Wilms tumor. For more information, see the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_23">

8818Stage Information for Wilms Tumor</a>

8819 section.</p>

8820<p id="_1082" tabindex="-1">

8821Histologically, the most distinctive features of rhabdoid tumors of the kidney are rather large cells with large vesicular nuclei, a prominent single nucleolus, and in some cells, the presence of globular eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions. </p>

8822</section>

8823<section id="_1205">

8824<h3 id="_1205_toc">

8825Genomics of Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</h3>

8826<section id="_sm_CDR0000777847_13">

8827<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777847_13_toc">

8828Molecular features of rhabdoid tumors of the kidney</h4>

8829<p id="_sm_CDR0000777847_15" tabindex="-1">

8830Independent of their anatomical locations, rhabdoid tumors have a common genetic abnormality&#8212;loss of function of the <em class="gene-name">

8831SMARCB1</em>

8832 gene located at chromosome 22q11.2 (&gt;95% of tumors).[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

88335</a>

8834] The following text refers to rhabdoid tumors without regard to their primary site. <em class="gene-name">

8835SMARCB1</em>

8836 encodes a component of the SWItch/Sucrose Non-Fermentable (SWI/SNF) chromatin remodeling complex that has an important role in controlling gene transcription.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

88376</a>

8838,<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

88397</a>

8840] Loss of function occurs by deletions that lead to loss of part or all of the <em class="gene-name">

8841SMARCB1</em>

8842 gene and by mutations that are commonly frameshift or nonsense mutations that lead to premature truncation of the SMARCB1 protein.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

88435</a>

8844,<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

88457</a>

8846] A common pathway for achieving complete loss of SMARCB1 function is the combination of a <em class="gene-name">

8847SMARCB1</em>

8848 mutation or partial/complete gene deletion for one <em class="gene-name">

8849SMARCB1</em>

8850 allele in conjunction with uniparental disomy for the chromosomal region containing <em class="gene-name">

8851SMARCB1</em>

8852 with loss of part or all of the parental chromosome that has a wild-type <em class="gene-name">

8853SMARCB1</em>

8854 allele.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

88558</a>

8856] A small percentage of rhabdoid tumors are caused by alterations in <em class="gene-name">

8857SMARCA4</em>

8858, which is the primary ATPase in the SWI/SNF complex.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

88599</a>

8860,<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

886110</a>

8862] Exome sequencing of 35 cases of rhabdoid tumor identified a very low mutation rate, with no genes having recurring mutations other than <em class="gene-name">

8863SMARCB1</em>

8864, which appeared to contribute to tumorigenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

886511</a>

8866] </p>

8867<p id="_sm_CDR0000777847_16" tabindex="-1">

8868Germline mutations of <em class="gene-name">

8869SMARCB1</em>

8870 have been documented in patients with one or more primary tumors of the brain and/or kidney, consistent with a genetic predisposition to the development of rhabdoid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

887112</a>

8872,<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

887313</a>

8874] Approximately one-third of patients with rhabdoid tumors have germline <em class="gene-name">

8875SMARCB1</em>

8876 alterations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

88777</a>

8878,<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

887914</a>

8880] In most cases, the mutations are de novo and not inherited. The median age at diagnosis of children with rhabdoid tumors and a germline mutation or deletion is younger (6 months) than that of children with apparently sporadic disease (18 months).[<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

888115</a>

8882] Early-onset, multifocal disease and familial cases with the presence of <em class="gene-name">

8883SMARCB1</em>

8884 strongly support the possibility of rhabdoid tumor predisposition syndrome, type 1.</p>

8885<p id="_sm_CDR0000777847_961" tabindex="-1">

8886In a study of 100 patients with rhabdoid tumors of the brain, kidney, or soft tissues, 35 were found to have a germline <em class="gene-name">

8887SMARCB1</em>

8888 abnormality. These abnormalities included point and frameshift mutations, intragenic deletions and duplications, and larger deletions. Nine cases demonstrated parent-to-child transmission of a mutated copy of <em class="gene-name">

8889SMARCB1</em>

8890. In eight of the nine cases, one or more family members were also diagnosed with rhabdoid tumor or schwannoma. Two of the eight families presented with multiple affected children, consistent with gonadal mosaicism.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

88917</a>

8892] It appears that patients with germline mutations may have the worst prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

889316</a>

8894,<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

889517</a>

8896]</p>

8897<p id="_sm_CDR0000777847_963" tabindex="-1">

8898Rarely, extracranial rhabdoid tumors can harbor the alternative inactivation of <em class="gene-name">

8899SMARCA4</em>

8900 instead of <em class="gene-name">

8901SMARCB1</em>

8902.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

89039</a>

8904,<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

890510</a>

8906,<a href="#cit/section_4.18">

890718</a>

8908] In a series of 12 patients diagnosed with extracranial rhabdoid tumors with <em class="gene-name">

8909SMARCA4</em>

8910 inactivation, 4 cases occurred in the kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

891119</a>

8912] All four cases had germline alteration of <em class="gene-name">

8913SMARCA4</em>

8914. The cases of <em class="gene-name">

8915SMARCA4</em>

8916 inactivation were comparable to the extracranial rhabdoid tumors with <em class="gene-name">

8917SMARCB1</em>

8918 inactivation on a clinical, pathological, and genomic level. Using DNA methylation and transcriptomics-based tumor classification, the extracranial rhabdoid tumors with <em class="gene-name">

8919SMARCA4</em>

8920 inactivation display molecular features intermediate between small cell carcinoma of the ovary, hypercalcemic type (driven by <em class="gene-name">

8921SMARCA4</em>

8922 alterations), and extracranial rhabdoid tumors with <em class="gene-name">

8923SMARCB1</em>

8924 inactivations. Extracranial rhabdoid tumors with <em class="gene-name">

8925SMARCA4</em>

8926 inactivation display concomitant lack of <em class="gene-name">

8927SMARCA4</em>

8928 (BRG1) and <em class="gene-name">

8929SMARCA2</em>

8930 (BRM) expression at the protein level, similar to what is seen in small cell carcinoma of the ovary, hypercalcemic type. These results help to expand the similarities and differences between these three tumor types within the rhabdoid tumor spectrum.[<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

893119</a>

8932]</p>

8933</section>

8934</section>

8935<section id="_1105">

8936<h3 id="_1105_toc">

8937Genetic Testing and Surveillance of Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</h3>

8938<p id="_1106" tabindex="-1">

8939Germline analysis should be considered for individuals of all ages with rhabdoid tumors. Genetic counseling is also part of the treatment plan, given the low-but-actual risk of familial recurrence. In cases of mutations, parental screening should be considered, although such screening carries a low probability of positivity. Prenatal diagnosis can be performed in situations in which a specific <em class="gene-name">

8940SMARCB1</em>

8941 mutation or deletion has been documented in the family.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

89427</a>

8943]</p>

8944<p id="_1107" tabindex="-1">

8945To date, there is little evidence regarding the effectiveness of surveillance for patients with rhabdoid tumor predisposition syndrome, type 1 caused by loss-of-function germline <em class="gene-name">

8946SMARCB1</em>

8947 mutations. However, because of the aggressive nature of the tumors with significant lethality and young age of onset in <em class="gene-name">

8948SMARCB1</em>

8949 carriers with truncating mutations, consensus recommendations have been developed. These recommendations were developed by a group of pediatric cancer genetic experts (including oncologists, radiologists, and geneticists). They have not been formally studied to confirm the benefit of monitoring patients with germline <em class="gene-name">

8950SMARCB1</em>

8951 mutations. Given the potential survival benefit of surgically resectable disease, it is postulated that early detection might improve overall survival (OS).[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

895220</a>

8953-<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

895422</a>

8955]</p>

8956<p id="_1286" tabindex="-1">

8957Surveillance for patients with germline <em class="gene-name">

8958SMARCB1</em>

8959 mutations includes the following:</p>

8960<div class="pdq-content-list">

8961<ul id="_1108">

8962<li>

8963Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) every 3 months from birth (or diagnosis) until age 5 years.</li>

8964<li>

8965 Abdominal ultrasonography with a focus on the kidneys every 3 months.</li>

8966</ul>

8967</div>

8968</section>

8969<section id="_1287">

8970<h3 id="_1287_toc">

8971Prognosis and Prognostic Factors for Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</h3>

8972<p id="_1288" tabindex="-1">

8973Patients with rhabdoid tumors of the kidney have a poor prognosis.

8974 In a review of 142 patients from the National Wilms Tumor Studies (NWTS) (NWTS-1, NWTS-2, NWTS-3, NWTS-4, and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

8975NWTS-5 [COG-Q9401/NCT00002611]</a>

8976), age and stage were identified as important prognostic factors:[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

89774</a>

8978]</p>

8979<div class="pdq-content-list">

8980<ul id="_1289">

8981<li>

8982<strong>

8983Age at diagnosis.</strong>

8984 Infants younger than 6 months at diagnosis demonstrated a 4-year OS rate of 9%, whereas the OS rate in patients aged 2 years and older was 41% (highly significant).</li>

8985<li>

8986<strong>

8987Stage of disease.</strong>

8988 Patients with stage I and stage II disease had an OS rate of 42%. Patients with a higher stage of disease had an OS rate of 16%.</li>

8989<li>

8990<strong>

8991Presence of a CNS lesion.</strong>

8992 All but one patient with a CNS lesion (n = 32) died.</li>

8993</ul>

8994</div>

8995<p id="_2395" tabindex="-1">

8996One study that used the National Cancer Database identified 202 patients (aged younger than 18 years) with non-CNS malignant rhabdoid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

899723</a>

8998][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8999Level of evidence C1</a>

9000]</p>

9001<div class="pdq-content-list">

9002<ul id="_2396">

9003<li>

9004The 1-year OS rate was 48.8%, and the 5-year OS rate was 35.9%.</li>

9005<li>

9006Multivariate analysis demonstrated that age younger than 1 year and presence of metastasis were negative prognostic indications (<em>

9007P</em>

9008 = .058).</li>

9009<li>

9010In the cohort of surgical patients (n = 143), the presence of residual disease was associated with a clinically significant worse outcome (hazard ratio, 1.54; 95% confidence interval, 0.88&#8211;2.69; <em>

9011P</em>

9012 = .13).</li>

9013</ul>

9014</div>

9015</section>

9016<section id="_103">

9017<h3 id="_103_toc">

9018Treatment of Rhabdoid Tumor of the Kidney</h3>

9019<p id="_378" tabindex="-1">

9020Because of the relative rarity of this tumor, all patients with rhabdoid tumor of the kidney should consider entering into a clinical trial. Treatment planning by a multidisciplinary team of cancer specialists (pediatric surgeon or pediatric urologist, pediatric radiation oncologist, and pediatric oncologist) with experience treating renal tumors is required to determine and implement optimal treatment.</p>

9021<p id="_819" tabindex="-1">

9022There are no standard treatment options for rhabdoid tumor of the kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

902324</a>

9024]</p>

9025<p id="_1290" tabindex="-1">

9026The following results have been observed in studies of rhabdoid tumor of the kidney:</p>

9027<div class="pdq-content-list">

9028<ol id="_1301">

9029<li>

9030On the basis of a retrospective comparison of tumor response to preoperative treatment with vincristine/dactinomycin versus vincristine/dactinomycin/doxorubicin, doxorubicin is considered an active drug in malignant rhabdoid tumor of the kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

903125</a>

9032][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9033Level of evidence C3</a>

9034]</li>

9035<li>

9036The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

9037NWTS-5</a>

9038 trial closed the arm for patients with rhabdoid tumor who were treated with cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and carboplatin because poor outcomes were observed. Combinations of etoposide and cisplatin;

9039 etoposide and ifosfamide; and ifosfamide, carboplatin, and etoposide (ICE chemotherapy) have been used.[<a href="#cit/section_4.26">

904026</a>

9041,<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

904227</a>

9043] </li>

9044<li>

9045Treatment with high-dose alkylator therapy followed by consolidation with high-dose chemotherapy and, in some cases, autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT) after achieving a radiographic remission has resulted in some long-term survival (5 of 13 patients). None of the patients with unresectable primary tumors survived in this small series (N = 21).[<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

904628</a>

9047]</li>

9048<li>

9049A retrospective analysis of 58 patients with malignant rhabdoid tumor of the kidney from the International Society of Paediatric Oncology (SIOP), Gesellschaft f&#252;r P&#228;diatrische Onkologie und H&#228;matologie (GPOH), and European Rhabdoid Tumor Registry was performed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.29">

905029</a>

9051]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9052<ul id="_1839">

9053<li>

9054For the entire group, the 2-year event-free survival (EFS) rate was 37%, and the OS rate was 38%.</li>

9055<li>

9056Patients with multifocal involvement (n = 12) had significantly inferior survival than did patients with pulmonary or mediastinal metastases or local disease.</li>

9057<li>

9058Patients who underwent up-front chemotherapy had a lower, but not statistically significant, 2-year EFS rate than did patients who underwent immediate surgical resection.</li>

9059<li>

9060Younger age (&lt;12 months) and local stage III disease were associated with significantly inferior survival than were stage I and stage II disease.</li>

9061<li>

9062No difference was seen in 2-year EFS rates for patients without progression within 90 days consolidated by high-dose SCT (n = 10) compared with patients without consolidation by SCT (n = 21).</li>

9063<li>

9064In a separate analysis of the same patient population, investigators examined the role of radiation therapy for local control in patients with higher-stage disease. Twenty-one patients (stages II and III) received radiation therapy during first-line treatment, 18 of whom received radiation therapy to all involved sites. The local failure rate was 29% for patients with local stage II or stage III disease who received radiation therapy to all sites, compared with 68% for nonirradiated patients. The progression-free survival rate was 67% for patients with local stage II and stage III disease who were treated with radiation therapy during first-line treatment (adjusted for early relapse or treatment abandonment), compared with 15% for patients who did not receive radiation therapy (<em>

9065P</em>

9066 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

906730</a>

9068][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9069Level of evidence C1</a>

9070]</li>

9071</ul>

9072</div>

9073</li>

9074</ol>

9075</div>

9076</section>

9077<section id="_1236">

9078<h3 id="_1236_toc">

9079Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Rhabdoid Tumors of the Kidney</h3>

9080<p id="_1834" tabindex="-1">

9081Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

9082NCI website</a>

9083. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

9084ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

9085.</p>

9086<p id="_1237" tabindex="-1">

9087The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

9088<div class="pdq-content-list">

9089<ul id="_1238">

9090<li>

9091<strong>

9092<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03155620">

9093APEC1621 (NCT03155620)</a>

9094</strong>

9095 (Pediatric MATCH: Targeted Therapy Directed by Genetic Testing in Treating Pediatric Patients with Relapsed or Refractory Advanced Solid Tumors, Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas, or Histiocytic Disorders)<strong>

9096:</strong>

9097 NCI-COG Pediatric Molecular Analysis for Therapeutic Choice (MATCH), referred to as Pediatric MATCH, will match targeted agents with specific molecular changes identified in a patient's tumor (refractory or recurrent). Children and adolescents aged 1 to 21 years are eligible for the trial.<p id="_1807" tabindex="-1">

9098Patients with tumors that have molecular variants addressed by open treatment arms included in the trial may be enrolled in treatment on Pediatric MATCH. Additional information can be obtained on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match">

9099NCI website</a>

9100 and <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620">

9101ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

9102.</p>

9103

9104</li>

9105<li>

9106<strong>

9107<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT05286801">

9108PEPN2121 (NCT05286801)</a>

9109</strong>

9110 (Tiragolumab and Atezolizumab for the Treatment of Relapsed or Refractory <em class="gene-name">

9111SMARCB1</em>

9112- or <em class="gene-name">

9113SMARCA4</em>

9114-Deficient Tumors)<strong>

9115:</strong>

9116 This study is evaluating the combination of a PD-L1 targeting antibody (atezolizumab) with a TIGIT targeting antibody (tiragolumab) for patients with <em class="gene-name">

9117SMARCB1</em>

9118- or <em class="gene-name">

9119SMARCA4</em>

9120-deficient tumors.</li>

9121</ul>

9122</div>

9123</section>

9124<section id="_TrialSearch_17_sid_4">

9125<h3 id="_TrialSearch_17_sid_4_toc">

9126Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9127<p id="_TrialSearch_17_22" tabindex="-1">

9128Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9129advanced clinical trial search</a>

9130 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9131General information</a>

9132 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9133</section>

9263

9264 <section id="_10">

9265

9266 <h2>

9267Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney</h2>

9268

9269 <div id="_section_10" class="pdq-sections">

9314<section id="_887">

9315<h3 id="_887_toc">

9316General Information About Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney</h3>

9317<p id="_2011" tabindex="-1">

9318Clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is an uncommon renal tumor that comprises approximately 5% of all primary renal malignancies in children, accounts for approximately 20 new cases per year in the United States, and is observed most often before age 3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

93191</a>

9320] </p>

9321<p id="_780" tabindex="-1">

9322Clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is not a Wilms tumor variant, but it

9323is an important primary renal tumor associated with a higher rate

9324of relapse and death than is favorable histology (FH) Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

93251</a>

9326] The classic pattern of clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is defined by nests or cords of cells

9327separated by regularly spaced fibrovascular septa. In addition to

9328pulmonary metastases, clear cell sarcoma also spreads to bone, brain, and soft

9329tissue.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

93301</a>

9331] For more information about the clinical features and diagnostic evaluation of childhood kidney tumors, see the sections on <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_898">

9332Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

9333 and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

9334Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

9335.</p>

9336<p id="_953" tabindex="-1">

9337Younger age and stage IV disease have been identified as adverse prognostic factors for event-free survival (EFS).[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

93382</a>

9339]</p>

9340<p id="_782" tabindex="-1">

9341Historically, relapses have occurred up to 14 years after the completion of chemotherapy. However, with current therapy, relapses after 3 years are uncommon.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

93423</a>

9343] The brain is a frequent site of recurrent disease, suggesting that it is a sanctuary site for cells that are protected from the intensive chemotherapy that patients receive.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

93442</a>

9345-<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

93465</a>

9347] An awareness of the clinical signs of recurrent disease in the brain is important during regular follow-up.

9348There are no standard recommendations for the frequency of brain imaging during follow-up. </p>

9349<p id="_2467" tabindex="-1">

9350Clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is rare in adults but has been reported. In a series of 17 patients, the median age was 25 years (range, 19&#8211;62 years). The ratio of male to female patients was 13:4. The pathological diagnosis can be achieved with microscopy and immunohistochemistry panels that include <em class="gene-name">

9351BCOR</em>

9352. The primary treatment for adult patients is nephrectomy and regional lymphadenectomy, although chemotherapy with or without radiation therapy may be helpful in preventing local recurrence and distant metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

93536</a>

9354]; [<a href="#cit/section_5.7">

93557</a>

9356][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9357Level of evidence C3</a>

9358]</p>

9359</section>

9360<section id="_1206">

9361<h3 id="_1206_toc">

9362Genomics of Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney</h3>

9363<section id="_sm_CDR0000777848_13">

9364<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777848_13_toc">

9365Molecular features of clear cell sarcoma of the kidney</h4>

9366<p id="_sm_CDR0000777848_15" tabindex="-1">

9367The molecular background of clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is poorly understood because of its rarity and lack of experimental models. However, several molecular features of clear cell sarcoma of the kidney have been described, including the following:</p>

9368<div class="pdq-content-list">

9369<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777848_16">

9370<li>

9371Internal tandem duplications in exon 15 of the <em class="gene-name">

9372BCOR</em>

9373 gene (BCL6 corepressor) have been reported in 90% of cases of clear cell sarcoma of the kidney, with a smaller subset harboring <em class="gene-name">

9374YWHAE</em>

9375::<em class="gene-name">

9376NUTM2B</em>

9377, <em class="gene-name">

9378YWHAE</em>

9379::<em class="gene-name">

9380NUTM2E</em>

9381, or <em class="gene-name">

9382BCOR</em>

9383::<em class="gene-name">

9384CCNB3</em>

9385 gene fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_5.8">

93868</a>

9387-<a href="#cit/section_5.13">

938813</a>

9389] All of these genetic abnormalities result in a transcriptional signature characterized by high BCOR mRNA expression.[<a href="#cit/section_5.14">

939014</a>

9391]</li>

9392<li>

9393Diffuse strong immunoreactivity for <em class="gene-name">

9394BCOR</em>

9395 is highly sensitive and specific for the diagnosis of clear cell sarcoma of the kidney. One series evaluated 79 neoplasms, including Wilms tumors, congenital mesoblastic nephromas, clear cell sarcoma of the kidney, metanephric stromal tumors, rhabdoid tumors of the kidney, renal primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET), and sclerosing epithelioid fibrosarcomas. All of the clear cell sarcoma of the kidney samples that were tested demonstrated diffuse, strong nuclear labeling for <em class="gene-name">

9396BCOR</em>

9397. Most of the other pediatric renal neoplasms were completely negative for <em class="gene-name">

9398BCOR</em>

9399.[<a href="#cit/section_5.15">

940015</a>

9401]</li>

9402</ul>

9403</div>

9404</section>

9405</section>

9406<section id="_99">

9407<h3 id="_99_toc">

9408Treatment of Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney</h3>

9409<p id="_377" tabindex="-1">

9410Because of the relative rarity of this tumor, all patients with clear cell sarcoma of the kidney should consider entering into a clinical trial. Treatment planning by a multidisciplinary team of cancer specialists (pediatric surgeon or pediatric urologist, pediatric radiation oncologist, and pediatric oncologist) with experience treating renal tumors is required to determine and implement optimal treatment.</p>

9411<p id="_824" tabindex="-1">

9412The approach for treating clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is different from the approach for treating

9413Wilms tumor because the overall survival (OS) of children with clear cell sarcoma of the kidney remains lower than that for patients with FH Wilms tumor. All patients undergo postoperative radiation to the tumor bed and receive doxorubicin as part of their chemotherapy regimen.</p>

9414<p id="_825" tabindex="-1">

9415The standard treatment option for clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is the following:</p>

9416<div class="pdq-content-list">

9417<ol id="_826">

9418<li>

9419<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1061">

9420Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy</a>

9421.</li>

9422</ol>

9423</div>

9424<section id="_1061">

9425<h4 id="_1061_toc">

9426Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy</h4>

9427<p id="_827" tabindex="-1">

9428Evidence (surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy):</p>

9429<div class="pdq-content-list">

9430<ol id="_828">

9431<li>

9432In the National Wilms Tumor Study (NWTS) <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

9433NWTS-5 (COG-Q9401/NCT00002611)</a>

9434 trial, children with stages

9435I to IV clear cell sarcoma of the kidney were treated with a new

9436chemotherapeutic regimen combining vincristine, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide,

9437and etoposide in an attempt to further improve the survival of these high-risk

9438groups. All patients received radiation therapy to the tumor bed.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

94393</a>

9440] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9441<ul id="_818">

9442<li>

9443With this treatment, the 5-year EFS rate was 79%, and the OS rate was 90%.</li>

9444<li>

9445Stage I patients had 5-year EFS and OS rates of 100%.</li>

9446<li>

9447Stage II patients had a 5-year EFS rate of 88% and a 5-year OS rate of 98%.</li>

9448<li>

9449Stage III patients had a 5-year EFS rate of 73% and a 5-year OS rate of 89%.</li>

9450<li>

9451Stage IV patients had a 5-year EFS rate of 29% and a 5-year OS rate of 36%.</li>

9452</ul>

9453</div>

9454</li>

9455<li>

9456A review of patients with stage I clear cell sarcoma of the kidney treated on the NWTS-1, NWTS-2, NWTS-3, NWTS-4, and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002611">

9457NWTS-5</a>

9458 trials showed an excellent OS rate of 100% with a wide variety of chemotherapy and radiation therapy regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

945916</a>

9460]</li>

9461<li>

9462 In the NWTS-3 trial, the addition of doxorubicin to the combination of vincristine,

9463dactinomycin (DD-4A), and radiation therapy resulted in an improvement in disease-free

9464survival for patients with clear cell sarcoma of the kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

94651</a>

9466] The NWTS-4 trial expanded on this trial, with patients randomly assigned to either 15 months of therapy or 6 months of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.17">

946717</a>

9468]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9469<ul id="_2435">

9470<li>

9471Patients who were treated with DD-4A for 15 months had an improved relapse-free survival rate compared with patients who were treated for 6 months (88% vs. 61% at 8 years).</li>

9472</ul>

9473</div>

9474</li>

9475</ol>

9476</div>

9477</section>

9478</section>

9479<section id="_598">

9480<h3 id="_598_toc">

9481Treatment of Recurrent Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney</h3>

9482<p id="_2451" tabindex="-1">

9483 Patients with most forms of recurrent childhood cancer should consider enrolling in available phase I and phase II clinical trials. Other treatment options for clear cell sarcoma of the kidney are discussed below.</p>

9484<p id="_2452" tabindex="-1">

9485Palliative care remains a central focus of management regardless of whether disease-directed therapy is pursued at the time of progression. This ensures that quality of life is maximized while attempting to reduce symptoms and stress related to the terminal illness.</p>

9486<p id="_599" tabindex="-1">

9487Clear cell sarcoma of the kidney has been characterized by late relapses. However, in trials after 1992, most relapses occurred within 3 years, and the most common sites of recurrence were the brain and the lungs.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

94883</a>

9489,<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

94905</a>

9491] In a series of 37 patients with clear cell sarcoma of the kidney who relapsed, the 5-year EFS rate after relapse was 18%, and the OS rate after relapse was 26%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

94925</a>

9493] </p>

9494<p id="_1053" tabindex="-1">

9495The optimal treatment of relapsed clear cell sarcoma of the kidney has not been established. Treatment of patients with recurrent clear cell sarcoma of the kidney depends on initial therapy and site of recurrence. </p>

9496<p id="_881" tabindex="-1">

9497Treatment options for recurrent clear cell sarcoma of the kidney include the following:</p>

9498<div class="pdq-content-list">

9499<ol id="_882">

9500<li>

9501Chemotherapy, complete surgical resection (if possible), and/or radiation therapy.</li>

9502</ol>

9503</div>

9504<p id="_883" tabindex="-1">

9505Cyclophosphamide and carboplatin should be considered if not used initially. Patients with recurrent clear cell sarcoma of the kidney, in some cases involving the brain, have responded to treatment with ifosfamide, carboplatin, and etoposide (ICE), coupled with local control consisting of surgical resection, radiation therapy, or both.[<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

95065</a>

9507]; [<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

95084</a>

9509][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9510Level of evidence B4</a>

9511] </p>

9512<p id="_954" tabindex="-1">

9513The use of high-dose chemotherapy followed by hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is undefined in patients with recurrent clear cell sarcoma of the kidney. A total of 24 patients with relapsed clear cell sarcoma of the kidney received high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous HSCT. Of those patients, 12 (50%) were alive without disease after a median of 52 months. Patients who had already achieved a second complete remission were more likely to receive high-dose chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

95144</a>

9515,<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

95165</a>

9517,<a href="#cit/section_5.18">

951818</a>

9519]</p>

9520<section id="_1817">

9521<h4 id="_1817_toc">

9522Treatment options under clinical evaluation for recurrent clear cell sarcoma of the kidney</h4>

9523<p id="_1836" tabindex="-1">

9524Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

9525NCI website</a>

9526. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

9527ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

9528.</p>

9529<p id="_1818" tabindex="-1">

9530The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

9531<div class="pdq-content-list">

9532<ul id="_1819">

9533<li>

9534<strong>

9535<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03155620">

9536APEC1621 (NCT03155620)</a>

9537</strong>

9538 (Pediatric MATCH: Targeted Therapy Directed by Genetic Testing in Treating Pediatric Patients with Relapsed or Refractory Advanced Solid Tumors, Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas, or Histiocytic Disorders)<strong>

9539:</strong>

9540 NCI-COG Pediatric Molecular Analysis for Therapeutic Choice (MATCH), referred to as Pediatric MATCH, will match targeted agents with specific molecular changes identified in a patient's tumor (refractory or recurrent). Children and adolescents aged 1 to 21 years are eligible for the trial.<p id="_2398" tabindex="-1">

9541Patients with tumors that have molecular variants addressed by open treatment arms in the trial may be enrolled in treatment on Pediatric MATCH. Additional information can be obtained on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match">

9542NCI website</a>

9543 and <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620">

9544ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

9545.</p>

9546

9547</li>

9548</ul>

9549</div>

9550</section>

9551</section>

9552<section id="_TrialSearch_10_sid_5">

9553<h3 id="_TrialSearch_10_sid_5_toc">

9554Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9555<p id="_TrialSearch_10_22" tabindex="-1">

9556Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9557advanced clinical trial search</a>

9558 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9559General information</a>

9560 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9561</section>
