9615[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9616</li>

9617<li id="section_5.14">

9618Kao YC, Sung YS, Zhang L, et al.: Recurrent BCOR Internal Tandem Duplication and YWHAE-NUTM2B Fusions in Soft Tissue Undifferentiated Round Cell Sarcoma of Infancy: Overlapping Genetic Features With Clear Cell Sarcoma of Kidney. Am J Surg Pathol 40 (8): 1009-20, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26945340&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26945340&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9619[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9620</li>

9621<li id="section_5.15">

9622Argani P, Pawel B, Szabo S, et al.: Diffuse Strong BCOR Immunoreactivity Is a Sensitive and Specific Marker for Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney (CCSK) in Pediatric Renal Neoplasia. Am J Surg Pathol 42 (8): 1128-1131, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29851702&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29851702&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9623[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9624</li>

9625<li id="section_5.16">

9626Kalapurakal JA, Perlman EJ, Seibel NL, et al.: Outcomes of patients with revised stage I clear cell sarcoma of kidney treated in National Wilms Tumor Studies 1-5. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 85 (2): 428-31, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22658515&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22658515&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9627[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9628</li>

9629<li id="section_5.17">

9630Seibel NL, Li S, Breslow NE, et al.: Effect of duration of treatment on treatment outcome for patients with clear-cell sarcoma of the kidney: a report from the National Wilms' Tumor Study Group. J Clin Oncol 22 (3): 468-73, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14752069&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14752069&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9631[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9632</li>

9633<li id="section_5.18">

9634Pein F, Michon J, Valteau-Couanet D, et al.: High-dose melphalan, etoposide, and carboplatin followed by autologous stem-cell rescue in pediatric high-risk recurrent Wilms' tumor: a French Society of Pediatric Oncology study. J Clin Oncol 16 (10): 3295-301, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9779704&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9779704&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9635[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9636</li>

9637</ol>

9638</div>

9639

9640 </section>

9641

9642

9643

9644 <section id="_429">

9645

9646 <h2>

9647Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma</h2>

9648

9649 <div id="_section_429" class="pdq-sections">

9650<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

9651<h6>

9652In This Section</h6>

9653<ul>

9654<li>

9655<a href="#_888_toc">

9656General Information About Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma</a>

9657</li>

9658<li>

9659<a href="#_283_toc">

9660Treatment of Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma<ul>

9661<li>

9662<a href="#_1040_toc">

9663Nephrectomy</a>

9664</li>

9665<li>

9666<a href="#_1041_toc">

9667Adjuvant chemotherapy</a>

9668</li>

9669</ul>

9670</a>

9671</li>

9672<li>

9673<a href="#_1951_toc">

9674Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma</a>

9675</li>

9676<li>

9677<a href="#_1312_toc">

9678Treatment of Recurrent Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma<ul>

9679<li>

9680<a href="#_1314_toc">

9681Treatment options under clinical evaluation for recurrent congenital mesoblastic nephroma</a>

9682</li>

9683</ul>

9684</a>

9685</li>

9686<li>

9687<a href="#_TrialSearch_429_sid_6_toc">

9688Current Clinical Trials</a>

9689</li>

9690</ul>

9691</nav>

9692<section id="_888">

9693<h3 id="_888_toc">

9694General Information About Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma</h3>

9695<p id="_430" tabindex="-1">

9696Mesoblastic nephroma comprises about 5% of childhood kidney tumors, and more than 90% of cases appear within the first year of life. More than 15% of the cases are detected prenatally.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

96971</a>

9698] It is the most common kidney tumor found in infants younger than 6 months, with a median age at diagnosis of 1 to 2 months.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

96992</a>

9700] Twice as many males as females are diagnosed. The diagnosis should be questioned when applied to individuals older than 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

97011</a>

9702] </p>

9703<p id="_1037" tabindex="-1">

9704When patients are diagnosed in the first 7 months of life, the 5-year event-free survival rate is 94%, and the overall survival (OS) rate is 96%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

97053</a>

9706] In a report from the United Kingdom of 50 children with mesoblastic nephroma studied on clinical trials and 80 cases from the national registry in the same time period, there were no deaths.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

97071</a>

9708] However, in a comprehensive review of the literature, 12 deaths were reported, 7 of which were the result of surgical complications in infants.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

97094</a>

9710][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9711Level of evidence C2</a>

9712]</p>

9713<p id="_431" tabindex="-1">

9714Grossly, mesoblastic nephromas appear as solitary, unilateral masses indistinguishable from nephroblastoma. Microscopically, they consist of spindled mesenchymal cells. Mesoblastic nephroma can be divided into the following three histological subtypes:</p>

9715<div class="pdq-content-list">

9716<ul id="_1038">

9717<li>

9718<strong>

9719Classic.</strong>

9720[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

97215</a>

9722]</li>

9723<li>

9724<strong>

9725Cellular.</strong>

9726 The cellular subtype is identical to infantile fibrosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

97276</a>

9728]</li>

9729<li>

9730<strong>

9731Mixed.</strong>

9732 The mixed subtype (&lt;10%) is a mixture of classic and cellular patterns.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

97337</a>

9734]</li>

9735</ul>

9736</div>

9737<p id="_1307" tabindex="-1">

9738A frequent genetic alteration is the translocation t(12;15)(q13;q25), resulting in a fusion of the <em class="gene-name">

9739ETV6</em>

9740 and <em class="gene-name">

9741NTRK3</em>

9742 genes on 15p15 that occurs almost exclusively in the cellular type of mesoblastic nephroma. In a cohort of 79 mesoblastic nephromas analyzed for the translocation, all classical (n = 38) and mixed (n = 12) mesoblastic nephromas were translocation negative.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

97438</a>

9744] Other rare mutations in cellular congenital mesoblastic nephroma include <em class="gene-name">

9745EML4</em>

9746::<em class="gene-name">

9747NRTK3</em>

9748 and <em class="gene-name">

9749LMNA</em>

9750::<em class="gene-name">

9751NRTK1</em>

9752 fusions, <em class="gene-name">

9753BRAF</em>

9754 internal duplications, <em class="gene-name">

9755RET</em>

9756 fusions, and <em class="gene-name">

9757ALK</em>

9758 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

97599</a>

9760,<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

976110</a>

9762] Classic congenital mesoblastic nephroma can also harbor <em class="gene-name">

9763EGFR</em>

9764 internal tandem duplications.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

976511</a>

9766] Cellular congenital mesoblastic nephroma shares its genetic and morphological hallmarks with infantile fibrosarcoma because mutations of <em class="gene-name">

9767NRTK3</em>

9768 and <em class="gene-name">

9769BRAF</em>

9770 have been reported in both tumor types.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

977112</a>

9772]</p>

9773<p id="_1039" tabindex="-1">

9774The risk of recurrence for patients with mesoblastic nephroma is closely associated with the presence of a cellular subtype and with stage III disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

97755</a>

9776] In an International Society of Paediatric Oncology (SIOP) series of 79 patients with congenital mesoblastic nephromas, patients within the cellular subgroup who had translocation-positive tumors had a significantly superior relapse-free survival (RFS) rate when compared with patients who did not have the gene fusion (100% vs. 73%, respectively).[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

97778</a>

9778]</p>

9779<p id="_963" tabindex="-1">

9780For more information about the clinical features and diagnostic evaluation of childhood kidney tumors, see the sections on <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_898">

9781Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

9782 and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

9783Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

9784.</p>

9785</section>

9786<section id="_283">

9787<h3 id="_283_toc">

9788Treatment of Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma</h3>

9789<p id="_1308" tabindex="-1">

9790The OS of patients with congenital mesoblastic nephroma is excellent. However, reported causes of death are treatment related in about one-half of the cases. Additionally, most of these patients were very young (median age, &lt;1 year).[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

97914</a>

9792] This underscores the special attention that infants with renal tumors require, with respect to timing and type of treatment and the importance of a dedicated expert pediatric oncology setting.</p>

9793<p id="_842" tabindex="-1">

9794Standard treatment options for stages I and II (80% of patients) and stage III (classic and mixed subtypes) congenital mesoblastic nephroma include the following:</p>

9795<div class="pdq-content-list">

9796<ol id="_897">

9797<li>

9798<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1040">

9799Nephrectomy only</a>

9800 (stages I and II all subtypes and stage III classic and mixed subtypes).</li>

9801<li>

9802<a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_1041">

9803Adjuvant chemotherapy</a>

9804 (stage III cellular subtype).</li>

9805</ol>

9806</div>

9807<section id="_1040">

9808<h4 id="_1040_toc">

9809Nephrectomy</h4>

9810<p id="_844" tabindex="-1">

9811Evidence (nephrectomy):</p>

9812<div class="pdq-content-list">

9813<ol id="_1944">

9814<li>

9815A SIOP/Gesellschaft f&#252;r P&#228;diatrische H&#228;matologie und Onkologie (GPOH) nephroblastoma study evaluated 111 patients with congenital mesoblastic nephromas. Sixty-seven patients had classical congenital mesoblastic nephromas (60%), 29 patients had the cellular subtype (26%), and 15 patients had the mixed subtype (14%). Tumor stage consisted of stage I (35%), stage II (50%), and stage III (15%). Ninety-one patients were treated with surgery alone, and 19 patients were treated with chemotherapy in addition to surgery (12 preoperatively and 11 postoperatively).[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

98168</a>

9817]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9818<ul id="_1945">

9819<li>

9820Overall, the 5-year RFS rate was 93.2%, and the 5-year OS rate was 96.8%</li>

9821<li>

9822The 5-year RFS rate was significantly superior for the classical type (98%) compared with the cellular type (89%, <em>

9823P</em>

9824 = .039) or mixed type (80%, <em>

9825P</em>

9826 = .002). There was no significant difference in OS by tumor types.</li>

9827<li>

9828Seven patients relapsed (five local and two combined) and three patients died because of local relapse (one of each histological type).</li>

9829<li>

9830Tissue was available for translocation analysis from 79 of the 111 tumors. Within the group of cellular congenital mesoblastic nephromas, patients who had translocation-positive tumors had a significantly improved RFS compared with the patients who had translocation-negative tumors (5-year RFS rate, 100% vs. 73%).</li>

9831</ul>

9832</div>

9833</li>

9834</ol>

9835</div>

9836</section>

9837<section id="_1041">

9838<h4 id="_1041_toc">

9839Adjuvant chemotherapy</h4>

9840<p id="_1042" tabindex="-1">

9841Adjuvant chemotherapy has been recommended for patients with stage III cellular subtype mesoblastic nephromas who are aged 3 months or older at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

98425</a>

9843] In a study of stage III cellular type congenital mesoblastic nephroma, 7 of 12 patients who were treated with surgery only suffered from a relapse, while 4 of 14 patients who were treated with adjuvant chemotherapy (primarily dactinomycin/vincristine and sometimes doxorubicin) developed a relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

98441</a>

9845,<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

98465</a>

9847,<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

984813</a>

9849] Cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide have been combined with these agents and have shown activity.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

985014</a>

9851]</p>

9852<p id="_1311" tabindex="-1">

9853Infants younger than 2 months with incompletely resected, stage III disease may not need chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

98541</a>

9855]</p>

9856</section>

9857</section>

9858<section id="_1951">

9859<h3 id="_1951_toc">

9860Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma</h3>

9861<p id="_1955" tabindex="-1">

9862Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

9863NCI website</a>

9864. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

9865ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

9866.</p>

9867</section>

9868<section id="_1312">

9869<h3 id="_1312_toc">

9870Treatment of Recurrent Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma</h3>

9871<p id="_2453" tabindex="-1">

9872Patients with most forms of recurrent childhood cancer should consider enrolling in available phase I and phase II clinical trials. Other treatment options for recurrent congenital mesoblastic nephroma are discussed below.</p>

9873<p id="_2454" tabindex="-1">

9874Palliative care remains a central focus of management regardless of whether disease-directed therapy is pursued at the time of progression. This ensures that quality of life is maximized while attempting to reduce symptoms and stress related to the terminal illness.</p>

9875<p id="_1313" tabindex="-1">

9876Relapses were reported in 4% of patients with congenital mesoblastic nephroma, and all relapses occurred within 12 months after diagnosis. Most relapses occurred locally, although metastatic relapses have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

98774</a>

9878] About 70% of patients who relapsed survived with individualized treatment comprising combinations of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

98794</a>

9880]</p>

9881<p id="_1946" tabindex="-1">

9882Targeted therapy should be considered for patients with recurrent or refractory disease containing the <em class="gene-name">

9883ETV6</em>

9884::<em class="gene-name">

9885NTRK3</em>

9886 fusion. Larotrectinib and entrectinib are NTRK inhibitors that are approved for adult and pediatric patients with solid tumors that have an <em class="gene-name">

9887NTRK</em>

9888 gene fusion without a known acquired resistance mutation, who are either metastatic or when surgical resection is likely to result in severe morbidity, and who have no satisfactory alternative treatments or whose cancer has progressed after treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

988915</a>

9890,<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

989116</a>

9892]</p>

9893<section id="_1314">

9894<h4 id="_1314_toc">

9895Treatment options under clinical evaluation for recurrent congenital mesoblastic nephroma</h4>

9896<p id="_1837" tabindex="-1">

9897Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

9898NCI website</a>

9899. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

9900ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

9901.</p>

9902<p id="_1838" tabindex="-1">

9903The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

9904<div class="pdq-content-list">

9905<ul id="_1316">

9906<li>

9907<strong>

9908<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03155620">

9909APEC1621 (NCT03155620)</a>

9910</strong>

9911 (Pediatric MATCH: Targeted Therapy Directed by Genetic Testing in Treating Pediatric Patients with Relapsed or Refractory Advanced Solid Tumors, Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas, or Histiocytic Disorders)<strong>

9912:</strong>

9913 NCI-COG Pediatric Molecular Analysis for Therapeutic Choice (MATCH), referred to as Pediatric MATCH, will match targeted agents with specific molecular changes identified in a patient's tumor (refractory or recurrent). Children and adolescents aged 1 to 21 years are eligible for the trial.<p id="_2399" tabindex="-1">

9914Patients with tumors that have molecular variants addressed by open treatment arms in the trial may be enrolled in treatment on Pediatric MATCH. Additional information can be obtained on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match">

9915NCI website</a>

9916 and <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620">

9917ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

9918.</p>

9919

9920<p id="_1843" tabindex="-1">

9921The cellular subtype of congenital mesoblastic nephroma, which commonly harbors the <em class="gene-name">

9922ETV6</em>

9923::<em class="gene-name">

9924NTRK3</em>

9925 fusion, is associated with relapsed disease. Patients should consider enrolling on this trial because one of the treatment arms (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03213704">

9926APEC1621A [NCT03213704]</a>

9927) uses larotrectinib, which inhibits <em class="gene-name">

9928NTRK</em>

9929 fusions.

9930</p>

9931</li>

9932<li>

9933<strong>

9934<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02637687">

9935LOXO-TRK-15003 (NCT02637687)</a>

9936</strong>

9937 (Oral TRK Inhibitor LOXO-101 for Treatment of Advanced Pediatric Solid or Primary Central Nervous System [CNS] Tumors)<strong>

9938:</strong>

9939 This is a multicenter, open-label, phase I study of pediatric patients with advanced solid

9940

9941or primary CNS tumors. LOXO-101 will be administered orally twice daily, with the

9942

9943dose adjusted by body surface area.</li>

9944</ul>

9945</div>

9946</section>

9947</section>

9948<section id="_TrialSearch_429_sid_6">

9949<h3 id="_TrialSearch_429_sid_6_toc">

9950Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9951<p id="_TrialSearch_429_22" tabindex="-1">

9952Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9953advanced clinical trial search</a>

9954 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9955General information</a>

9956 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9957</section>

9988</li>

9989<li id="section_6.8">

9990Vokuhl C, Nourkami-Tutdibi N, Furtw&#228;ngler R, et al.: ETV6-NTRK3 in congenital mesoblastic nephroma: A report of the SIOP/GPOH nephroblastoma study. Pediatr Blood Cancer 65 (4): , 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29286563&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29286563&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9991[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9992</li>

9993<li id="section_6.9">

9994Davis JL, Vargas SO, Rudzinski ER, et al.: Recurrent RET gene fusions in paediatric spindle mesenchymal neoplasms. Histopathology 76 (7): 1032-1041, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31994201&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31994201&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9995[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9996</li>

9997<li id="section_6.10">

9998Tan SY, Al-Ibraheemi A, Ahrens WA, et al.: ALK rearrangements in infantile fibrosarcoma-like spindle cell tumours of soft tissue and kidney. Histopathology 80 (4): 698-707, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34843129&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34843129&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9999[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10000</li>

10001<li id="section_6.11">

10002Wegert J, Vokuhl C, Collord G, et al.: Recurrent intragenic rearrangements of EGFR and BRAF in soft tissue tumors of infants. Nat Commun 9 (1): 2378, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29915264&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29915264&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10003[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10004</li>

10005<li id="section_6.12">

10006Knezevich SR, Garnett MJ, Pysher TJ, et al.: ETV6-NTRK3 gene fusions and trisomy 11 establish a histogenetic link between mesoblastic nephroma and congenital fibrosarcoma. Cancer Res 58 (22): 5046-8, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9823307&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9823307&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10007[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10008</li>

10009<li id="section_6.13">

10010Bayindir P, Guillerman RP, Hicks MJ, et al.: Cellular mesoblastic nephroma (infantile renal fibrosarcoma): institutional review of the clinical, diagnostic imaging, and pathologic features of a distinctive neoplasm of infancy. Pediatr Radiol 39 (10): 1066-74, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19629465&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19629465&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10011[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10012</li>

10013<li id="section_6.14">

10014McCahon E, Sorensen PH, Davis JH, et al.: Non-resectable congenital tumors with the ETV6-NTRK3 gene fusion are highly responsive to chemotherapy. Med Pediatr Oncol 40 (5): 288-92, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12652616&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12652616&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10015[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10016</li>

10017<li id="section_6.15">

10018Drilon A, Laetsch TW, Kummar S, et al.: Efficacy of Larotrectinib in TRK Fusion-Positive Cancers in Adults and Children. N Engl J Med 378 (8): 731-739, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29466156&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29466156&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10019[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10020</li>

10021<li id="section_6.16">

10022Entrectinib Shows Pediatric Potential. Cancer Discov 9 (7): OF4, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31113803&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31113803&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10023[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10024</li>

10025</ol>

10026</div>

10027

10028 </section>

10029

10030

10031

10032 <section id="_20">

10033

10034 <h2>

10035Ewing Sarcoma of the Kidney</h2>

10036

10037 <div id="_section_20" class="pdq-sections">

10038<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10039<h6>

10040In This Section</h6>

10041<ul>

10042<li>

10043<a href="#_889_toc">

10044General Information About Ewing Sarcoma of the Kidney</a>

10045</li>

10046<li>

10047<a href="#_106_toc">

10048Treatment of Ewing Sarcoma of the Kidney</a>

10049</li>

10050<li>

10051<a href="#_TrialSearch_20_sid_7_toc">

10052Current Clinical Trials</a>

10053</li>

10054</ul>

10055</nav>

10056<section id="_889">

10057<h3 id="_889_toc">

10058General Information About Ewing Sarcoma of the Kidney</h3>

10059<p id="_21" tabindex="-1">

10060Ewing sarcoma (previously known as neuroepithelial tumor) of the kidney is extremely rare (&lt;5% of renal tumors) and demonstrates a unique proclivity for young adults. It is a highly aggressive neoplasm, more often presenting with large tumors, penetration of the renal capsule, and extension into the renal vein.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

100611</a>

10062,<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

100632</a>

10064] In a literature review of 362 patients, the metastatic rate was 53.2%. Lymph node involvement was noted in 24% of the cases (13.9% in patients aged &lt;18 years vs. 28.4% in adult patients; <em>

10065P</em>

10066 = .07). All age groups showed a male predilection for nodal involvement, with significant sex differences seen in adolescent and young adult groups and adult groups (<em>

10067P</em>

10068 = .007 and <em>

10069P</em>

10070 = .002, respectively). The mortality rate was 21.5% at 1 year after diagnosis and 59.7% at 3 years after diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

100713</a>

10072][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10073Level of evidence C1</a>

10074]</p>

10075<p id="_1043" tabindex="-1">

10076Ewing sarcoma of the kidney is characterized by CD99 (MIC-2) positivity and

10077the detection of EWS::FLI1 fusion transcripts. Focal, atypical histological features

10078have been seen, including clear cell sarcoma, rhabdoid tumor, malignant

10079peripheral nerve sheath tumors, and paraganglioma.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

100801</a>

10081,<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

100824</a>

10083] </p>

10084</section>

10085<section id="_106">

10086<h3 id="_106_toc">

10087Treatment of Ewing Sarcoma of the Kidney</h3>

10088<p id="_849" tabindex="-1">

10089There is no consensus for the optimal treatment of Ewing sarcoma of the kidney because data are lacking. The current treatment approach is extrapolated from the experience of treating Ewing sarcoma at other sites with multimodal therapy consisting of multiagent chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiation therapy for local control. The MD Anderson Cancer Center reported their experience with 30 patients (median age, 30.5 years) with Ewing sarcoma of the kidney over a period of 23 years.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

100905</a>

10091]</p>

10092<div class="pdq-content-list">

10093<ul id="_2436">

10094<li>

10095Twenty percent of the patients had tumors confined to the kidney, 23% had tumors extending locally beyond the kidney, and 57% had metastasis at diagnosis (lungs, liver, and bone). The 4-year EFS and OS rates were 54% and 85%, respectively, for patients without metastasis at diagnosis, compared with 35% and 47%, respectively, for patients with metastasis. </li>

10096<li>

10097Patients with tumors confined to the kidney and treated with nephrectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy have favorable outcomes compared with patients who did not complete adjuvant therapy. Twelve of 13 patients with nonmetastatic disease who underwent upfront nephrectomy had a favorable outcome when adjuvant chemotherapy was used.</li>

10098<li>

10099Presence of tumor thrombus in the renal vein and/or inferior vena cave was associated with worse EFS (<em>

10100P</em>

10101 = .053).</li>

10102<li>

10103Unfavorable prognostic factors were local tumor extension beyond the kidney, tumor thrombus, and distant metastasis.</li>

10104<li>

10105The most commonly used chemotherapy was vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, ifosfamide, etoposide, cisplatin, irinotecan, and temozolomide. The most common initial chemotherapy used was vincristine, doxorubicin, and cyclophosphamide, either alone (23%) or in combination with ifosfamide and etoposide (23%). The second most common combination used was vincristine, doxorubicin, and ifosfamide.</li>

10106</ul>

10107</div>

10108<p id="_1044" tabindex="-1">

10109Treatment

10110according to Ewing sarcoma protocols should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

101111</a>

10112]</p>

10113<p id="_2012" tabindex="-1">

10114For more information, see <a href="/types/bone/hp/ewing-treatment-pdq">

10115Ewing Sarcoma and Undifferentiated Small Round Cell Sarcomas of Bone and Soft Tissue Treatment</a>

10116.</p>

10117</section>

10118<section id="_TrialSearch_20_sid_7">

10119<h3 id="_TrialSearch_20_sid_7_toc">

10120Current Clinical Trials</h3>

10121<p id="_TrialSearch_20_22" tabindex="-1">

10122Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

10123advanced clinical trial search</a>

10124 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

10125General information</a>

10126 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

10127</section>

10128<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10129References</h6>

10130<ol>

10131<li id="section_7.1">

10132Parham DM, Roloson GJ, Feely M, et al.: Primary malignant neuroepithelial tumors of the kidney: a clinicopathologic analysis of 146 adult and pediatric cases from the National Wilms' Tumor Study Group Pathology Center. Am J Surg Pathol 25 (2): 133-46, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11176062&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11176062&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10133[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10134</li>

10135<li id="section_7.2">

10136Tagarelli A, Spreafico F, Ferrari A, et al.: Primary renal soft tissue sarcoma in children. Urology 80 (3): 698-702, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22784490&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22784490&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10137[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10138</li>

10139<li id="section_7.3">

10140Bradford K, Nobori A, Johnson B, et al.: Primary Renal Ewing Sarcoma in Children and Young Adults. J Pediatr Hematol Oncol 42 (8): 474-481, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32282650&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32282650&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10141[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10142</li>

10143<li id="section_7.4">

10144Ellison DA, Parham DM, Bridge J, et al.: Immunohistochemistry of primary malignant neuroepithelial tumors of the kidney: a potential source of confusion? A study of 30 cases from the National Wilms Tumor Study Pathology Center. Hum Pathol 38 (2): 205-11, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17134738&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17134738&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10145[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10146</li>

10147<li id="section_7.5">

10148Tarek N, Said R, Andersen CR, et al.: Primary Ewing Sarcoma/Primitive Neuroectodermal Tumor of the Kidney: The MD Anderson Cancer Center Experience. Cancers (Basel) 12 (10): , 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33050651&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33050651&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10149[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10150</li>

10151</ol>

10152</div>

10153

10154 </section>

10155

10156

10157

10158 <section id="_1241">

10159

10160 <h2>

10161Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinoma</h2>

10162

10163 <div id="_section_1241" class="pdq-sections">

10164<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10165<h6>

10166In This Section</h6>

10167<ul>

10168<li>

10169<a href="#_1292_toc">

10170General Information About Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinoma</a>

10171</li>

10172<li>

10173<a href="#_1293_toc">

10174Treatment of Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinoma</a>

10175</li>

10176</ul>

10177</nav>

10178<section id="_1292">

10179<h3 id="_1292_toc">

10180General Information About Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinoma</h3>

10181<p id="_1242" tabindex="-1">

10182Myoepithelial carcinomas are aggressive malignancies primarily affecting soft tissues with occasional visceral origin. Approximately 20% of all reported cases have been described in children and are associated with a particularly unfavorable outcome, frequent development of metastases, and short overall survival.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

101831</a>

10184] </p>

10185<p id="_1253" tabindex="-1">

10186Two cases of primary renal myoepithelial carcinoma have occurred in children, and both cases had a translocation involving <em class="gene-name">

10187EWSR1</em>

10188 and the novel fusion partner <em class="gene-name">

10189KLF15</em>

10190, a transcription factor uniquely functioning within the kidney. Helpful features to establish the diagnosis include coexpression of cytokeratins, S-100, smooth muscle markers, and the documentation of <em class="gene-name">

10191EWSR1</em>

10192 rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

101932</a>

10194]</p>

10195</section>

10196<section id="_1293">

10197<h3 id="_1293_toc">

10198Treatment of Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinoma</h3>

10199<p id="_1249" tabindex="-1">

10200Although no standard therapy has been established, surgical resection of the primary tumor and pulmonary nodules (if present) has been used in addition to chemotherapy and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

102012</a>

10202]</p>

10203</section>

10204<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10205References</h6>

10206<ol>

10207<li id="section_8.1">

10208Gleason BC, Fletcher CD: Myoepithelial carcinoma of soft tissue in children: an aggressive neoplasm analyzed in a series of 29 cases. Am J Surg Pathol 31 (12): 1813-24, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18043035&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18043035&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10209[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10210</li>

10211<li id="section_8.2">

10212Cajaiba MM, Jennings LJ, Rohan SM, et al.: Expanding the Spectrum of Renal Tumors in Children: Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinomas With a Novel EWSR1-KLF15 Fusion. Am J Surg Pathol 40 (3): 386-94, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26523541&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26523541&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10213[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10214</li>

10215</ol>

10216</div>

10217

10218 </section>

10219

10220

10221

10222 <section id="_150">

10223

10224 <h2>

10225Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma</h2>

10226

10227 <div id="_section_150" class="pdq-sections">

10228<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10229<h6>

10230In This Section</h6>

10231<ul>

10232<li>

10233<a href="#_891_toc">

10234General Information About Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma</a>

10235</li>

10236<li>

10237<a href="#_855_toc">

10238Treatment of Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma</a>

10239</li>

10240</ul>

10241</nav>

10242<section id="_891">

10243<h3 id="_891_toc">

10244General Information About Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma</h3>

10245<p id="_151" tabindex="-1">

10246Cystic partially differentiated nephroblastoma is a rare cystic variant of Wilms tumor (1%), with unique pathological and clinical characteristics. The median age at presentation is 12 months. No patients with metastatic disease have been reported. Bilateral disease has occurred (4.4%). It has also been reported to occur in combination with contralateral Wilms tumor. Two of 113 patients identified in the literature had previous, concomitant, or subsequent other tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

102471</a>

10248] It is composed entirely of cysts, and their thin septa are the only solid portion of the tumor. The septa contain blastemal cells in any amount with or without embryonal stromal or epithelial cell type. Several pathological features distinguish this neoplasm from standard Wilms tumor. <em class="gene-name">

10249DICER1</em>

10250 mutations have not been reported in cystic partially differentiated nephroblastoma, which supports a distinction between multilocular cystic nephromas and cystic partially differentiated nephroblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

102512</a>

10252] Somatic hyperdiploidy has been reported in nonsyndromic patients (7 of 8 karyotyped cases).[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

102531</a>

10254]</p>

10255<p id="_969" tabindex="-1">

10256Recurrence has been reported after tumor spillage during surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

102573</a>

10258][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10259Level of evidence C1</a>

10260]</p>

10261<p id="_964" tabindex="-1">

10262For more information about the clinical features and diagnostic evaluation of childhood kidney tumors, see the sections on <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_898">

10263Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

10264 and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

10265Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

10266.</p>

10267</section>

10268<section id="_855">

10269<h3 id="_855_toc">

10270Treatment of Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma</h3>

10271<p id="_2437" tabindex="-1">

10272Surgery is the main treatment. Preoperative chemotherapy administration was reported in 20 of 98 patients. None of the preoperatively treated patients showed response to chemotherapy on imaging or histological examination.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

102731</a>

10274]</p>

10275<p id="_856" tabindex="-1">

10276Standard treatment options for cystic partially differentiated nephroblastoma include the following:</p>

10277<div class="pdq-content-list">

10278<ol id="_857">

10279<li>

10280Surgery. Patients with stage I disease have a 100% survival rate with surgery alone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

102814</a>

10282] </li>

10283<li>

10284Surgery and adjuvant chemotherapy. Patients with stage II disease have an excellent outcome with tumor resection followed by postoperative vincristine and dactinomycin.[<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

102854</a>

10286]</li>

10287</ol>

10288</div>

10289</section>

10290<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10291References</h6>

10292<ol>

10293<li id="section_9.1">

10294van Peer SE, Pleijte CJH, de Krijger RR, et al.: Clinical and Molecular Characteristics and Outcome of Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma and Cystic Nephroma: A Narrative Review of the Literature. Cancers (Basel) 13 (5): , 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33673661&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33673661&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10295[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10296</li>

10297<li id="section_9.2">

10298Cajaiba MM, Khanna G, Smith EA, et al.: Pediatric cystic nephromas: distinctive features and frequent DICER1 mutations. Hum Pathol 48: 81-7, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26772403&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26772403&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10299[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10300</li>

10301<li id="section_9.3">

10302Baker JM, Viero S, Kim PC, et al.: Stage III cystic partially differentiated nephroblastoma recurring after nephrectomy and chemotherapy. Pediatr Blood Cancer 50 (1): 129-31, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16786584&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16786584&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10303[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10304</li>

10305<li id="section_9.4">

10306Blakely ML, Shamberger RC, Norkool P, et al.: Outcome of children with cystic partially differentiated nephroblastoma treated with or without chemotherapy. J Pediatr Surg 38 (6): 897-900, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12778388&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12778388&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10307[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10308</li>

10309</ol>

10310</div>

10311

10312 </section>

10313

10314

10315

10316 <section id="_383">

10317

10318 <h2>

10319Multilocular Cystic Nephroma</h2>

10320

10321 <div id="_section_383" class="pdq-sections">

10322<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10323<h6>

10324In This Section</h6>

10325<ul>

10326<li>

10327<a href="#_892_toc">

10328General Information About Multilocular Cystic Nephroma</a>

10329</li>

10330<li>

10331<a href="#_858_toc">

10332Treatment of Multilocular Cystic Nephroma</a>

10333</li>

10334</ul>

10335</nav>

10336<section id="_892">

10337<h3 id="_892_toc">

10338General Information About Multilocular Cystic Nephroma</h3>

10339<p id="_1243" tabindex="-1">

10340Multilocular cystic nephromas are uncommon benign lesions consisting of cysts lined by renal epithelium. They are characterized by a bimodal age distribution, affecting either infants/young children or adult females. In the 167 cases reported in the literature, the median age at diagnosis was 16 months, with a range from prenatal diagnosis to age 16 years.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

103411</a>

10342] These lesions can occur bilaterally (5.3%), and a familial pattern has been reported. They have been reported to occur in combination with contralateral Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

103431</a>

10344]</p>

10345<p id="_1244" tabindex="-1">

10346<em class="gene-name">

10347DICER1</em>

10348 mutations (germline and/or somatic) were identified in 33 of 35 cases tested. In the series of 167 patients with cystic nephromas, 10 of the 12 patients with germline <em class="gene-name">

10349DICER1</em>

10350 mutations had previously or subsequently developed other tumors in addition to the cystic nephroma.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

103511</a>

10352] Multilocular cystic nephroma has been associated with pleuropulmonary blastoma and the <em class="gene-name">

10353DICER1</em>

10354 mutation. Anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney has also been associated with the <em class="gene-name">

10355DICER1</em>

10356 mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

103572</a>

10358] This is in contrast to adult cystic nephromas, which lack <em class="gene-name">

10359DICER1</em>

10360 mutations, and supports the difference between adult and pediatric cases. Genetic counseling, <em class="gene-name">

10361DICER1</em>

10362 mutation testing, and screening for lung lesions of a solid or cystic nature should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

103631</a>

10364,<a href="#cit/section_10.3">

103653</a>

10366-<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

103676</a>

10368]</p>

10369<p id="_1245" tabindex="-1">

10370For more information about the clinical features and diagnostic evaluation of childhood kidney tumors, see the sections on <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_898">

10371Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

10372 and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

10373Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

10374.</p>

10375</section>

10376<section id="_858">

10377<h3 id="_858_toc">

10378Treatment of Multilocular Cystic Nephroma</h3>

10379<p id="_859" tabindex="-1">

10380The standard treatment option for multilocular cystic nephroma is surgery.</p>

10381</section>

10382<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10383References</h6>

10384<ol>

10385<li id="section_10.1">

10386van Peer SE, Pleijte CJH, de Krijger RR, et al.: Clinical and Molecular Characteristics and Outcome of Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma and Cystic Nephroma: A Narrative Review of the Literature. Cancers (Basel) 13 (5): , 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33673661&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33673661&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10387[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10388</li>

Pediatr Blood Cancer 63 (7): 1272-5, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26928971&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26928971&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10391[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10392</li>

10395[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10396</li>

10397<li id="section_10.4">

10398Doros LA, Rossi CT, Yang J, et al.: DICER1 mutations in childhood cystic nephroma and its relationship to DICER1-renal sarcoma. Mod Pathol 27 (9): 1267-80, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24481001&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24481001&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10399[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10400</li>

10401<li id="section_10.5">

10402Cajaiba MM, Khanna G, Smith EA, et al.: Pediatric cystic nephromas: distinctive features and frequent DICER1 mutations. Hum Pathol 48: 81-7, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26772403&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26772403&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10403[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10404</li>

10405<li id="section_10.6">

10406Li Y, Pawel BR, Hill DA, et al.: Pediatric Cystic Nephroma Is Morphologically, Immunohistochemically, and Genetically Distinct From Adult Cystic Nephroma. Am J Surg Pathol 41 (4): 472-481, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28177962&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28177962&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10407[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10408</li>

10409</ol>

10410</div>

10411

10412 </section>

10413

10414

10415

10416 <section id="_440">

10417

10418 <h2>

10419Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney</h2>

10420

10421 <div id="_section_440" class="pdq-sections">

10422<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10423<h6>

10424In This Section</h6>

10425<ul>

10426<li>

10427<a href="#_894_toc">

10428General Information About Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney</a>

10429</li>

10430<li>

10431<a href="#_862_toc">

10432Treatment of Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney</a>

10433</li>

10434</ul>

10435</nav>

10436<section id="_894">

10437<h3 id="_894_toc">

10438General Information About Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney</h3>

10439<p id="_441" tabindex="-1">

10440Anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney is a rare renal tumor (approximately 25 reported cases) that has been identified mainly in patients younger than 15 years. The average presenting age is 12.6 years. The median age of presentation is 10 years, and the youngest presenting age is 7 months.[<a href="#cit/section_11.1">

104411</a>

10442] </p>

10443<p id="_1046" tabindex="-1">

10444Patients present with a renal mass, with the most common sites of metastases being the lungs, liver, and bones. For more information about the clinical features and diagnostic evaluation of childhood kidney tumors, see the sections on <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_898">

10445Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

10446 and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

10447Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

10448.</p>

10449<p id="_1047" tabindex="-1">

10450Studies have reported a few isolated cases of anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney that harbor mutations in <em class="gene-name">

10451DICER1</em>

10452.[<a href="#cit/section_11.2">

104532</a>

10454,<a href="#cit/section_11.3">

104553</a>

10456] These tumors show pathological features similar to those of pleuropulmonary blastoma of childhood and undifferentiated embryonal sarcoma of the liver. Next-generation sequencing was performed on nine pairs of anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney tumors/normal pairs, along with immunohistochemistry for <em class="gene-name">

10457TP53</em>

10458. Eight of the nine cases had at least one RNase IIIb <em class="gene-name">

10459DICER1</em>

10460 mutation that impacted the generation of miRNAS. Six tumors had truncating <em class="gene-name">

10461DICER1</em>

10462 mutations and in four of the samples, the mutation was also detected in the normal tissue. Six of the nine tumors had aberrant <em class="gene-name">

10463TP53</em>

10464 on immunohistochemistry. This suggests that most anaplastic sarcomas of the kidney have <em class="gene-name">

10465DICER1</em>

10466 mutations and they are part of the DICER1 syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

104674</a>

10468] For more information about pleuropulmonary blastoma, see <a href="/types/lung/hp/child-pleuropulmonary-blastoma-treatment-pdq">

10469Childhood Pleuropulmonary Blastoma Treatment</a>

10470. For more information about undifferentiated embryonal sarcoma of the liver, see the <a href="/types/liver/hp/child-liver-treatment-pdq#_378">

10471Treatment Options for Undifferentiated Embryonal Sarcoma of the Liver</a>

10472 section in Childhood Liver Cancer Treatment.</p>

10473<p id="_2438" tabindex="-1">

10474Screening for germline and somatic <em class="gene-name">

10475DICER1</em>

10476 mutations should be considered in suspected cases of anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_11.3">

104773</a>

10478] Screening for lung lesions of a solid or cystic nature should also be considered on the basis of age and <em class="gene-name">

10479DICER1</em>

10480 mutation testing.[<a href="#cit/section_11.5">

104815</a>

10482]</p>

10483<p id="_2439" tabindex="-1">

10484Somatic mutations in <em class="gene-name">

10485BRAF</em>

10486 p.V600E and <em class="gene-name">

10487PPM1D</em>

10488 have also been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

104896</a>

10490][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810041&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810041&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10491Level of evidence: D</a>

10492]</p>

10493</section>

10494<section id="_862">

10495<h3 id="_862_toc">

10496Treatment of Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney</h3>

10497<p id="_863" tabindex="-1">

10498There is no standard treatment option for anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney. In the past, these tumors have been treated as anaplastic Wilms tumor or with Ewing sarcoma therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

104997</a>

10500]; [<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

105016</a>

10502][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810041&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810041&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10503Level of evidence D</a>

10504]</p>

10505</section>

10506<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10507References</h6>

10508<ol>

10509<li id="section_11.1">

10510Wu MK, Cotter MB, Pears J, et al.: Tumor progression in DICER1-mutated cystic nephroma-witnessing the genesis of anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney. Hum Pathol 53: 114-20, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27036314&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27036314&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10511[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10512</li>

10513<li id="section_11.2">
