Am J Surg Pathol 24 (8): 1087-96, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10935649&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10935649&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10515[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10516</li>

10517<li id="section_11.3">

10518Wu MK, Goudie C, Druker H, et al.: Evolution of Renal Cysts to Anaplastic Sarcoma of Kidney in a Child With DICER1 Syndrome. Pediatr Blood Cancer 63 (7): 1272-5, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26928971&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26928971&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10519[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10520</li>

10521<li id="section_11.4">

10522Wu MK, Vujanic GM, Fahiminiya S, et al.: Anaplastic sarcomas of the kidney are characterized by DICER1 mutations. Mod Pathol 31 (1): 169-178, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28862265&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28862265&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10523[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10524</li>

10525<li id="section_11.5">

10526Doros LA, Rossi CT, Yang J, et al.: DICER1 mutations in childhood cystic nephroma and its relationship to DICER1-renal sarcoma. Mod Pathol 27 (9): 1267-80, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24481001&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24481001&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10527[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10528</li>

10529<li id="section_11.6">

10530Kroll-Wheeler L, Heider A: Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney With Heterologous Ganglioneuroblastic Differentiation: Another DICER1-Associated Tumor. Pediatr Dev Pathol 25 (2): 186-191, 2022 Mar-Apr.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34515577&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34515577&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10531[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10532</li>

10533<li id="section_11.7">

10534Vujani&#263; GM, Kelsey A, Perlman EJ, et al.: Anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney: a clinicopathologic study of 20 cases of a new entity with polyphenotypic features. Am J Surg Pathol 31 (10): 1459-68, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17895746&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17895746&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10535[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10536</li>

10537</ol>

10538</div>

10539

10540 </section>

10541

10542

10543

10544 <section id="_438">

10545

10546 <h2>

10547Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma</h2>

10548

10549 <div id="_section_438" class="pdq-sections">

10550<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10551<h6>

10552In This Section</h6>

10553<ul>

10554<li>

10555<a href="#_893_toc">

10556General Information About Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma</a>

10557</li>

10558<li>

10559<a href="#_860_toc">

10560Treatment of Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma</a>

10561</li>

10562</ul>

10563</nav>

10564<section id="_893">

10565<h3 id="_893_toc">

10566General Information About Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma</h3>

10567<p id="_439" tabindex="-1">

10568Primary renal synovial sarcoma is a subset of embryonal sarcoma of the kidney that occurs more often on the right side in young adults (median age, 36.2 years).[<a href="#cit/section_12.1">

105691</a>

10570] It is similar in histology to the monophasic spindle cell synovial sarcoma and contains cystic structures derived from dilated, trapped renal tubules. It is considered an aggressive tumor, with adverse patient outcomes in more than 50% of cases (n = 16).[<a href="#cit/section_12.2">

105712</a>

10572] Primary renal synovial sarcoma is characterized by the t(x;18)(p11;q11) <em class="gene-name">

10573SS18</em>

10574::<em class="gene-name">

10575SSX</em>

10576 translocation. A second alternative gene fusion variant, <em class="gene-name">

10577SS18</em>

10578::<em class="gene-name">

10579NEDD4</em>

10580, has also been identified.</p>

10581<p id="_965" tabindex="-1">

10582For more information about the clinical features and diagnostic evaluation of childhood kidney tumors, see the sections on <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_898">

10583Clinical Features of Wilms Tumor</a>

10584 and <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_900">

10585Diagnostic and Staging Evaluation for Wilms Tumor</a>

10586.</p>

10587</section>

10588<section id="_860">

10589<h3 id="_860_toc">

10590Treatment of Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma</h3>

10591<p id="_861" tabindex="-1">

10592Although no standard treatment guidelines exist, surgery is considered the treatment of choice. Chemotherapy (ifosfamide with doxorubicin or epirubicin) has been used in about 31% of cases in the adjuvant setting.[<a href="#cit/section_12.1">

105931</a>

10594] The chemotherapy regimens used differ from those traditionally used for Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_12.3">

105953</a>

10596]</p>

10597</section>

10598<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10599References</h6>

10600<ol>

10601<li id="section_12.1">

10602Blas L, Roberti J: Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma and Clinical and Pathological Findings: a Systematic Review. Curr Urol Rep 22 (4): 25, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33704587&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33704587&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10603[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10604</li>

10605<li id="section_12.2">

10606Schoolmeester JK, Cheville JC, Folpe AL: Synovial sarcoma of the kidney: a clinicopathologic, immunohistochemical, and molecular genetic study of 16 cases. Am J Surg Pathol 38 (1): 60-5, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24061517&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24061517&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10607[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10608</li>

10609<li id="section_12.3">

10610Argani P, Faria PA, Epstein JI, et al.: Primary renal synovial sarcoma: molecular and morphologic delineation of an entity previously included among embryonal sarcomas of the kidney. Am J Surg Pathol 24 (8): 1087-96, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10935649&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10935649&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10611[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10612</li>

10613</ol>

10614</div>

10615

10616 </section>

10617

10618

10619

10620 <section id="_436">

10621

10622 <h2>

10623Nephroblastomatosis</h2>

10624

10625 <div id="_section_436" class="pdq-sections">

10626<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10627<h6>

10628In This Section</h6>

10629<ul>

10630<li>

10631<a href="#_890_toc">

10632General Information About Nephroblastomatosis (Diffuse Hyperplastic Perilobar Nephroblastomatosis)</a>

10633</li>

10634<li>

10635<a href="#_850_toc">

10636Treatment of Nephroblastomatosis (Diffuse Hyperplastic Perilobar Nephroblastomatosis)</a>

10637</li>

10638</ul>

10639</nav>

10640<section id="_890">

10641<h3 id="_890_toc">

10642General Information About Nephroblastomatosis (Diffuse Hyperplastic Perilobar Nephroblastomatosis)</h3>

10643<p id="_437" tabindex="-1">

10644Some multifocal nephrogenic rests may become hyperplastic, which may produce a thick rind of blastemal or tubular cells that enlarge the kidney. Radiological studies may be helpful in making the difficult distinction between diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis and Wilms tumor. On magnetic resonance imaging, nephrogenic rests appear homogeneous and hypointense with contrast, whereas Wilms tumor has mixed echogenicity and inhomogeneous appearance. Incisional biopsies are difficult to interpret, and it is essential that the biopsy includes the juncture between the lesion and surrounding renal parenchyma.[<a href="#cit/section_13.1">

106451</a>

10646] Differentiation may occur after chemotherapy is administered. </p>

10647</section>

10648<section id="_850">

10649<h3 id="_850_toc">

10650Treatment of Nephroblastomatosis (Diffuse Hyperplastic Perilobar Nephroblastomatosis)</h3>

10651<p id="_2440" tabindex="-1">

10652Left untreated, all patients with diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis have been reported to develop Wilms tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_13.1">

106531</a>

10654,<a href="#cit/section_13.2">

106552</a>

10656] Although most cases of diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis are bilateral, a few cases have been reported with unilateral occurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_13.1">

106571</a>

10658] Until recently, diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis had not been prospectively studied by any of the pediatric oncology groups. As a result, patients have been treated in a variety of ways (observation, multiple chemotherapeutic agents in a nonstandard manner, or flank radiation therapy).[<a href="#cit/section_13.2">

106592</a>

10660] Additionally, a consistent definition of diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis has not been uniformly applied to all cases. </p>

10661<p id="_851" tabindex="-1">

10662Treatment options for diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis include the following:</p>

10663<div class="pdq-content-list">

10664<ol id="_852">

10665<li>

10666Preoperative chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_13.3">

106673</a>

10668]</li>

10669<li>

10670Renal-sparing surgery. Given the high incidence of bilaterality and subsequent Wilms tumors, renal-sparing surgery may be indicated.[<a href="#cit/section_13.1">

106711</a>

10672]</li>

10673</ol>

10674</div>

10675<p id="_1302" tabindex="-1">

10676Evidence (preoperative chemotherapy and surgery):</p>

10677<div class="pdq-content-list">

10678<ol id="_1303">

10679<li>

10680The Children&#8217;s Oncology Group <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00945009">

10681AREN0534 (NCT00945009)</a>

10682 study was the first clinical trial to prospectively enroll and uniformly treat patients with diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis. Patients were enrolled after having central radiological review. Diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis was defined as the cortical surface of the kidney being composed of hyperplastic rests, with the entire nephrogenic zone involved, and with a thick rind capping all of one or both kidneys. Patients were treated with induction chemotherapy consisting of vincristine and dactinomycin (regimen EE-4A) and had cross-sectional imaging at weeks 6 and 12. Therapy could be continued if the patient's disease was stable or decreasing. Maximum treatment duration was 19 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_13.3">

106833</a>

10684][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10685Level of evidence: C1</a>

10686]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10687<ul id="_2414">

10688<li>

10689Nine patients were enrolled, and the median age was 10 months. One patient was not evaluable based on radiological criteria for diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis. Eight patients had confirmed bilateral diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis and started chemotherapy without tissue diagnosis. One patient had an upfront partial nephrectomy that was found to have diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis in the specimen and was subsequently treated with EE-4A. All patients were alive at a median follow-up of 6.6 years (range, 4.5&#8211;9.1 years). </li>

10690<li>

10691No patients were anephric. Fourteen of the 16 kidneys were functioning (87.5%). </li>

10692<li>

10693Three of eight patients did not develop Wilms tumor. One of these patients had a complete radiographic response, one had a few sclerotic lesions at the end of therapy, and one had significant response but still had radiographic abnormalities. </li>

10694<li>

10695Five of eight patients had Wilms tumor at some point in their disease: one at diagnosis, one during therapy, and three after therapy (at 2 months and again at 4 months, 6 months, and 8 months). Only one of the patients developed a Wilms tumor with anaplastic histology.</li>

10696<li>

10697A 19-week course of EE-4A prevents some patients from developing Wilms tumor (three of eight), but it is not fully effective. The ideal duration of therapy remains unknown.</li>

10698</ul>

10699</div>

10700</li>

10701<li>

10702In a retrospective series of 52 patients with diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis (46 with confirmed diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis), 33 patients were treated with chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy initially, 16 patients underwent unilateral nephrectomy followed by adjuvant therapy, and 3 patients were observed only.[<a href="#cit/section_13.1">

107031</a>

10704]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10705<ul id="_1304">

10706<li>

10707A total of 24 patients developed Wilms tumor (including the 3 patients who were observed only), at a median of 30 months.</li>

10708<li>

10709Eighteen of the 33 patients who received chemotherapy alone developed a Wilms tumor.</li>

10710<li>

10711Of 16 patients who underwent a nephrectomy and adjuvant therapy, 3 developed Wilms tumor, despite the fact that 14 of 16 patients had bilateral disease.</li>

10712<li>

10713Thirty-three percent of the patients who developed Wilms tumor had anaplastic Wilms tumor at some time during their course, probably as a result of selection of chemotherapy-resistant tumors; thus, early detection is critical.</li>

10714</ul>

10715</div>

10716</li>

10717</ol>

10718</div>

10719</section>

10720<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10721References</h6>

10722<ol>

10723<li id="section_13.1">

10724Perlman EJ, Faria P, Soares A, et al.: Hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis: long-term survival of 52 patients. Pediatr Blood Cancer 46 (2): 203-21, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15816029&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15816029&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10725[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10726</li>

10727<li id="section_13.2">

10728Furtw&#228;ngler R, Schmolze M, Gr&#228;ber S, et al.: Pretreatment for bilateral nephroblastomatosis is an independent risk factor for progressive disease in patients with stage V nephroblastoma. Klin Padiatr 226 (3): 175-81, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24819388&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24819388&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10729[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10730</li>

10731<li id="section_13.3">

10732Ehrlich PF, Tornwall B, Chintagumpala MM, et al.: Kidney Preservation and Wilms Tumor Development in Children with Diffuse Hyperplastic Perilobar Nephroblastomatosis: A Report from the Children's Oncology Group Study AREN0534. Ann Surg Oncol 29 (5): 3252-3261, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35072864&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35072864&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10733[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10734</li>

10735</ol>

10736</div>

10737

10738 </section>

10739

10740

10741

10742 <section id="_1820">

10743

10744 <h2>

10745Special Considerations for the Treatment of Children With Cancer</h2>

10746

10747 <div id="_section_1820" class="pdq-sections">

10748<p id="_1821" tabindex="-1">

10749Cancer in children and adolescents is rare, although the overall incidence has been slowly increasing since 1975.[<a href="#cit/section_14.1">

107501</a>

10751] Children and adolescents with

10752cancer need to be referred to medical centers that have multidisciplinary teams

10753of cancer specialists with experience treating the cancers that occur during

10754childhood and adolescence. This multidisciplinary team approach incorporates

10755the skills of the following health care professionals and others to ensure that children receive treatment, supportive care, and rehabilitation that will achieve optimal survival and quality of life:</p>

10756<div class="pdq-content-list">

10757<ul id="_1827">

10758<li>

10759Primary care physicians.</li>

10760<li>

10761Pediatric surgical subspecialists.</li>

10762<li>

10763Radiation oncologists.</li>

10764<li>

10765Pediatric medical oncologists/hematologists.</li>

10766<li>

10767Rehabilitation specialists.</li>

10768<li>

10769Pediatric nurse specialists.</li>

10770<li>

10771Social workers.</li>

10772</ul>

10773</div>

10774<p id="_1832" tabindex="-1">

10775For information about supportive care for children and adolescents with cancer, see the summaries on <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/information-summaries/supportive-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/information-summaries/supportive-care">

10776Supportive and Palliative Care</a>

10777.</p>

10778<p id="_1822" tabindex="-1">

10779 The American Academy of

10780Pediatrics has outlined guidelines for pediatric cancer centers and their role in the treatment of

10781pediatric patients with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_14.2">

107822</a>

10783] At these pediatric cancer centers, clinical trials are

10784available for most of the types of cancer that occur in children and

10785adolescents, and the opportunity to participate is offered to

10786most patients and their families. Clinical trials for children and adolescents with

10787cancer are generally designed to compare potentially better therapy with current standard

10788therapy. Most of the progress

10789made in identifying curative therapies for childhood cancers has been achieved

10790through clinical trials under the auspices of cooperative groups such as the <a href="https://childrensoncologygroup.org/" title="https://childrensoncologygroup.org/">

10791Children's Oncology Group</a>

10792 (COG) and the <a href="https://siop-online.org/" title="https://siop-online.org/">

10793International Society of Paediatric Oncology</a>

10794 (SIOP). Information about ongoing clinical trials is

10795available from the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

10796NCI website</a>

10797. </p>

10798<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10799References</h6>

10800<ol>

10801<li id="section_14.1">

10802Smith MA, Seibel NL, Altekruse SF, et al.: Outcomes for children and adolescents with cancer: challenges for the twenty-first century. J Clin Oncol 28 (15): 2625-34, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20404250&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20404250&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10803[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10804</li>

10805<li id="section_14.2">

10806American Academy of Pediatrics: Standards for pediatric cancer centers. Pediatrics 134 (2): 410-4, 2014. <a href="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410" title="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410">

10807Also available online</a>

10808. Last accessed May 19, 2023.</li>

10809</ol>

10810</div>

10811

10812 </section>

10813

10814

10815

10816 <section id="_134">

10817

10818 <h2>

10819Changes to This Summary (09/11/2023)</h2>

10820

10821 <div id="_section_134" class="pdq-sections">

10822<p id="_137" tabindex="-1">

10823The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as

10824new information becomes available. This section describes the latest

10825changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

10826<p id="_2495" tabindex="-1">

10827Editorial changes were made to this summary.</p>

10828<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

10829This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

10830PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

10831, which is

10832editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

10833the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

10834information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

10835maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

10836About This PDQ Summary</a>

10837 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

10838PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

10839 pages.

10840</p>

10841</div>

10842

10843 </section>

10844

10845

10846

10847 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

10848

10849 <h2>

10850About This PDQ Summary</h2>

10851

10852 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

10853<section id="_AboutThis_2">

10854<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

10855Purpose of This Summary</h3>

10856<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

10857This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the treatment of Wilms tumor and other childhood kidney tumors. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

10858</section>

10859<section id="_AboutThis_4">

10860<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

10861Reviewers and Updates</h3>

10862<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

10863This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

10864PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

10865, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

10866<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

10867 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

10868<div class="pdq-content-list">

10869<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

10870<li>

10871be discussed at a meeting,</li>

10872<li>

10873be cited with text, or</li>

10874<li>

10875replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

10876</ul>

10877</div>

10878<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

10879Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

10880<p id="" tabindex="-1">

10881The lead reviewers for Wilms Tumor and Other Childhood Kidney Tumors Treatment are:</p>

10882<div class="pdq-content-list">

10883<ul id="">

10884<li>

10885Louis S. Constine, MD (James P. Wilmot Cancer Center at University of Rochester Medical Center)</li>

10886<li>

10887Andrea A. Hayes-Dixon, MD, FACS, FAAP (Howard University)</li>

10888<li>

10889Michael V. Ortiz, MD (Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center)</li>

10890<li>

10891Nita Louise Seibel, MD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

10892<li>

10893Stephen J. Shochat, MD (St. Jude Children's Research Hospital)</li>

10894<li>

10895Malcolm A. Smith, MD, PhD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

10896</ul>

10897</div>

10898<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

10899Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

10900Email Us</a>

10901. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

10902</section>

10903<section id="_AboutThis_10">

10904<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

10905Levels of Evidence</h3>

10906<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

10907Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

10908formal evidence ranking system</a>

10909 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

10910</section>

10911<section id="_AboutThis_12">

10912<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

10913Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

10914<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

10915PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

10916<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

10917The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

10918<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

10919PDQ&#174; Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Wilms Tumor and Other Childhood Kidney Tumors Treatment. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq">

10920https://www.cancer.gov/types/kidney/hp/wilms-treatment-pdq</a>

10921. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389282]</p>

10922<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

10923Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

10924Visuals Online</a>

10925, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

10926

10927</p>

10928</section>

10929<section id="_AboutThis_17">

10930<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

10931Disclaimer</h3>

10932<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

10933Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

10934Managing Cancer Care</a>

10935 page.</p>

10936</section>

10937<section id="_AboutThis_20">

10938<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

10939Contact Us</h3>

10940<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

10941More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

10942Contact Us for Help</a>

10943 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

10944Email Us</a>

10945.</p>

10946</section>
